story:
A cabin consumed by demons, homicidal trees, singing taxidermy, an incorrigible severed hand…

EVIL DEAD: THE MUSICAL presents incredible and expensive challenges for a nonprofit theater. Director Matt Kollar (Space Barbarians Productions) and our team of appetent designers and performers are leaning heavily on Sam Raimi’s beloved film trilogy (no, not Spider-Man) to inform decisions every step of the way. It's our responsibility to give the people what they want: the familiar frights and sounds they've known since the VHS era, with enough spewing crimson ichor to make a Deadite blush! We'll need all the evil we can muster for this sanguine showstopper, and since money is the root of all evil, we're asking for your support.

Q&A

"Who are you people?"

Since 2001, The Garage Theatre and its army of volunteers have transformed a humble space into diverse and immersive entertainment. Our 70th show (in our 15th season!) will be no exception. We're all huge fans of Bruce Campbell's classic cabin misadventures, and couldn't be more excited to bring the humor and horror of the original films to a live audience. The aim of this campaign is to supplement our modest production budget, allowing designers breathing room to pursue gruesome greatness and obliterate high expectations. A terrible evil is coming to the city of Long Beach this Halloween season, and only one boomstick-brandishing S-Mart employee will stop it - through song and dance!

"How are you using this money?"

Here's a breakdown of where finances will be allocated, should we meet our full goal:

Royalties - $3,900

Set Design/Build - $750

Props (Purchased & Custom-Built) - $1,150

Wardrobe - $300

Special Effects - $200

Stage Blood/Cleaning Supplies - $200

Lighting - $100

Sound - $60

The Garage Theatre is run by an all-volunteer staff so any additional funds received will go towards operations and future productions.

All donations are tax-deductable.

"I can't contribute, but would love to help?"

We're grateful you read this far down! There are other ways to help besides donating:

  • Share our campaign on social media
  • Follow us behind the scenes on Instagram
  • See our show this September/October 2016 in Long Beach, CA, or keep an eye out for production videos after the run!

story:
Charlottesville Ballet's 13/13/13 Campaign

Our goal is to raise $13,000 for our 13 company artists to launch us into our 13th season.

Your donations will directly benefit the artists of the Charlottesville Ballet. These dancers come from across the country and around the world to dance with us in Central Virginia. The money raised in this campaign will go towards their contracts, pointe shoe stipends, and the choreographer and performance fees accompanied by putting on shows across the state. 

 

Your Impact

To this date, the generous support of our donors has allowed Charlottesville Ballet to engage with our community through programs like:

  • Chance To Dance (C2D): an after-school outreach program for grades K-5 that gives underserved children a hands-on experience with the arts
  • Movement for Parkinson's: our free, weekly class open to anyone, with a special focus on creating a community for people with movement disorders and their care partners
  • Silver Swans: a collaborative program with The Center that gives free classes just for seniors 

Donor support has also allowed Charlottesville Ballet Academy to grow and train dancers with a focus on wellness—physical, mental, and emotional—in Charlottesville and Scottsville, Virginia. 

 

About Charlottesville Ballet

Founded in 2007 with a unique mission for dancer wellness, Charlottesville Ballet is the only full time professional dance company in the Charlottesville, Virginia area. Co-Directors Sara Clayborne and Emily Hartka are committed to elevating professional ballet with a healthy working environment for the artists. Read more at www.CharlottesvilleBallet.org/About.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Charlottesville Ballet appreciates any contribution you can make, and we can always use help getting the word out and sharing on social media!

Facebook: Charlottesville Ballet

Instagram: @cvilleballet

story:
Who Are We? 

We are Blood Pact Theatre, and we make plays. 

Blood Pact Theatre is a Toronto based indie-theatre company writing, developing, and producing original plays in the GTA since 2016. We have quickly cemented a strong reputation as the punk rock kids “bringing unique, fresh voices to the Canadian theatre scene” (NOW MAGAZINE). 

In 2016 our play Kill Your Parents in Viking Alberta premiered in The Storefront Theatre’s 2016/17 season with a box office record breaking sold out run. In March, 2017 we were invited to bring our play After Westling to Factory Theatre’s 2017/18 season earning equal success. This past December our newest play No Clowns Allowed ran for 2 weeks at Assembly Theatre in Parkdale to rave revues and adoration. 

We are gearing up to produce our new play Dock Mother God Society, written & directed by Bryce Hodgson. 

The Story 

Set in Kelowna British Columbia amidst the worst wild fire season in Canadian history, Dock Mother God Society is a play that explores modern western community and its relationship to death, family, generosity, resentment, forgiveness and our connection to the land we live on.

 The story is one act  that follows Ed, a recently sober, 32 year old  living with his reclusive widowed god mother, as he tries to win back his wife and young daughter.

Between his aunties stories of magical lake monsters, mermaids, talking trees and never ending war against everyone in her small bay community will he be able to stay sober, survive the summer and prove to his wife he’s in fit condition to come back home and try things again?

The Goal

We are hoping to raise $7000 for our new play, and the funds will be used to the following things:

Appropriate fees for all artists involved 

Set/building materials 

Publicity materials, so we can get the word out about our play

If you donate, you will be given the opportunity to claim some pretty sweet prizes, including free tickets, theatre themed swag and personal songs. 

The Team

Crew:

Bryce Hodgson, Writer/Director
Bri Proke, Producer
Quinn Hoodless, Lighting Designer 
Bryce Hodgson, Set Designer
Miss Langley, Sound Designer 
Marvin Araneta, Stage Manager

Cast:
Mark Paci, Ed
Elizabeth Saunders, Bev
Wayne Burns, Jay
John Healy, Rich

Risks & Challenges

Toronto's Indie theatre scene is constantly being faced with challenges, in many aspects, but especially proper funding for projects. Although our community is full of vibrant storytellers, artists, and dreamers, it is becoming increasingly difficult for those voices to be shared or heard. 

By donating you would be helping a great, passionate group of artists bring a new story to the stage, which we believe will be a fun, thought-provoking piece for many people. 

​How Else Can You Help? 

Donate today to take advantage of our stellar list of awards. If you can't donate (or even if you can) share our campaign with everyone on social media, emails, phone calls, even your mailman if he'd be open to hearing about that sort of thing. Get the story out, make some noise and help us bring Dock Mother God Society to life.

story:
a 501(c)(3) nonprofit

 

About Us

The mission of Ayana Arts is to bring together a community of young professionals seeking to further cultivate their passion and experience in the South Asian arts. We aim to encourage fusion across all art forms, geographic regions, and styles with the shared goal of creating an innovative and unique performance.

Ayana provides an enjoyable outlet for artists to collaborate, share and explore their talents. Above all, we will push the boundaries of traditional South Asian performing arts while remaining rooted in and honoring our South Asian culture and heritage.

As a 501(c)3 nonprofit, we are committed to serving our community through performance and service oriented programming.

 

Seasons of Love - Our Fourth Production!

On Saturday, October 26th, Ayana Arts will premiere its 2019 Annual Showcase, Seasons of Love, at the Manhattan Movement & Arts Center located in New York City. The production will interweave dance and music across the show's theme of Seasons, with four distinct sections: Summer, Fall, Winter, and Spring. Here is a glimpse into our past productions.

 

What We Need...

Ayana Arts is built on a passion for our mission and giving back to the community. As such, all of Ayana's artists, Board of Directors, choreographers, and musicians contribute to Ayana Arts on a volunteer basis. We ask for your kind support to help sustain our organization in the following ways:

  • Create: Help us to support our ever-growing group of artists. Funds will go toward practice space where artists can collaborate on new ideas and work on creating the magic you'll see at our showcase!
  • Engage: We are excited to continue producing annual showcases including this year's Seasons of Love. Help us to recover the costs of bringing this event to life.
  • Share: It's all about community. Your support helps us share our South Asian heritage with the local NYC-area and continue our philanthropic partnerships.

 

...and the Perks You'll Get!

Thank you for your contributions! We are excited to offer the following as a thank you for your generous support (all levels include onscreen and print recognition):

  • Bronze Level: Name recognition onscreen and in print at our show
  • Silver Level: A new addition to our Ayana swag- receive a reusable branded water bottle! Stay hydrated in Ayana style.
  • Gold Level: A new addition to our Ayana swag- stay en vogue and receive Ayana's first tote bag with print created by one of our own resident artists, Pia Sawhney. 
  • Platinum Level (LIMITED QUANTITY): Not one but TWO front section seat tickets (rows 1 & 2) to see Seasons of Love live! Experience the Ayana magic up close. 

 

**If purchasing after October 20th, name will only appear onscreen.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please support us however you can- any donations, no matter how small, are helpful for us and go straight to supporting Ayana Arts! If you are interested in joining Ayana Arts as a resident dancer, musician, or artist, please contact us through our website below.

We hope to see you at our upcoming performance!

Ayana Website | Facebook | YouTube

story:
We did it! What's next?

A tremendous thank you to all of our supporters! We are so honored and grateful for your contributions -- and inspired by what a community can do when it comes together to reach a goal! Let's keep this momentum going!

Our Reach Goal is $5,000 -- for our Summer Season

For those of you who would still like to contribute -- fear not! All additional funds raised above and beyond our orginal goal will be saved to continue paying the dancers for our exciting Summer Season.  (Quick preview: this includes a full-length performance on the Boston Common in July as part of the brand new Outside the Box Festival!) 

A total of $5,000 will allow us to pay the dancers an honorarium for summer performances.  So every dollar you give will still go directly to the artists involved.  Thank you again for your support! 

 

*      *      *

 

What’s quick and silver and dances all over?

Hello! and Welcome to the 2013 Indiegogo campaign for Quicksilver Dance: a modern dance company based in Cambridge, Massachusetts, which is growing like crazy!  In the last year, we’ve had two prestigious residencies, created several new, exciting dances, built up our core number of dancers from five to eight, and continued to reach out to new audiences.  We are on a roll! 

And now, Simmons Hall at MIT wants us back!  In what is becoming an annual tradition, Quicksilver Dance will transform the quirky theater in the architectural wonder that is Simmons Hall into another world.  On April 19th and 20th, 2013, we present our newest show:

“Rites of Passage”

The dances in “Rites of Passage” will bring you back in time to many different ages of humanity:

  • "Epoch Tales" is back by popular demand! Eight dancers echo the movement of various life-forms throughout evolutionary history, illuminating how the world may have moved from protozoa to primates.
  • “Got Art?” takes you on a journey through the history of consumerism, using text and movement inspired by print advertisements of the last hundred years.  This new dance promises to make you laugh out loud and think different(ly) about your daily dose of ads.
  • New sections of "Festivals and Visions,” based on 14 grand murals by the Spanish impressionist painter Joaquin Sorolla, explore the rituals, festivals and lifestyles of different regions of pre-WWI Spain. At our fall performance, we presented the first 6 sections, and now we are working on the remaining 8.  When all the sections are complete, “Festivals and Visions” will be Quicksilver's first full evening-length piece, a moving feast of ritual and culture. 

We hope you are as excited about these new pieces as we are. And guess what?  You can help to make it happen!

Our Goal is $4,000

This goal will allow us to pay each of our eight dancers $12 per hour and cover our fundraising costs.  It's not much; and in the future we hope to be able to pay the dancers more – but it's a start.  And in a world where dancers usually work several different jobs - waitressing, tutoring, teaching dance to kids - to support their passion, being paid to dance is what makes high-quality performances possible.

We are fortunate to have limited costs for the show.  Simmons Hall very generously funds the lights and lighting designer, in addition to providing their magical theater.  And because of Simmons’ sponsorship, tickets to the show are FREE!

So every dollar you give will go directly to the hard-working artists who will share their passion with you on April 19th and 20th! 

We have several fun and personalized perks available for you as a thank you for your donation.  See the sidebar for details!  Many of the dancers, and local friends’ businesses, will be contributing their creative energy and skills for these perks - so look for an option featuring your friend.

Our Very Own Rite of Passage

Quicksilver Dance has been growing by leaps and bounds over the last year.  Our overarching goal is to build a more sustainable and consistent organization, rather than a “pick-up company” of dancers.  Paying the dancers is one of the most important steps towards this goal, and is a big challenge for the entire dance world, especially here in the Boston area.

So your support not only helps a short-term goal of enabling the artistry of eight individual dancers, but will also foster the continued growth of Quicksilver Dance as an organization. 

Other Ways You Can Help!

We also greatly appreciate the many other ways you can help besides giving money: 

  • Come to the show!  Bring your friends! 
  • Get the word out, for the show and the fundraiser!  
  • Multiply your gift through the magic of social media, by using the Indiegogo share tools above!  
  • Got a venue, or an idea for a future collaboration?  Write to us at quicksilverdance@gmail.com!

The Two Who Tango

It takes two to tango, two to have a performance (dancer and audience) and two (donor and dance company) to make productions happen. We hope you’ll be our partner in all of the above.  We can’t thank you enough for your support!

 

                              www.quicksilverdance.com

Got a venue, or an idea for a future collaboration?  Write to us at quicksilverdance@gmail.com!

story:
“We’re just babies, us Americans. With fragmented bones that haven’t fused and hardened yet…”

 

 

Help us produce a staged reading of a new play! After three years of being written and rewritten, this story is ready to be told in front of a New York City audience.

We are set to present the reading at The Bridge at Shetler Studios on June 16th, 17th and 18th, 2013. But we need your help to get there!  

 

 

I AM NOT I is a new full-length play set in modern-day America. 15-year-old Jane Jiménez, the daughter of a Jewish mother and Mexican father, is about to have her quinceañera. However, as the celebration of her “transition into womanhood” approaches, Jane isn’t as much excited as she is horrified—because she doesn’t feel like a woman…In fact, she knows she’s not female at all.

Jane isn’t the only one trying to break free of the waltz she’s been taught in order to create a dance of her own. Her mother, Lisa, seems trapped in the past but is unable to find anyone else to live in it with her. Her father, Reynaldo, is about to break under the weight of the secrets he’s been hiding. Her lesbian girlfriend, Dawn, would run away from the trailer park in a heartbeat—if she didn’t have to play parent to her alcoholic mother. All four characters find themselves stepping off-beat, attempting to figure out the proper choreography. Do we truly have control over who we are? Are we fated to a prescribed story? Or do we have a choice in who we become? 

 

 

The team behind I AM NOT I is largely made up of Roundabout Theatre Company apprentices and Ithaca College “mafia” who wanted to create art together. The producing team, led by Kim Oria, consists of Maureen Keleher, Mara Abeleda and Blair Laurie. The creative team includes playwright Laura Abbott, director Chrysta Naron, and stage manager Erin Coen.

Laura Abbott is a contributing writer for Roundabout Theatre Company’s official blog and Upstage Playgoers Guide. A one-act she wrote while in high school, Trapped, is published through Playscripts, Inc. A rough draft of Trapped was a Top 20 finalist in Stephen Sondheim’s nationwide Young Playwrights competition. As a performer, she has been seen onstage at the Kitchen Theatre Company, St. Michael’s Playhouse, as well as acting under the direction of the incomparable Bob Moss. 

Chrysta Naron is a Brooklyn based director who has worked in New York, Texas, and Germany.  She worked as a prop intern at BAM on A WINTER'S TALE & THE CHERRY ORCHARD as part of Sam Mendes' The Bridge Project.  Chrysta also served as assistant director on THE TOWN OF NO ONE in the New York International Fringe Festival in 2011 and directed CHAIN REACTION in the New York International Fringe Festival in 2012. Chrysta serves as the totally rad Head of Production for Playsmiths.

 

As a staged reading, our budget is minimal. However, we do need help paying for some very important things:

- We need to pay our actors. Need to. They deserve it!

- We need to pay our artists! We’d like to bring a guitarist onboard. A talented person needs to read the stage directions for us. Someone made that video at the top of the page.

- Space! We can’t rehearse or perform without space. Those benches in Central Park might work, but we’d rather work with our actors inside a studio—and studios cost money!

- Props. Costume bits. Things that will help the performers bring the story to life.

- The little things. Like paying to advertise for auditions on Playbill. Keeping our actors hydrated by providing bottled water. Creating pretty programs for YOU to have when you come see the reading!

Take a look at the nifty incentives you can receive for helping us out!

 

Thank you to Adrian Rothschild for filming our campaign video!

Thank you to Maureen Keleher for choreographing and performing a dance in the video!

Music by Sueño de Dahlia.
story_txt:
“We’re just babies, us Americans. With fragmented bones that haven’t fused and hardened yet…”
 

 
Help us produce a staged reading of a new play! After three years of being written and rewritten, this story is ready to be told in front of a New York City audience.
We are set to present the reading at The Bridge at Shetler Studios on June 16th, 17th and 18th, 2013. But we need your help to get there!  
 

 
I AM NOT I is a new full-length play set in modern-day America. 15-year-old Jane Jiménez, the daughter of a Jewish mother and Mexican father, is about to have her quinceañera. However, as the celebration of her “transition into womanhood” approaches, Jane isn’t as much excited as she is horrified—because she doesn’t feel like a woman…In fact, she knows she’s not female at all.
Jane isn’t the only one trying to break free of the waltz she’s been taught in order to create a dance of her own. Her mother, Lisa, seems trapped in the past but is unable to find anyone else to live in it with her. Her father, Reynaldo, is about to break under the weight of the secrets he’s been hiding. Her lesbian girlfriend, Dawn, would run away from the trailer park in a heartbeat—if she didn’t have to play parent to her alcoholic mother. All four characters find themselves stepping off-beat, attempting to figure out the proper choreography. Do we truly have control over who we are? Are we fated to a prescribed story? Or do we have a choice in who we become? 
 
 
The team behind I AM NOT I is largely made up of Roundabout Theatre Company apprentices and Ithaca College “mafia” who wanted to create art together. The producing team, led by Kim Oria, consists of Maureen Keleher, Mara Abeleda and Blair Laurie. The creative team includes playwright Laura Abbott, director Chrysta Naron, and stage manager Erin Coen.
Laura Abbott is a contributing writer for Roundabout Theatre Company’s official blog and Upstage Playgoers Guide. A one-act she wrote while in high school, Trapped, is published through Playscripts, Inc. A rough draft of Trapped was a Top 20 finalist in Stephen Sondheim’s nationwide Young Playwrights competition. As a performer, she has been seen onstage at the Kitchen Theatre Company, St. Michael’s Playhouse, as well as acting under the direction of the incomparable Bob Moss. 
Chrysta Naron is a Brooklyn based director who has worked in New York, Texas, and Germany.  She worked as a prop intern at BAM on A WINTER'S TALE & THE CHERRY ORCHARD as part of Sam Mendes' The Bridge Project.  Chrysta also served as assistant director on THE TOWN OF NO ONE in the New York International Fringe Festival in 2011 and directed CHAIN REACTION in the New York International Fringe Festival in 2012. Chrysta serves as the totally rad Head of Production for Playsmiths.

- We need to pay our actors. Need to. They deserve it!
- We need to pay our artists! We’d like to bring a guitarist onboard. A talented person needs to read the stage directions for us. Someone made that video at the top of the page.
- Space! We can’t rehearse or perform without space. Those benches in Central Park might work, but we’d rather work with our actors inside a studio—and studios cost money!
- Props. Costume bits. Things that will help the performers bring the story to life. 
- The little things. Like paying to advertise for auditions on Playbill. Keeping our actors hydrated by providing bottled water. Creating pretty programs for YOU to have when you come see the reading!
Take a look at the nifty incentives you can receive for helping us out!

story:
Hey guys my names is Lenox Cedeno. Jesus, dance, and burgers are my passion! I live in New York City and have been dancing from the age of 16. I would rush out of school 3 days a week,make a 1hr trip to learn break dance in Queens. Surrounded by a community of bboys and dancers i was moved by the culture of dance and passion of the people in it.

     I’m raising money to attend the training program at Broadway dance center, located on 45th street between 8th and 9th avenue. My fundraising goal is 4000 dollars which would cover my tuition costs for the spring and summer semesters.I would be trained in all sort of dance styles ranging from street styles like from Hip hop, house, and street jazz, to more classic styles like ballet and Broadway jazz ! 

   You might ask “Lenox why do you even want to go to Broadway dance center?”Great question my friends; I’m part of a team that dreams of having an urban dance/recreation center. We are moved with the goal of having a facility that carries the atmosphere of righteousness, peace and joy. Could you imagine the neighborhood kids and families having a place where there is freedom and can be who they were made be! I personally dream to teach dance and change lives in this facility! Your donations are the beginning seeds in our process. Your seeds are what will plant the foundation of this community changing facility. The donations you provide will directly impact this vision by giving me an opportunity to better my craft and learn from the best dancers in the city ! This wouldn’t be possible without your help.

  If you want to help in any other way share this with your friends and family! Spread this through your social media by using indiegogo's social media links. Send in your email to Lenoxjcc@gmail.com if you want to be up to date with the projects i will be working on this summer! I will be needing your help, thank you and love ya'll.

Don't forget the perks !

Perk 1: 

You will get first hand look into the world of dance ! You might catch me with the other international students in the program or receiving a hello from one great staff member. The updates will be fun and worth a second look!

Perk 2:

Have you ever wanted to take a fun hip-hop class? Were going to throw down with some down to earth choreography but will be blessed by the experience! Claim this perk and receive a letter through the mail inviting you a hip-hop class in beautiful downtown Manhattan.

Perk 3:

Claim this perk and get a great one on one session with Lenox! You'll come out of their feeling good , a bit sweaty but with some new moves in your dance repertoire that you can show family and friends!

Perk 4:

Get a personal letter straight from Lenox! This letter will be more than a thank you note but an encouraging letter and invitation to start a correspondence during his months at Broadway dance center. You will also be sent a personal song from Lenox and his guitar ! Finally you will be invited to Lenox's Hip-hop class held in downtown Manhattan.

story:
Welcome to Acting Manitou's first Alumni Campaign!

This year, our goal is to sponsor a future Acting Manitou camper - someone who would be a perfect fit for the camp but cannot afford to attend. Acting Manitou has had a very special impact on every camper and now it's our turn to offer someone a chance to have the same experience!

Our goal: $1,100

We have been lucky enough to have a very generous Acting Manitou supporter promise a 1:1 match on every donation we receive! All of these funds will go straight towards the future camper's tuition.

The full support of the Acting Manitou alumni community can have an extremely positive impact and the Scholarship Foundation is confident we can reach this goal! Remember, everything counts! Any amount, regardless of how small, is a great step.

Other Ways to Help

If you just can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help! Remember to tell your AM friends about the campaign and get the word out about our goal!  

Spring Alumni Mixer

We are planning a spring mixer for Acting Manitou alums to get together with each other and beloved staff to network and share stories.  We'll let you know shortly about the specifics of the event.  

Thanks, 
Acting Manitou Scholarship Foundation

story:
Airmid Theatre is looking forward to a very exciting 2014.  We are now the only theatre company on Long Island to have received a coveted NATIONAL ENDOWMENT FOR THE ARTS grant and we are planning a superior set of programs.

To receive this grant, we need to match the NEA's donation of $3000. So, for every dollar you donate, another will be contributed, allowing us to to make this our greatest year yet!

This year we will present:

1. 4 MAJOR READINGS as part of our ALL SHE WROTE Reading & Discussion series; March 10, June 9 and two in the fall (dates TBD);

2. SUMMER THEATRE FESTIVAL, 2 productions, 30 performances (family series show, & main stage production of Anna Cora Mowatt's FASHION; a Long Island premiere). This event draws people from all across Long Island and the greater metro area for free professional theatre under the stars, in a recently rejuvenated park

3.  Special ENGAGEMENT PROGRAMS AND TALKBACKS during the festival;

4.  And we will launch the SHE SAID / HE SAID performance program comparing translations of classics by women vs. men. 

All these programs are presented FREE OF CHARGE and bring much needed cultural and educational activity to our region, a part of the country that is under-served artistically and culturally even though (or maybe because) we are in the shadow of NYC.

As we develop an even deeper engagement with the community, we hope you might consider becoming an Airmid donor / sponsor. 

It is a great time to align with a proven winner through personal or corporate support! 


WHAT PEOPLE ARE SAYING ABOUT AIRMID!

Airmid is a non-profit organization who brings the arts into a deeper dimension for the community. The productions are all first class! – maryg

Airmid brings the work of forgotten or unknown female playwrights to life for today’s audience - their productions are professional and profound - addressing issues that are both universal and timeless - thank you Airmid for keeping these works alive. --sirschwendy

I have attended readings and full productions. The crisp, professional acting and directing as well as the plays chosen provide exciting and enjoyable entertainment. The outdoor setting during the summer is delightful. I particularly enjoy becoming more familiar with works from women of various eras. Airmid Theatre Company is great! -- smdsings 

I think Airmid offers a great service to the community, both adult and youth. The productions I have experienced have offered top quality entertainment. I would recommend others to become fans/members/ or patrons of this company. -- flibertigibet

My wife and I attended our first outdoor Summer Festival Production and were extremely impressed with the quality of the acting and production value. Professional actors… brought genuine heart and soul to the performance. The humor they brought to the performance was a wonderful touch.--cmattern

I am a theatre professor with a specialization in plays by women, so I have been interested in Airmid for a while. The summer before last, I was in New York for a research trip. I took a train to Long Island to see both Airmid's children's play and a fabulous production of Aphra Behn's The Emperor of the Moon. Both productions were staged outdoors in a beautiful park, and both were very good. The company operates on donations, bringing free theatre to its community. I think they also serve an important function by bringing attention to neglected classic works by female authors. I am impressed with what they were able to do on a shoestring budget. -- maria

story:
WE CAN'T HEAR YOU!!!

We need a sound system! We were able to fund the opening of a new dinner theatre on the Jersey shore, in an historic building from the late 1800's.  We purchased the lighting system and rigging, but cannot afford the sound.  What good is doing professional quality productions if nobody can hear them!? 

What do we need? Why do we need it?...

WHAT: Well, we need a professional audio system. You can find the details of what we're looking to purchase further down... but the situation is desperate financially.

WHY: We're simply out of funds.  We have purchased the lighting and the rigging. We have purchased the rights to a bunch of wonderful shows for this awesome new little theatre, with everything from musicals, to dramas, to theatre for young audiences.  It's eclectic and it's exciting! But now we are tapped out... Help us get there!


About Coastal Artists...
Coastal Artists is an organization based on the beautiful New Jersey shore. It is dedicated to forging the emergence of quality, passionate talent in the crafts of theatre, film, music, dance, photography, modeling, drawing, painting, and sculpting. It hopes to open its members to professional and semi-professional endeavors. We have been luck enough to do some really cool things over the past few years. We produced/designed the Miss New York Pageant for the Miss America Organization. We offered theatrical technical direction, rigging, lighting support, and fly system operation, as well as special projects to Season One of SMASH for NBC Studios/Dreamworks. We served as the technical and design team for "Midnight Love", the show and wedding of Shaun T (Insanity, T-25, Hip Hop Abs). We have designed, built, produced, directed and cast theatrical productions for venues throughout NY and NJ. And now we are an in-house theatre company for the historic Jersey Shore Arts Center in Ocean Grove, NJ, which is where we need your help!!!  You can see what we have coming up at www.coastalartists.org

Who's hungry??
The new little theatre space comes along with the opening of the kitchen/dining room area in the newly renovated 3rd floor of the historic Jersey Shore Arts Center. It will also function as a culinary school for the visually impaired! (I mean, how cool is that?!)

THE PERKS!
You can get everything from thank yous, to free photo sessions, to tickets, to having our photography/studio theatre space named after you! But, what is far more important, is that we will be able to bring quality entertainment to this historic building.  No community is complete without a thriving arts and theatre scene!

The System:
This is basically what we are looking to purchase:
  • Behringer X32 digital mixing console with digital snake
  • (2) JBL PRX735 Full Range Main System
  • (2) JBL PRX718XLF Subwoofer
  • (4) JBL PRX712 Monitors
  • (5) Shure UHF-R Professional Dual Wireless Microphone System w/handheld SM58s and UR1 Bodypacks w/a combo of broadway quality headset and lavalier microphones (a total of 10 wireless setups)
The system is designed so that it may be integrated into a larger system for concerts in the arts centers main 600-seat theatre space, and as money and expansion of the system would allow.  (example: the mains can become side-fill monitors for a larger concert, the X32 could be a monitor console, etc)

We want to be heard! Please help in any way you can! 
Even if you can't contribute, please share this with anyone you think might be able to.  Thank you all! Much love.

story:
About us:

Perchance To Dream Theatre is a new theatre company dedicated to fresh and spirited interpretations of new and classic works.  We are committed to the highest level of artistic and professional standards and to keeping our ticket prices affordable. We believe theatre should be accessible to all and is an integral part of an international cultural community.

PTDT is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the purposes of Perchance To Dream Theatre must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

What's this all about?

PTDT is excited to announce its 2013 season!  We have a huge selection of original and unique works and we need help getting it off the ground!  Here's what we have in store:

ANTIGONE - This is an original adaptation devised by the company members of PTDT.  The script is an entirely new piece inspired by the Dover edition of Sophocles's Antigone, as well as the other plays in the Oedipus cycle, and will feature unique masks designed by Elizabeth Dapo. 

A DAY DREAM - In both the winter and summer of 2013 PTDT will continue our successful 24 hour play festival featuring 7 ten-minute plays conceived, written, rehearsed and performed in the span of a day. 

THE COMEDY OF ERRORS- One of Shakespeare's funniest plays where two sets of twins mean an abundance of cases of mistaken identity!

27/29 - A workshop production of this brand-new play inspired by Shakespeare's Sonnets 27, 28 and 29, written exclusively by Lindsay Calleran for Perchance To Dream Theatre.

Ok.  I'm interested.  Where will my money go?

The money you contribute to our campaign goes completely towards our 2013 Season - performance/rehearsal space, sets, costumes, props, marketing, and artist fees. We have on board a complete production team of professional costume, set, lighting, sound, and projection designers!  If you donate just $10 you help pay for an hour of rehearsal!  $25 will pay for 50 postcards! $75 will pay an actor! $500 will purchase an entire set!

Best of all WE HAVE SO MANY AMAZING PERKS!!  The more you donate, the more we can do for you! We have one-of-a-kind buttons with our logo, t-shirts, bags, season tickets, posters and other amazing deals, including AN AUTHENTIC SHAKESPEAREAN DINNER PREPARED BY THE COMPANY and EVEN AN ORIGINAL MASK DESIGNED BY ELIZABETH DAPO. See details to the right!

And with the holidays approaching, what greater gift is there than that of the arts!  Donate and you not only get something for yourself, but you help to give the gift of the theatre to the community at large!

Why donate to us specifically?

As a company, we feel that Shakespeare and other classic texts can and should be more accessible to all.  We strive to take these classic works off the pedestals that scholars place them on and show the people, the poetry, the relationships and the life and death struggles of these characters and how real and modern they can be.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute fiscally?  SHARE OUR STORY ON FACEBOOK, TWITTER, EMAIL, PINTEREST, ANYTHING! Tell your friends! Talk us up! 

https://www.facebook.com/PerchanceToDreamTheatre

http://www.twitter.com/p2dreamtheatre

We thank you for your support and look forward to bringing you an amazing season!

THE COMEDY OF ERRORS- One of Shakespeare's funniest plays where two sets of twins mean an abundance of cases of mistaken identity!
27/29 - A workshop production of this brand-new play inspired by Shakespeare's Sonnets 27, 28 and 29, written exclusively by Lindsay Calleran for Perchance To Dream Theatre.
Ok.  I'm interested.  Where will my money go?


The money you contribute to our campaign goes completely towards our 2013 Season - performance/rehearsal space, sets, costumes, props, marketing, and artist fees. We have on board a complete production team of professional costume, set, lighting, sound, and projection designers!  If you donate just $10 you help pay for an hour of rehearsal!  $25 will pay for 50 postcards! $75 will pay an actor! $500 will purchase an entire set!
Best of all WE HAVE SO MANY AMAZING PERKS!!  The more you donate, the more we can do for you! We have one-of-a-kind buttons with our logo, t-shirts, bags, season tickets, posters and other amazing deals, including AN AUTHENTIC SHAKESPEAREAN DINNER PREPARED BY THE COMPANY and EVEN AN ORIGINAL MASK DESIGNED BY ELIZABETH DAPO. See details to the right!
And with the holidays approaching, what greater gift is there than that of the arts!  Donate and you not only get something for yourself, but you help to give the gift of the theatre to the community at large!



Why donate to us specifically?
As a company, we feel that Shakespeare and other classic texts can and should be more accessible to all.  We strive to take these classic works off the pedestals that scholars place them on and show the people, the poetry, the relationships and the life and death struggles of these characters and how real and modern they can be.
Other Ways You Can Help


Can't contribute fiscally?  SHARE OUR STORY ON FACEBOOK, TWITTER, EMAIL, PINTEREST, ANYTHING! Tell your friends! Talk us up! 
https://www.facebook.com/PerchanceToDreamTheatre
http://www.twitter.com/p2dreamtheatre
We thank you for your support and look forward to bringing you an amazing season!

story:
Our Story

Hello! First, we want to thank you for taking the time to visit our project's page. Just by doing so, you have shown yourself to be a supportive member of the theatre community. You are our favorite kind of people! +1,000,000 points for you!


We are a group of students at Brown University who have taken on the enormous, daunting, and thoroughly exciting task of founding a repertory company! The Repertory Project (the company's current name) is founded on the values on creating an open, giving, and, most importantly, collaborative environment for creating theatre, while producing work that is both accessible and important to the community at large. We may no know much, but we all believe in the power that theatre has to affect a community, and we want to do just that.


We are new to running a company, but we are jumping in head first, producing our first season this February. The theme of this season is 'The Art of Collaboration." Collaboration is an enormous part of every person's life. From negotiating challenging foreign relations issues to putting on a play, collaboration is about how we connect with each other in our attempt to make a difference in our world. Through the two productions we will present, David Mamet's contemporary classic "Speed-the-Plow," and Michael Hollinger's new play "Opus," we hope to start a conversation in the community about the joys and challenges of collaboration in each of our lives, and what it means to work with others toward a single goal. In a community of young people who are the world's future movers and shakers, we feel like this is an important conversation to have, and one that theatre can effectively take a part in starting.


The Impact

Our project's impact is two-fold. First, there is the impact of important learning experience for the students involved. Students involved in the repertory project (15 and counting) have the unique experience of working in a professional, but fun environment where they teach and learn from each other on a daily basis. For example, all actors work on the stage crew of the production the are not performing in, to give them a different perspective on the theatrical creative process. In such ways, we hope The Repertory Project will help student artists grow into working professionals with the skills to be great leaders and collaborators.

The second leg of our impact is on the community at large. We will be presenting our shows FREE (that's right, absolutely free) for the entire weekend. With six total performances, over 500 people will be able to see theatre without spending a penny. That doesn't just apply to Brown students. ANYONE in the world can reserve a ticket and come to the show. In such a way, we hope to reach out beyond Brown's borders and bring together students with members of the community at-large to share the work we will have created.


What We Need & What You Get

We have trimmed our needs down to the bare minimum. We don't want to waste your money! We want to put it to good use. However, all we have now working for us is a free space and a lot of enthusiasm. Below are our bare minimum needs:


Royalties: $650- That's right. Just to be legally allowed to put on our six performances, this is the price we must pay.


Sets: $350- That's right. We are going to attempt to build two ENTIRELY different sets for just this much. It will take a lot of work and savvy spending, but we think we can do it.


Costumes: $200- We need over 20 costumes to make our season run. We have our amazing designer attempting to make this happen for only $10 per costume. She has her work cut out for her.


Props: $200- Screenplays and cheesecake and violin cases, telephones and wine glasses and music stand bases, smashable instruments tuned up with strings, these are a few of our necessary things.


Publicity: $100- Word-of-mouth is golden, but how can we create word-of-mouth without fliers and posters to spread to the community?


Remember: This is the BARE MINIMUM we need to function. Please help us meet and exceed our goal. Any funds beyond our goal of $1500 will go to bettering our productions and outreach to help bring diverse audiences to our shows. 


So, what do you get for helping out (besides the feeling of eternal awesomeness for being part of such a cool project)? Check out our "Perks" listings. They are, guaranteed, some of the best available.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please, if you like what we're doing, use the magic of social networking to spread the word! Post about us on facebook! Tweet about us! Make a youtube video of cute kittens singing our praises! You'll want to spread the word because we have a...


SPECIAL DEAL: If we meet or exceed our goal, the entire company will perform a song that includes every contributor's name live on closing night. This song will be videotaped and posted on youtube.

story:
Who we are and What we do

 

The GOOD Works Theatre Festival is an international, four-day festival celebrating new and emerging playwrights, presenting original works July 25-28, 2013.


The Good Works Theatre Festival is more than a theatre festival; it is representative of a grandiose, international community of artists who have collaborated as playwrights, actors, directors, stage managers and designers. Selected works will be presented to an audience in a festival setting where the heart of the matter is the celebration of the craft and artistry of playwrights. GOOD Acting Studio has facilitated a strong line-up of national, local, and regional talent to be your storytellers for a four-night engagement, turning a bright spotlight on Atlanta, Georgia.

Why we are different

We are an international festival! One goal of the festival is to facilitate an exchange of works from country to country.

The GWTF spirit is a desire to see a circulation of works and ideas that will become a movement that will celebrate and revitalize playwrights everywhere.

We want to use this festival as a vehicle to bring the world of the arts together. To take one piece of work in one geographical location, and then see it in a new place and culture, seeing how similar it can be and different at the same time.

The top two plays will be sent to  theatre companies around the world in an exchange of works that will become international productions.

 

We need your help!

Our Indiegogo fundraising goal is $1200.

Publicity, lighting and sound equipment, set and props , printing costs, oh my!

Ticket revenue currently only offsets roughly one-third of theatre production costs, which makes your involvement crucial to our success.

Your donations will go towards funding these essential areas of our festival

Imagine the thrill of knowing YOUR gift is another step closer to putting a dream on center stage.

 

 

The GOOD Works Theatre Festival 2012 Success stories!

21 actors. 7 plays. 4 days. 1 place.

You can see last year's promo video at the top of our page!

Last year's inaugural festival took place at Atlanta's own 14th Street Playhouse.   With consistantly sold out performances, we were truly able to bring new GOOD works to our theatre community. Live talkbacks with our audience gave an opportunity for  the playwrights and directors to recieve feedback to further their play's growth.

Our top plays were chosen and we are currently working towards an international production in 2014!

We had some wonderful acknowledgments from the city as well!

View our files below to see a Proclamation in honor of The GOOD Works Theatre Festival from  Atlanta City Councilman, Michael Julian Bond.

You can also view our letter from Atlanta's Mayor, Kasim Reed!

Other Ways You Can Help

The GWTF provides an avenue for new, emerging writers to have their voices heard in today's world of theatre. This festival can't happen without you!

We need to reach our goal to make this festival a reality. Donate and help our festival move forward! We understand that not everyone can donate monetarily, If you are interested in being a sponsor or volunteering, please contact us at: (404) 647-2484.

But most importantly, spread the word about our festival and our fundraiser! Every little bit helps! Be sure to use Indiegogo's share tools.

Thank you for taking the time to check us out!

story:
Summary

How misérable? Très misérable. The French are always complaining, but they do it with such style and musical genius that we can forgive them and dedicate a show to them and their plight.  

'Tres Mis' is the comedic spawn of Alice Tovey, Sam Garlepp and Lachie McKenzie. One day, whilst warming up for another comedy show, we started singing Les Mis songs and thought "this is not funny, this is sad." So we stopped and vowed to change all that. 

Just six months later, with many significant alterations to the script, Tres Mis has come to fruition. Join us as we explore this well-known story from a peculiar angle. There will be singing, sketches, accents and many quick costume changes. 

We will perform our show at the Melbourne International Comedy Festival. As a group of new performers, we don't have the financial backing or gravitas of other comedians. Whatever your contribution, even if it's only spreading the word, you will be helping us fulfil a dream that we once dreamed.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $2000 to make the show happen. Venue hire is the biggest cost. On top of that we need costumes, set, equipment, and fees and insurance. Performers aren't getting paid (obviously!) and we've got volunteer producers, publicists, composers, accompanist, and technicians to keep down costs. 

But what about the perks? Well. Mon Dieu. You are in for a treat. Check them out in the perks column on the right.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute funds, that doesn’t mean you can’t help!

  • Spread the word! Les Mis fans are everywhere and they will want to see the funny side of misery. 

  • Like us on Facebook and check out our other social media channels for free hilarious content. 

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
Love Letters Cabaret was founded by Pastel Supernova in celebration of love and beauty in pursuit of finding ways to free the audience from any inhibitions to enjoy the subtleties of seduction. The company uses elements of cabaret, vaudeville and burlesque to tell stories and explore decadence, primal instincts and romance. Love Letters has just begun production for it's second full length show ever, "The Bacchanal" and needs your help raising money for wages, costumes, props and sets.

 

Love Letters Cabaret  is preparing "The Bacchanal". This will be the company's second full length (1.5hr) show with a cast of dancers & musicians. Dailey Ensemble rehearsals have already begun and will continue to do so for the next two months until show days: Oct 31st & Nov 1st. We need you! Help us raise $5000+ so that all of our talent gets paid, costumed sparkled and our performance space gets transformed into a magical world just for you!

Production:

Artistic Director and Choreographer:  Pastel Supernova

Producer:  Karen Brar

Stage Manager & Rehearsal Director:  Kasia Rheann

Assistant Choreographer:  KJ McNight

Company Dancers: 

Pastel Supernova

KJ McKnight

Lianna Lewis

Brittany-Brie D'Amico

Meghan Norah Smith

Kate Knox

Julie McLachlan

Katelynn Goulding

Marisa Ricci

Gary Lucich

Jackie English

Aidan Morris

Karen Murray

 

Love Letters Cabaret currently has NO budget and at this point if we achieve our goal our performers would be paid an honorarium, which isn't much but it'll show appreciation. Each cast member is professionally trained and has extensive performance experience and they deserve payment for all their well earned work, just like any other skilled worker.  

Our main Sponsor LULA LOUNGE has graciously allowed Love Letters Cabaret a rehearsal home to rehearse and we are extreamly thankful! Photographer Billy Archos has also donated a company photoshoot to help create our promo material.

If we raise $5000 the funds will be divided as follows:

$1,065 will costume 20 performers, props and set 

$230 honorarium to each principal dancer (12)

$500 will pay the in house sound & lighting technician 

$150 will go to labor costs for costume making

$150 honorarium to the producer

$150 honorarium to the stage manager/ rehearsal director 

$45  honorarium to guest performers & musicians (5)

If we don't meet our goal the funds will be distributed in the following sequence;  

-sound and lighting technician (non negotiable)

-costumes and labour

-cast (will divide the remainder of the funds) 

Everyone involved believes in this project. We are all dedicated to the preparation necessary in order to deliver a gorgeous show.

 "Choreographer Pastel Supernova titillates her audience into a daze of complicity during a night of mischievous seduction." -- Judith Cockman, Blogger

Of course we dont expect you to walk away empty handed so everytime you donate you can choose from the following presents...

A Jukari class; Private Ballroom dancing classes; Pastel Supernova 2013 PinUp calendar; tickets to the show; autographed cast poster; dance up a sweat classes; website shout outs; meet the cast and watch a rehearsal; guest appearance in a heels at home episode; cast kisses and much more...

 

Love Letters is a merging of classical contemporary choreographic styles infused with elements of vaudville, vintage busrlesque teases and musical theatre.

"More and more dancers starting to appear on stage following Pastel's lead [created] the ultimate erotic experience." Julia Marie, Diva Dish Blog

 

LOVE LETTERS CABARET's LIFELINE Since Feb 2012...

FEB *Love Letters Cabaret debues "The Lady"  to 3 sold out shows. *PM TV covers "The Lady" & creates a popular online spot

June *Love Letters presents new work at The Choreographer's Ball

July *Company is featured in Night of Essence

March - Present* Love Letters performs at private functions & events  

The Bacchanal is the cabaret's second full length production but hopefully will be the last non-paying show we create. We would love to present dinner theatres shows and eventually tour our work through the country and internationally. 

By donating now your investment will be the stepping stone to providing paying work to Torontonial performers with something beautiful to present. Help kick start "The Bacchanal" and be part of the first steps to achieving our goals!  

No Cash? Other Ways You Can Help

Donate time instead of $$. We are producing a big show and are calling on volunteers to contact us at  info@pastelsupernova.com and find out how to help out. We may need you for an hour, a day or night maybe even a week.

Tell your friends and share our campaign! We all know someone who loves to donate to sexy causes. Have a twitter account or FaceBook? SHARE, TWEET, POST the love! Follow our blog http://loveletters.pastelsupernova.com and recieve sneek peeks of the phots shoots and cute moments throughout the creation of the show.

Check out the share tools that indie gogo has to make it easier. 

OCT. 13th, We are hosting an auction at LULA LOUNGE 1585 Dundas St West. 7pm. FREE SALSA lesson, SNEAK PEEK of the show and a very sexy AUCTION!  

Thank you so much for your time and money, we hope to see you at the SHOW OCT 31st and NOV 1st!

story:
The coiling, contorted beauty of the human body held pride of place.. at the ROOFTOP DANCE program produced by Steven Moses and Jaimi Patterson... their simplicity and innocence of sentiment, coupled with the virtuosity of the dancing and the beauty of the danc(ing), make you a little happier about being human.

Tom Strini - Third Coast Digest, July 2012

 

round two.

six dances

                          six choreographers

bodies        folding,

     unfolding,      collapsing,     creasing, colliding and separating

                                                                     reveal

narrative          hints                              charged landscapes   

permeated with intimate velocity of the

                                                        human kind  

 

What We Need

..is the necessary resources to make sure that the second round of ROOFTOP DANCE MKE happens.  Equally important is our commitment to supporting all of the creative voices involved with the creation and performance of this project.  

Details:

creative stipend | $400 per dance = $2400

technical support | $800

equipment rental | $500

space rental | TBD

advertisement/misc. | $500

videographer | $400

As you can see, our costs far exceed what we're hoping to raise - we just need a little boost!

 

The Basics

Where:  Kenilworth Square East 620 (KSE)

When:  June 27 - 8pm, June 28-29 - 8pm/10pm

 

 For more information, visit us @ ROOFTOP DANCE MKE
story_txt:
The coiling, contorted beauty of the human body held pride of place.. at the ROOFTOP DANCE program produced by Steven Moses and Jaimi Patterson... their simplicity and innocence of sentiment, coupled with the virtuosity of the dancing and the beauty of the danc(ing), make you a little happier about being human.
Tom Strini - Third Coast Digest, July 2012
 
round two.
six dances
                          six choreographers
bodies        folding, 
     unfolding,      collapsing,     creasing, colliding and separating

narrative          hints                              charged landscapes   
permeated with intimate velocity of the

story:
Our Story

Roaring Lion Theatre is raising money to put on a dream project, Goblin Market, at the 2011 Vancouver Fringe Festival.  We are a group of 3 women who have been talking about putting this show on for about 5 years.  We have pitched it to a few theatre companies in town, but none, due to funding challenges were willing to take a risk on the project. 

This year we decided to take a leap and not only produce the show ourselves, but to do it in a beautiful outdoor venue as part of the Vancouver Fringe Festival.  This is an exciting but risky venture financially( and possibly environmentally due to the Vancouver weather)!


About Goblin Market

"We must not look at goblin men,
We must not buy their fruits:
Who knows upon what soil they fed
Their hungry thirsty roots?"

Set in a magical outdoor venue this sensual voyage through the labyrinths of the Laura and Lizzie's imaginations will weave an enchanting spell that will linger long in your memory. Goblin Market is a beautiful, intimate musical about the sexually charged fantasies of  two proper Victorian sisters. 

Laura and LIzzie are both now grown women and mothers, and they return to their childhood nursery to relive the haunting memories of their youth. Magically, they are transported back to their girlhood, as their nursery becomes a woodland glen peopled by bizarre goblins who entice them with luscious fruits and promises of unimagined ecstasies.  


Who we are:

Barbara Tomasic directs a stellar cast of Vancouver actors; Lauren Bowler, currently starring in Anything Goes at Theatre Under the Stars plays Lizzie and Tracey Power, the writer and star of the Fringe hit Living Shadows: A Story of Mary Pickford, plays the younger Laura.  They are joined by the amazing musical talent of Steve Charles (Brief Encounter, Back To You, The Fugitives) who will bring the intricate music to life.


Impact

Goblin Market will be have its BC Premiere at the Vancouver Fringe Festival with Roaring Lion Theatre.  The impact of this campaign is that it will allow a piece of theatre to happen that would not be produced in Vancouver under different circumstances.  In this time of a lack of artistic funding, theatre companies are not taking risks on new unknown pieces.   If Goblin Market is successful there is an excellent chance that it will be picked up by a larger theatre company and produced again. 


This will provide work for at least 5 artists directly and potential for more in the future!


What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $2500 in total to get this show up on its feet.  Part of the reason this amount is so low is that we are not paying our artists.  Roaring Lion Theatre is a collective, which means that the artists agree to do the show for free and then split the box office equally after ticket sales. 

Your money would pay for:
- costumes
- props
- lighting
- instrument rental
- Theatrical Rights for the show (this means the people who wrote the show are paid for this wonderful piece of art they have written).  The show costs $100 per night to produce. 

Our potential ticket sales per night are $500 if we sell out every night. 

A successful show in Vancouver plans for 30% attendance per night.  That means 15 people per night. 
That is only $150 per night. 

Our costs per night:
 - $50 for the venue
 - $10 for lighting
 - $10 for props
 - $15 for costumes
 - $10 for instrument rental
 - $100 for Theatrical rights

Total costs per show: $195.  So we are running a $45 per night deficit before we even start to think about paying artists. 

I am sure you see our challenge.  We plan to hold our own fundraiser, a summer party, but every little bit helps!

You can donate on this page with your credit card, or if you want to use another method, please contact us at roaringliontheatre@yahoo.com.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to donate (and even if you are) the  best way to help is to buy tickets to the show for you and all your friends.

Tickets go on Sale in August 2011 - for more info go to http://www.vancouverfringe.com/ticket-information/

Share our project on Facebook, Twitter, Telephone, and Word of Mouth!

Thank you so much!
Barb, Lauren, Steve and Tracey.

story:
My name is Joe Beck. I wrote A Homecoming after meeting an elderly couple who had spent their lives working hard and raising children of their own. Instead of being blessed with good health and a peaceful retirement, they were assaulted with a life changing diagnosis-Alzheimer's. James and Lee, both in their mid to late seventies, refused to be defeated however, and James took care of his wife until the end. This is a tender, long goodbye; a love story so genuine it can be called part Virginia Wolf, Romeo and Juliet, The Brady Bunch and The Adams Family.

Alzheimer's is a national issue and this story, I'm proud to say, puts a human face on it. It is educational, inspirational for those who care for loved ones afflicted with the disease and the caretakers themslves. It's human dignity, strength and an opportunity for hope-to remind sufferers, caregivers and those people they love that they are not alone. 

 

The funds raised will go to paying for rehearsal space, administrative fees, the actors and sets, props, costumes, insurance and transporatation.

The Impact

Writing, directing and performaing a play about Alzheimer's and how it affects families and loved ones and friends we hope will have a strong inpact on audiences in a way that is respectful, tender and educational. The show is not all maudlin, but sardonic and sometimes comical and sad and everything in between. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can gve a little or a lot, every little bit is appreciated. In the resource section of our website at www. AHomecoming.com you can find a resource list for many Alzheimers support groups, medical resources and charities where you can give of your time and support those in need.

I’m handling all the publicity myself. Everyone who is able to contribute by May 10 will see their name in print in the back of the book in a special Thank You section. The book will be released in June.

I currently have ads in Screem, Shock Cinema, VideoScope, Fangoria, and Rue Morgue. I’m seeking assistance with covering the costs of those ads and traveling up the west coast to Seattle then to Chicago. Thanks to any and all that are able to assist me in this latest venture! Much appreciated, of course!

story:
We are Post5 Theatre!

And we say, "when life gives you lemons... tell a compelling story with them!" Oh, and make it Free of charge, while you're at it!


Post5 Theatre's Mission Statement:

Through classical and contemporary works alike, we seek to harness and showcase the immeasurable vision and commitment of both emerging and established theatre artists-- to create affordable, accessible, and engaging theatre events that ultimately hold the mirror up to, and celebrate, our own life experiences.  

This past summer, Post5's inaugural production of Romeo & Juliet brought FREE outdoor Shakespeare to 1,400 patrons -- an accomplishment we are very proud of! But the work is not over, and neither is our insatiable desire to bring quality storytelling to our community. The Post5 Theatre company and our team of dedicated artists strive to bring live theatre to Portland that is:
  • Exquisitely Enthusiastic 
  • Honest
  • Stirring 
  • and 100% Free-of-Charge!  


Bringing the "Louder, Faster, Funnier" to the life of PDX!


But it's not just about that, folks...

The Post5 Theatre Co. is based out of the Milepost 5 Community for Creatives, located in NE Portland.

Our base of operations is located right off of 82nd Ave., one of the longest thoroughfares in the city, in an area of Portland currently in a state of renovation. We strive to be an ongoing part of that positive change within our community. 

After witnessing the overwhelmingly successful turnout for Romeo & Juliet, it is clear to us more than ever that our community cries out for more performance art and live storytelling, that is accessible to all income levels and tax brackets. 

They say laughter is the best medicine... and with this ruckus, feel-good, and fast-paced comedy, we want to provide all this, with bells on!

 

What We Need & What You Get

Last summer, we shared with community members of all ages a true classic, and perhaps the greatest love story ever written... This winter, we would like to offer up one of the silliest works of the modern era, with The Complete Works of William Shakespeare (Abridged)! Here are the reasons we think this show will be a warm offering to NE Portland's chilly winter:

  • It's laugh-out-loud funny!
  • It's fun for the whole family!
  • It takes place in an on-site restaurant, so food & libations are close at-hand!
  • It doesn't cost an arm & a leg to enjoy!

... But it does cost us some to produce free theatre, and that's where you come in!
This show is chocked full of quick costume changes and prop pieces, so lots of clothing articles and dozens of hilarious props integral to the storytelling are required. Not to mention that we have brought on several driven and imaginative artists to be a part of this endeavor, and help us to build a professional quality theatrical experience. We would very much like to monetarily reimburse these talented theatre artists at the end of the show's run. Because after all... heartfelt gratitude is priceless, but money helps keep the electricity on.  


Other Ways You Can Rock Our World...

SHARE THIS LINK!!!

Tell your friends about it!

'Like' Post5 Theatre Co. on Facebook!

Follow us on Twitter!  

Come see the show... and bring everyone you know!

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it’s important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it’s going. Be transparent and specific—people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don’t reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
Bringing quality theatre to the people of Kansas City is our passion.  But we need your help to make it a reality! Please help Egads! Theatre Company bring Hedwig and the Angry Inch to Kansas City as a fundraiser for our upcoming season!

Contributions for the purpose of supporting Egads Theatre Company and payable to Egads Theatre Company are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law!

Who Are We?

Voted "2011 Best Local Theatre Company in Kansas City" by The Pitch readers.

EGADS! THEATRE COMPANY fosters emerging theatre professionals, produces theatre entertainment that is relevant and/or outlandish, and provides Kansas City audiences with quality productions as a stimulating outlet. The people involved have been in the Kansas City theatre scene for years, but Egads! formed in 2009, and since then we have been dedicated to engaging professional theatre artists in creative collaboration by producing  affordable and high quality entertainment to delight and inspire both new audiences and seasoned theatre patrons.


What Are We Doing Here?

In a compelling effort to relieve the cost of producing our unique brand of theatre, Egads! Theatre Company is going to hold the most unique fundraiser this side of Berlin. In February, we will be bringing back one of our most loved productions - Hedwig and The Angy Inch, the inspiring Off Broadway hit. The 4 performances of Hedwig will raise funds to cover our yearly production costs.


The Pitch, The Match, The Promise

This fundraiser is vital to our survival, but we need your help to make it happen. Please consider donating to our cause to help us offset the cost of producing our fundraiser. Producing theatre is very rewarding, but it is also very costly.


We've set the goal for this phase of our campaign at $2,000. A generous donor has stepped forward with a promise to match your contributions dollar for dollar IF that goal is met or exceeded. That means that if you pledge $10, we get $20, if you pledge $50, we get $100, and onward and upward - but ONLY if our goal is reached! Since we are a 501(c)3 not-for-profit organization, all gifts are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by the law.


What We Want To Give You

In exchange for your generous contribution, you will receive the fun, one-of-a-kind perks listed in the sidebar,  as well as our promise to bring this work to the stage with all the vitality it deserves. We will employ professional artists and use all the resources at our disposal to bring this story and this music to the widest possible audience. Look below for a quick breakdown of how the money will be spent...


Hedwig says: "Tear...Down" the Budget

Production Specific Costs - $2700
2 actors, 5 musicians, Stage Manager, Spot Ops, air fare, Licensing and Royalty Fees. (Please note - all individuals involved in this project have generously agreed to accepting a reduced payment as a donation in support of the fund-raising efforts for Egads Theatre Company)


Theatre Rental - $850
Performance Space


Publicity - $600
Poster/Flyer/Postcard printing, Advertising


Other - $600
Printing, Box Office Fees, Incidentals


What Else You Can Do

Share, share, share! Sharing your enthusiasm for this project via email, Facebook, Twitter, phone, and good ol' word of mouth is a gift to us that keeps on giving. Please help us go viral with this project by getting the word out on the streets!


Every gift is deeply appreciated. Every gift makes a difference. Every gift is tax-deductible. Thank you for helping us realize our dream.




What Perks Have Been Taken?

Some of the perks that we're offering our generous donors involve seeing the show on certain nights. Below, you'll find a list of perks that are still available...

Sugar Daddy Award - Thursday February 23rd @ 8pm
Sugar Daddy Award - Friday February 24th @ 8pm TAKEN!
Sugar Daddy Award - Friday February 24th @ 11pm 
Sugar Daddy Award - Saturday February 25th @ 7pm 

Punk Rock Star of Stage&Screen - Thursday February 23rd @ 8pm
Punk Rock Star of Stage&Screen - Friday February 24th @ 8pm
Punk Rock Star of Stage&Screen - Friday February 24th @ 11pm
Punk Rock Star of Stage&Screen - Saturday February 25th @ 7pm TAKEN!

Origins of Love - Thursday February 23rd @ 8pm
Origins of Love - Friday February 24th @ 8pm
Origins of Love - Friday February 24th @ 11pm 
Origins of Love - Saturday February 25th @ 7pm

That means that if you pledge $10, we get $20, if you pledge $50, we get $100, and onward and upward - but ONLY if our goal is reached! Since we are a 501(c)3 not-for-profit organization, all gifts are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by the law.

What We Want To Give You
In exchange for your generous contribution, you will receive the fun, one-of-a-kind perks listed in the sidebar,  as well as our promise to bring this work to the stage with all the vitality it deserves. We will employ professional artists and use all the resources at our disposal to bring this story and this music to the widest possible audience. Look below for a quick breakdown of how the money will be spent...

Hedwig says: "Tear...Down" the Budget
Production Specific Costs - $27002 actors, 5 musicians, Stage Manager, Spot Ops, air fare, Licensing and Royalty Fees. (Please note - all individuals involved in this project have generously agreed to accepting a reduced payment as a donation in support of the fund-raising efforts for Egads Theatre Company)
Theatre Rental - $850Performance Space
Publicity - $600Poster/Flyer/Postcard printing, Advertising
Other - $600Printing, Box Office Fees, Incidentals


What Else You Can Do
Share, share, share! Sharing your enthusiasm for this project via email, Facebook, Twitter, phone, and good ol' word of mouth is a gift to us that keeps on giving. Please help us go viral with this project by getting the word out on the streets!

Every gift is deeply appreciated. Every gift makes a difference. Every gift is tax-deductible. Thank you for helping us realize our dream.



What Perks Have Been Taken?
Some of the perks that we're offering our generous donors involve seeing the show on certain nights. Below, you'll find a list of perks that are still available...

Sugar Daddy Award - Thursday February 23rd @ 8pm

Sugar Daddy Award - Friday February 24th @ 8pm TAKEN!

Sugar Daddy Award - Friday February 24th @ 11pm 

Sugar Daddy Award - Saturday February 25th @ 7pm 


Punk Rock Star of Stage&Screen - Thursday February 23rd @ 8pm
Punk Rock Star of Stage&Screen - Friday February 24th @ 8pm

Punk Rock Star of Stage&Screen - Friday February 24th @ 11pm


Punk Rock Star of Stage&Screen - Saturday February 25th @ 7pm TAKEN!


Origins of Love - Thursday February 23rd @ 8pm
Origins of Love - Friday February 24th @ 8pm

Origins of Love - Friday February 24th @ 11pm 

Origins of Love - Saturday February 25th @ 7pm

story:
We want to help save the Pokemon. Through song and dance. And we want you to be a part of that journey. 

The Pokemusical delves into the wild world of Pokemon with abandon. The brainchild of two Baldwin Wallace University students, the Pokemon adventure of a lifetime is now being brought to life upon the stage! Join Ash, Misty, Brock, Pikachu, and the rest of the crew from the original games and anime, and prepare to be hit with a wave of nostalgia! With an original book and lyrics by Alex Syiek, plus brand new music by Andrew L. Cooper, the Pokemusical is gearing up to be released from the Pokeball, this time with musical numbers in tow.

Save a Pokemon. Your support can ensure that little Pikachus like this one here find a loving home. 

It is remarkable the number of pocket monsters that face a dangerous quality of life in their current homes.

The Pokemusical sets out to right these wrongs, but it is a journey that we cannot do alone. 

Please help us to ensure that these creatures:

  • Have a roof over their heads - rehearsal spaces and theatres are some of pocket monsters favorite places to curl up and rest.
  • Are properly clothed - many of the creatures we've found have been without clothes for years now. Please help us ensure that they can be adequately costumed before they go onstage. 
  • Receive clean and safe drinking water -  Many have only had access to the pixellated version for the entirety of their short Poke-lives. Even a small donation will ensure that the Poke-players have water to drink.
  • Have the ability to live a better life - your donation could supply these lovely creatures with a prop or two, a lighting designer, and a score of other things they would never have the opportunity to otherwise access.

Remember, it takes a village to raise a Pokemon. We cannot do this without you. 

What Does Your Donation Get You?

We believe in reciprocity here at The Pokemusical. If you can find it in your heart to make a donation to this cause today, you will receive one of following gifts.

 

For a $10 donation, you will receive the Boulder Badge and a signed picture of the entire LA cast in complete Pokegarb, holding a sign thanking YOU. You will also receive a program from the production, complete with an insert with details about the Pokemon that you helped to save.

For a donation of $25, you will receive the Boulder Badge, The Cascade Badge, and everything above including a video from the LA cast in complete Pokegarb saying how completely awesome you are, perhaps in a song!

For a generous donation of $50, you will receive everything from the Boulder and Cascade Badges along with a copy of the official demo album of The Pokemusical recorded by the original Ohio workshop cast. You can sing along with the creatures in their native homes!

Somewhere over the rainbow, there was you, generous donor. Your $75 donation will ensure that you receive everything from the Boulder, Cascade, and Thunder Badges along with a copy of the video recording of the original production of The Pokemusical.

So aptly named. You will be forever immortalized for your generosity of a $125 donation with a Producer credit in the program. Not only do you join the ranks of Hollywood producers, you also receive everything from the Boulder, Cascade, Thunder, Rainbow, and Soul Badges.  

For your overwhelmingly gracious donation of $200, you will receive everything from the Boulder, Cascade, Thunder, and Rainbow Badges. In addition, the writers of the Pokemusical, Alex Syiek and Andrew Leslie Cooper, will pen a new song involving YOU and the world of Pokemon.

Brave of soul and generous of heart, you will receive everything from the Boulder, Cascade, Thunder, Rainbow, Soul, and Marsh Badges. You will also get to choose what musical you would like to see the Poketeam do next. You will receive a 10 minute version of the musical performed entirely by Pikachu.

If we receive full funding before the expiration, you will have unlocked the Earth Badge. This much generosity only begets more gifts. But what are they? Play on to see!
