story:
ELEANOR RIGBY: THE UNTOLD STORY

Before Ellen, there was Eleanor Rigby.

Eleanor Rigby: The Untold Story is the story of a young woman who in the early 1940’s begins a struggle between her faith and her own demons as she comes to terms with her sexuality.

A feast for the senses, Eleanor Rigby: The Untold Story combines elements of live music, dance, and storytelling, as it weaves together musical styles from “Annie” to Ani (DiFranco).

Find us on Facebook @ Eleanor Rigby Untold Story

ABOUT THE CAST

Mathieu Cadart – Director / Choreographer/ Marketing

Mathieu is an Aussie expat director who finds himself drawn to musical theatre in Vancouver B.C. With his honors degree in Theatre & Drama, and over 20 years performing experience, Mathieu loves exploring character work with movement, styles and technique.

His last production in Sydney won awards at the 2011 Sydney Fringe Awards and his directing style was described as follows:  “He has a real love of comedy and humor, with a sophisticated edge!”.

Full of passion and enthusiasm, Mathieu was quickly drawn to Eleanor Rigby: The Untold Story and is excited to direct and choreograph this show. 

Some of Mathieu’s most praised productions include:

Landing (SYDNEY / MELBOURNE FRINGE 2010) Director / Creator

Whose Memory (St. Martins Youth Arts) 2009 / Director

SquareROOT (Melbourne Fringe Festival) 2007 / Director

Laedy Rae – Co-Creator / Eleanor Rigby (Singer) / Costumes / Marketing

Rachael Clark was born in Vancouver B.C. and traveled North America throughout her teenage years. She was nominated for an ECMA and toured for two years as the opening act for music sensation “JEWEL”. Since moving back to Vancouver, Laedy Rae has performed in numerous cabarets and comedy shows and began her creative collaboration with Ty Lowe.  Having started her 26-year entertainment career in theater, she is delighted to return to the stage as the voice of Eleanor Rigby.

An accomplished performer and versatile singer, Laedy Rae’s vocal stylings have been called mesmerizing and soul lifting with an impact that is impossible to ignore.  

Some of Laedy Rae’s most favorite past productions include:

International Pop Overthrow Festival Showcase, The Joint, Los Angeles, CA

CB’s 313 Gallery, New York, NY, Headliner

Central Park Summer Stage, New York, NY (Opening for Jewel)

Canadian Music Week Showcase, B-Side Club, Toronto ON

Ty Lowe – Co Creator / Hamish (Singer) / Musical Director/ Technical Director / Production Manager

Having been a musician for as long as she can remember, Ty Lowe performed her first public vocal solo at the ripe old age of 3.  She holds a Bachelor of Music degree in Trumpet Performance and a Masters of Music degree in Jazz Studies.  During her first year of undergrad, Ty got involved with musical theatre and she will tell you that she is always happiest when she is conducting a show.  To date she has been musical director for over 40 shows in both Canada and the US – some of her most favorite were Sweeny Todd, Jesus Christ Superstar, A Chorus Line, Evita, and The Secret Garden.  When asked, “What was the best time of your life?” Ty refers to her time at Indiana University where she had the distinct honour to work with such jazz legends as Pearl Bailey, J J Johnson, Louis Bellson, Wynton Marsalis and Dizzy Gillespie.

Stephanie Pintar – Eleanor Rigby (Dancer)

AKA Miss Starry, is a versatile dance artist.  She started her early training in North Western Ontario but later moved to Vancouver to complete 4 years of dance school at Main Dance.  There she had the opportunity to perform works created by Crystal Pite, David Pressault and Donna Redlick.  Since then Stephanie has performed a variety of styles at events including: contemporary at the Vancouver International Dance Festival; eurythmy with the Enchant Dancers at the Sacred Dance Festival and burlesque at Madame JoJo’s in London UK.  Stephanie is also a hula-hoop aficionado.

Sarah Hillman-Stolz – Myfanwy Jones / Sister Theresa / Adoptive Mother

Sarah’s innovative, visually delightful and emotionally resonant performance work is informed by her training in physical theatre, Viewpoints and Suzuki method with New York’s SITI Company.

Past performance and directing credits include:

Guest of Miss Fribby Burlesque Cabaret (Rapscallion album launch & Screaming Sailor’s Ball 2012), I love that you forgot… (Melbourne Fringe 2010), A Tivoli Lovelie (Adelaide Fringe 2010), 

Cody Cox – Hamish (Dancer) / Father Donnelly / Adoptive Father

Cody is a contemporary dancer who moved from Vancouver Island to the mainland to pursue his career in dance. He is currently attending Simon Fraser University as a dance major and is going into his fourth and final year of the program.

 

Why this show is important to Vancouver Pride 2013?

Eleanor Rigby: The Untold Story deals with current issues using the backdrop of the 1940-60’s worldview. A coming of age and self-discovery story, Eleanor Rigby: The Untold Story explores how coming to terms with oneself is a unique journey that crosses the boundaries of sexuality, faith, and morality. In the show, we see how mixed feelings and messages result in an emotional rollercoaster for our heroine and how ultimately the only opinion that matters is your own.

This story takes place in a period where no one talked about sexuality or how to resolve certain feelings and conflicts. Furthermore, it demonstrates that historically not many people were brave enough to openly be in a homosexual relationship because of social stigmas.

Breaking barriers between communities through music, dance, and storytelling, Eleanor Rigby: The Untold Story teaches that being authentic to one’s self, no matter what, is the most important thing in life. 

Rae of Life Productions along with Vancouver Pride Society is committed to serving the Vancouver community a brand new experience during pride – a musical!  What could be more appropriate? 

We are booked for 5 shows over the course of 4 days at the Orpheum Annex Theatre - a beautiful 150 seat theatre located in the heart of Vancouver and sister theatre to the world renowned Orpheum. There’s not a bad seat in the house! This is a fantastic venue which boasts brilliant acoustics, state of the art lighting and the most helpful and wonderful staff in town!

It is the hope of the Rigby Team that by taking the show to this next level of development that we will educate and encourage people to embrace their uniqueness, no matter what it is, and that the show will become a vehicle to spread this message to a larger worldwide audience.

Showtimes @ The Orpheum Annex - 823 Seymour Street, 2nd floor. Vancouver B.C

July 31 (7:00 pm)
August 1st (7:00 pm)
August 2nd (7:00 pm)
August 3rd (2pm & 7:00 pm)

Tickets available @ http://www.vancouverpride.ca/Pride2013/official-events

What are your donations are paying for?

Rehearsal Space (Dancers) – 26 rehearsal days

Rehearsal Space (Band / Singers) – 26 rehearsal days

Musical Fees and Charges (SOCAN)

Publicity Materials (Posters & Business Cards for the show)

Musical Gear (Rental)

Costumes (Renting, building, and finding current pieces we can adapt)

Props (things the actors use during the play to set the stage)

Special Guest Choreographers

Please donate, and come join Laedy Rae and The Ty Lowe Trio in this unique musical theatre experience as they take you on a whimsical journey through Eleanor’s life.

If you are unable to donate, please share this link with people you know who love theater as much as we do.

About Vancouver Pride Society

The Vancouver Pride Society (VPS) brings together members of the Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, Two-Spirited and Queer community, their friends, allies and supporters in celebration!

We represent the unique culture and spirit of our community by producing quality, inclusive events such as the Pride Parade and Festival.

 

Visit them at : http://www.vancouverpride.ca/

 

To visit The Orpheum Annex website Please go to:

http://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/rent-the-orpheum-annex.aspx

story:
Plus bas, le texte en français.

In Brief

After two years of training and theatre creation together at the Jacques Lecoq Theatre School in Paris, Jo Even Bjørke, Jon Levin, Oda Kirkebø Nyfløtt and Vincent Vernerie have come together to create THE KRUMPLE THEATRE COMPANY.  We are at this very moment rehearsing and developing our first show “Go to Sleep, Goddamnit!” in Norway, which we will premiere at the Camden Fringe Festival in London this August.  

 

While we're lucky enough to have free theatre space in Norway to rehearse, we still need to pay for theatre rental in London, transportation, festival fees, marketing, props, costumes, etc to make this show a reality.  We've been putting everything we've got into this show, but we need your help to get us there.

 

With your help we will be able to finish creating this show, and bring it to London for our premiere.  Beyond this summer, having this show under our belt will help us apply for grants and residencies next year.  It's a crucial moment for us and we hope you'll consider supporting us as we take this leap.  

What We Need & What You Get

We’re asking for 2000 euros to help us pay for the costs of the show. This money will be going towards rental of the Camden People’s Theatre in London, the Camden Fringe Festival fees, transportation, the creation of our masks, sets, props, costumes and rehearsal space in London.  This amount won’t pay for all the show’s expenses, but with ticket sales we’re hoping to break even.  

We’ve got perks for every level, giving away personalized postcard creations, photo prints, a knitting/sewing surprise, mini masks and a gourmet dinner.

If we don’t reach our goal, we will still get the funds that we’ve raised (though we’ll get less of them, because Indiegogo will take a higher percentage).

The Impact

This show is a huge step for our company.  It’s our first full length production and we’re doing it all ourselves; writing, directing, designing, producing and marketing. This first step will allow us to apply for funding from Norway and France, and will pave the path to presenting our show in Edinburgh next summer.  

Although we’re a new theatre company, our members have a lot of experience creating and producing theatre. Jon, Oda and Vincent have all had experience establishing and leading theatre companies. Jon has worked on the producing and directing side of Sinking Ship Productions in New York for four years.  We’re confident that our communal experiences have given us the skills we need to create and produce this project.  For more information on each of us, please look at the “About us” section of our website.  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren’t able to donate financially, please consider liking our company page on Facebook and sharing our campaign with your friends using the Indiegogo like buttons.

Come to our show!  There’s no show without an audience.  We’ll be playing in London from August 17-19th.  Click here for tickets.  We hope to see you there!

 

more info at thekrumple.com

Please note:  The donation will appear as Oda Kirkebø Nyfløtt and not The Krumple, as we are in the process of formalising our company. 

 

 

En bref,

 

Après deux ans de formation à l'école Jacques Lecoq, Jo Even Bjørke, Jon Levin, Oda K. Nyflott et Vincent Vernerie ont créé ensemble le Krumple Theatre Company.

Nous sommes actuellement en pleine répétition de notre premier spectacle "Go to Sleep, Goddamnit" en Norvège, dont la première aura lieu en août, à Londres, pendant le Camden Fringe Festival.

 

Nous avons la chance d'avoir un espace gratuit en Norvège pour répéter. Cependant, il nous reste à payer la location du théâtre à Londres, les frais de transport, les frais du festival, la communication, les accessoires, les costumes, etc, pour que ce spectacle devienne réalité. Nous y avons mis tout notre cœur, mais nous avons besoin de votre aide pour nous permettre d'aller jusqu'au bout.

Avec votre soutien, nous pourrons finir la création du spectacle et l'emmener jusqu'à Londres pour notre première.

 

Après cet été, le fait d'avoir joué ce spectacle à Londres va nous permettre de demander plus facilement des subventions et des résidences pour l'année prochaine. C'est un moment crucial pour nous, ce serait un grand pas en avant si pouviez nous supporter.

 

Ce qu'il nous faut, ce que vous obtenez

 

Ici, les details:

 

- Nous demandons 2000 euros pour nous aider à couvrir les frais du spectacle. Cela comprend la location du Camden People's Theatre à Londres, les frais du Camden Fringe Festival, les frais de transport, la création de nos masques, notre scénographie, accessoires, costumes et espace de répétition a Londres. Ce montant ne couvrira pas toutes les dépenses du spectacle mais avec la vente des tickets, nous espérons bien rentrer dans nos frais.

 

- Nous avons des "petits cadeaux" pour chaque niveau, des cartes postales personnalisées que nous créons nous-mêmes, des photos et affiches de notre spectacle, des surprises "cousues à la main", des mini-masques et un dîner gourmet.

 

- Si nous ne parvenons pas à atteindre ces 2000 euros, nous pourrons quand même recevoir la somme atteinte au bout des 30 jours. Néanmoins, celle-ci sera diminuée puisqu'en pareil cas Indiegogo prélèvera un pourcentage plus élevé.

 

L'impact

 

Ce spectacle est un grand pas pour la compagnie. C'est notre première production et nous faisons tout nous-mêmes; l'écriture, la mise en scène, la régie, la production et la communication. Ce premier pas va nous permettre de demander des subventions en France et en Norvège, nous pourrons ainsi tracer notre sentier vers Edimbourg pour y présenter notre spectacle l'été prochain.

 

Même si nous sommes une jeune compagnie, chacun d'entre nous a de l'expérience dans la création et la production d'un spectacle. Jon, Oda et Vincent ont créé et dirigé des compagnies de théâtre. Pendant quatre ans Jon a travaillé sur la production et la direction de Sinking Ship Productions à New York. Nous avons confiance dans ce projet et nous espérons que nos expériences communes nous donnent les compétences dont nous avons besoin pour le réaliser. Pour plus d'informations sur chacun d'entre nous, vous pouvez jeter un œil sur la section "about us" de notre site internet.

 

D'autres manières de nous aider.

 

- Si vous ne pouvez pas nous supporter financièrement, vous pouvez "Liker" la page Facebook de notre compagnie et partager notre campagne Indiegogo avec vos amis.

 

- Venez voir notre spectacle ! Il n'y a pas de spectacle sans spectateur. Nous allons jouer à Londres le 17, 18 et 19 août. Cliquez ici pour les tickets. Nous espérons vous voir là-bas!

 

Attention: Le virement bancaire aparaîtera au nom de Oda Kirkebø Nyfløtt et non au nom du Krumple, puisque nous sommes en train de officialiser notre compagnie.

 

5 euros: un grand merci, et votre nom apparaîtra sur la liste des remerciements de notre site internet.

 

25 euros: du fond du cœur merci, votre nom sur la liste des remerciements et une carte postale personnalisée et illustrée par Vincent Vernerie.

 

50 euros: un poster de notre spectacle et un immense merci.

 

100 euros: une surprise cousue/tricotée par Oda. "Je suis très mauvaise pour coudre ou tricoter, mais je peux essayer, non? " - Oda.

 

250 euros: 2 tickets pour notre spectacle, votre nom sur la liste des remerciements et un mini-masque du Krumple.


500 euros: 2 tickets pour notre spectacle, votre nom sur la liste des remerciements et un dîner préparé par notre talentueux chef, Jo Even Bjørke.
story_txt:
Plus bas, le texte en français.
In Brief
After two years of training and theatre creation together at the Jacques Lecoq Theatre School in Paris, Jo Even Bjørke, Jon Levin, Oda Kirkebø Nyfløtt and Vincent Vernerie have come together to create THE KRUMPLE THEATRE COMPANY.  We are at this very moment rehearsing and developing our first show “Go to Sleep, Goddamnit!” in Norway, which we will premiere at the Camden Fringe Festival in London this August.  
 
While we're lucky enough to have free theatre space in Norway to rehearse, we still need to pay for theatre rental in London, transportation, festival fees, marketing, props, costumes, etc to make this show a reality.  We've been putting everything we've got into this show, but we need your help to get us there. 
 
With your help we will be able to finish creating this show, and bring it to London for our premiere.  Beyond this summer, having this show under our belt will help us apply for grants and residencies next year.  It's a crucial moment for us and we hope you'll consider supporting us as we take this leap.  

What We Need & What You Get
We’re asking for 2000 euros to help us pay for the costs of the show. This money will be going towards rental of the Camden People’s Theatre in London, the Camden Fringe Festival fees, transportation, the creation of our masks, sets, props, costumes and rehearsal space in London.  This amount won’t pay for all the show’s expenses, but with ticket sales we’re hoping to break even.  
We’ve got perks for every level, giving away personalized postcard creations, photo prints, a knitting/sewing surprise, mini masks and a gourmet dinner.If we don’t reach our goal, we will still get the funds that we’ve raised (though we’ll get less of them, because Indiegogo will take a higher percentage).
The Impact
This show is a huge step for our company.  It’s our first full length production and we’re doing it all ourselves; writing, directing, designing, producing and marketing. This first step will allow us to apply for funding from Norway and France, and will pave the path to presenting our show in Edinburgh next summer.  
Although we’re a new theatre company, our members have a lot of experience creating and producing theatre. Jon, Oda and Vincent have all had experience establishing and leading theatre companies. Jon has worked on the producing and directing side of Sinking Ship Productions in New York for four years.  We’re confident that our communal experiences have given us the skills we need to create and produce this project.  For more information on each of us, please look at the “About us” section of our website.  
Other Ways You Can Help
If you aren’t able to donate financially, please consider liking our company page on Facebook and sharing our campaign with your friends using the Indiegogo like buttons.
Come to our show!  There’s no show without an audience.  We’ll be playing in London from August 17-19th.  Click here for tickets.  We hope to see you there!
 
more info at thekrumple.com
Please note:  The donation will appear as Oda Kirkebø Nyfløtt and not The Krumple, as we are in the process of formalising our company.  
 

 
En bref, 
 
Après deux ans de formation à l'école Jacques Lecoq, Jo Even Bjørke, Jon Levin, Oda K. Nyflott et Vincent Vernerie ont créé ensemble le Krumple Theatre Company. 
Nous sommes actuellement en pleine répétition de notre premier spectacle "Go to Sleep, Goddamnit" en Norvège, dont la première aura lieu en août, à Londres, pendant le Camden Fringe Festival. 
 
Nous avons la chance d'avoir un espace gratuit en Norvège pour répéter. Cependant, il nous reste à payer la location du théâtre à Londres, les frais de transport, les frais du festival, la communication, les accessoires, les costumes, etc, pour que ce spectacle devienne réalité. Nous y avons mis tout notre cœur, mais nous avons besoin de votre aide pour nous permettre d'aller jusqu'au bout. 
Avec votre soutien, nous pourrons finir la création du spectacle et l'emmener jusqu'à Londres pour notre première.
 
 Après cet été, le fait d'avoir joué ce spectacle à Londres va nous permettre de demander plus facilement des subventions et des résidences pour l'année prochaine. C'est un moment crucial pour nous, ce serait un grand pas en avant si pouviez nous supporter. 
 
Ce qu'il nous faut, ce que vous obtenez
 
Ici, les details:
 
- Nous demandons 2000 euros pour nous aider à couvrir les frais du spectacle. Cela comprend la location du Camden People's Theatre à Londres, les frais du Camden Fringe Festival, les frais de transport, la création de nos masques, notre scénographie, accessoires, costumes et espace de répétition a Londres. Ce montant ne couvrira pas toutes les dépenses du spectacle mais avec la vente des tickets, nous espérons bien rentrer dans nos frais. 
 
- Nous avons des "petits cadeaux" pour chaque niveau, des cartes postales personnalisées que nous créons nous-mêmes, des photos et affiches de notre spectacle, des surprises "cousues à la main", des mini-masques et un dîner gourmet. 
 
- Si nous ne parvenons pas à atteindre ces 2000 euros, nous pourrons quand même recevoir la somme atteinte au bout des 30 jours. Néanmoins, celle-ci sera diminuée puisqu'en pareil cas Indiegogo prélèvera un pourcentage plus élevé.
 
L'impact 
 
Ce spectacle est un grand pas pour la compagnie. C'est notre première production et nous faisons tout nous-mêmes; l'écriture, la mise en scène, la régie, la production et la communication. Ce premier pas va nous permettre de demander des subventions en France et en Norvège, nous pourrons ainsi tracer notre sentier vers Edimbourg pour y présenter notre spectacle l'été prochain. 
 
Même si nous sommes une jeune compagnie, chacun d'entre nous a de l'expérience dans la création et la production d'un spectacle. Jon, Oda et Vincent ont créé et dirigé des compagnies de théâtre. Pendant quatre ans Jon a travaillé sur la production et la direction de Sinking Ship Productions à New York. Nous avons confiance dans ce projet et nous espérons que nos expériences communes nous donnent les compétences dont nous avons besoin pour le réaliser. Pour plus d'informations sur chacun d'entre nous, vous pouvez jeter un œil sur la section "about us" de notre site internet. 
 
D'autres manières de nous aider. 
 
- Si vous ne pouvez pas nous supporter financièrement, vous pouvez "Liker" la page Facebook de notre compagnie et partager notre campagne Indiegogo avec vos amis.
 
- Venez voir notre spectacle ! Il n'y a pas de spectacle sans spectateur. Nous allons jouer à Londres le 17, 18 et 19 août. Cliquez ici pour les tickets. Nous espérons vous voir là-bas!
 
Attention: Le virement bancaire aparaîtera au nom de Oda Kirkebø Nyfløtt et non au nom du Krumple, puisque nous sommes en train de officialiser notre compagnie.
 
5 euros: un grand merci, et votre nom apparaîtra sur la liste des remerciements de notre site internet. 
 
25 euros: du fond du cœur merci, votre nom sur la liste des remerciements et une carte postale personnalisée et illustrée par Vincent Vernerie. 
 
50 euros: un poster de notre spectacle et un immense merci.
 
100 euros: une surprise cousue/tricotée par Oda. "Je suis très mauvaise pour coudre ou tricoter, mais je peux essayer, non? " - Oda. 
 
250 euros: 2 tickets pour notre spectacle, votre nom sur la liste des remerciements et un mini-masque du Krumple.

story:
Short Summary

Dirty Stop-Out return to Soho Upstairs with their eagerly anticipated A Guide To Second Date Sex, following on from their 2012 sell-out success ,When Women Wee.

Based on real answers from interviews, A Guide to Second Date Sex, which enjoyed a completely sold out run at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe 2012, portrays the secrets and social pressures surrounding each gender’s attitudes and anxieties towards sex and dating in modern society. Male, female, single, married or divorced; here is everything you need to know... and lots of things you don't!

This time the Dirty Stop-Out duo Stef O’Driscoll and Rachel Hirons join forces with the filmic talents of Adam Kes Hipkin and Dan Patrick Hipkin of TEAfilms, whose clients include Nandos, Channel 4, MTV and the BFI, ensuring A Guide to Second Date Sex is a stylish multi-media experience. The spectacular cast of two comprise of comedian Amy Butterworth of Johnny and The Baptists and rising comedy star, Thomas O’Connell. 

Rachel Hirons writes and award winning Stef O’Driscoll directs in the rawest, most honest portrayal of modern day attitudes and anxieties surrounding gender, sex and dating.

 

What We Need & What You Get

In order to get this show up and running we have certain financial goals to meet. We are asking in particular for any contribution towards our £2000 marketing campaign target.

We truly value any financial contribution you can make. We have listed a selection of perks for you as well :)

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot contribute money at this time, you can help us by spreading the word! Feel free to share our campaign with as many people as possible, or anyone with a passion for theatre and/or this wonderful play.

story:
Onebody Works was founded in 2009 with the vision of creating an ensemble of individuals committed to nourishing the bonds among people and their environment.

 

In pursuit of our vision the Onebody Works Summer Intensive was created. During the summer of 2009 the Onebody Works ensemble incorporated the experiences of collective living, daily farm work, and an organic, local diet into a co-creative process to produce  "Late Harvest". The piece traveled on a national performance tour to venues in Louisiana, New Mexico, Alabama and California and the Burning Man Festival in Black Rock, Nevada.

 

In August of 2010 the second Summer Intensive focused specifically on deepening our commitment to local artistic and agricultural community development. Over a four-week period six actors generated “The Seed”, touring locally to several venues in Asheville, Warren-Wilson College and Black Mountain and closing at University of North Carolina School of the Arts in Winston-Salem, NC to a crowd of hundreds of students, faculty and community members.

 

During the intensive, we minimize our environmental impact by living on the land in a tent camp without electricity, cooking over fire or with propane, fetching water from the mountain spring and bathing in the pond. We work 20 hours a week toward the farm’s operations, in exchange for our campsite, rehearsal space and food produced by the land we work. We spend an additional 25 hours each week in rehearsal and artistic exploration that culminates in the creation of a new, challenging performance piece.

 

This summer we are continuing to grow and evolve by participating in the Capital Fringe Festival in Washington, D.C. Our new piece "I See You"  explores our relationship to technology and is currently in co-creation on Hickory Nut Gap Farm with an ensemble of eight artists including:

 

Kayla Carter, Carrie Davis, Drew Madland, Ben Mandelbaum, Sam Mandelbaum, Shannon Mackenzie, Nathaniel Mendez and Nathan Vargo, with help from Victoria Campbell.

 

In our effort to live and create sustainably, the bulk of our needs while on the farm-- a campsite, rehearsal space, meat from Hickory Nut Gap and vegetables from Flying Cloud-- are provided in exchange for the ensemble's work. While we are able to provide these things through our work we still need your help to launch us out into the community; your contribution will support bringing this vision of sustainability in art and life to the masses!


Here is how our budget breaks down and what your tax-deductible contribution will be used toward:

 

$700 Transportation to performances in Asheville, Washington, D.C. and Winston-Salem (1000 miles with two cars)

 

$775 Capital Fringe Participation Fee (entrance fee and performance insurance)

 

$500 Marketing (flyers, posters and newspaper ads)

 

$640  Food Staples and Supplies (rice, beans, bread, peanut butter, oats, honey, bug spray, sun screen, candles, bio-degradable soap)

 

$500 Administrative Cost (non-profit status fee, communications, outreach)

 

$250 Materials (lights, wood, rope, screws, propane, tarps)


You can meet the artists and follow our progress this summer through periodic video posts on this website, so stay tuned for more to come......

 

Also, you can help get the word out by forwarding this page to your friends, family and colleagues!

 

Thank You,

Drew Madland and Onebody Works

story:
I am a student concluding my studies as part of the three-year daytime conservatory program at The Stella Adler Studio of Acting in New York City. I am taking the initiative by producing and directing and acting in a rehearsal project of William Shakespeare's greatest tragedy King Lear.

I chose to produce Lear as the themes of control, faith, and how a crisis of the two (in others and in ourselves) are extremely topical. We as young student artists have very little control in regards to rising prices of such things as food and rent. There is little representation or connection between us and the political machine. We have faith that learning, teaching, producing art is somehow redemptive and our production needs your help to regain faith in the power of the people to come together to make something of their own. This project is what amounts to the first production of a burgeoning theatre company I've called the Jung Actors' Company ('Jung' is pronounced 'Young' by the way ;)...). I hope that our pooled resources of talent and determination to 'make' are enough to help us produce good work and for you to help contribute to a company of young idealists looking to strengthen their faith in the power of you...the power of us.

The production is using NYU & Adler actors. Rehearsals take place several times a week at the Stella Adler Studio. As of right now, we are opening up a rehearsal as a benefit. This will show the public where we're at creatively and how your funds have been applied. We hope to continue to raise interest and additional funding in order to stage the entire play on a raised-stage later in the summer. The upcoming workshop benefit will be held at Theaterlab (137 W 14th Street) Wednesday 27 June @ 7pm.

 

Here is our cast listed in order of appearance

Stage Manager - Lauren Erwin [NYU/Adler Graduate]

o Kent - Matt Laderoute [Day Conservatory @ Adler Class of '14]

o Gloucester - Rudy De La Cruz [NYU/Adler Graduate]

o Edmund - Jordan Coffey [NYU/Adler Class of '13]

o Lear - Jamie Jung [Day Conservatory @ Adler Class of '13]

o Cornwall - Edilio Flores [Day Conservatory Graduate]

o Albany - Liberty O'Dell [Day Conservatory @ Adler Class of '15]

o Goneril - Kimberley Ann Croscup [Day Conservatory @ Adler Class of '13]

o Regan - Emma Wisniewski [NYU/Adler Graduate]

o Cordelia / Fool - Jessica Smith [NYU/Adler Graduate]

o France / Knight / Gentleman / Servant / Doctor / Captain - Shannon Spangler [NYU/Adler Class of '14]

o Burgundy / Attendant / Servant / Soldier / Gentleman - Becca Beberaggi [Evening Conservatory Class of '12]

o Edgar - A.J. Ditty [NYU/Strasberg & Playwrights Graduate]

o Oswald / Servant / Herald - Lauren Erwin [NYU/Adler Graduate]

 

The $1,920 is broken down into performance and rehearsal fees which have been shopped for and kept to a minimum. To book an off-off Broadway venue on off-peak evenings costs $345 per night. Our company is rehearsing for free at Adler and will more than likely be using living rooms and parks. That said, two rehearsals at the 13th Street theatre are mandatory: one tech and one dress rehearsal. These rehearsals are billed at $45/hour and will be requiring the black box from 10am-5pm the Thursday and Friday prior to the run. Therefore...

 

Theaterlab
     Rehearsal =           $55
     Workshop =         $200
13th Street Rep Co Theater
     Rehearsal =         $630
     Performance =   $1,035

TOTAL:                   $1,920

In addition to asking for donations on this site, we will still sell tickets on Theatermania. This is simply to recoup monies.

Thank you for supporting us and for following our growth! Please follow us on Twitter (@JungActorsCo) and visit the newly created Weebly website (http://www.jungactorscompany.weebly.com) for up-to-date information regarding our progress in staging Shakespeare's greatest tragedy.

-Jamie

story:
Synthetic Unlimited is an energetic performance art organization founded in 2006 by young actors, filmmakers, musicians and writers from Grass Valley, CA.

Last year SU undertook our first official season, producing 8 plays in 8 months. We're proud to say our 2013 season was a smash hit, receiving critical acclaim from reviewers and several Elly awards and nominations.

Our plans for the future are even more ambitious but we can't do it without you.

As we launch our exciting 2014 season, your donation will allow us to continue bringing you rare and thought provoking entertainment with our signature style of fresh innovation.

We're asking for some help to fund our first show of 2014. We are pulling all the rabbits out of their hats, by pre-selling tickets, season passes, memberships, and special perks for friends who give to our Indiegogo campaign.

If we accomplish our goal, it will give us the head start we need to improve every show that follows, while keeping ticket prices affordable for our beloved patrons.

Synthetic Unlimited is committed to giving rare, classic and alternative performance art a powerful voice in the modern generation, and we want you to join us.

Learn More About Synthetic Unlimited


Nearly Nekkid on the Nile, Sacramento News and Review, September 6th, 2012 http://www.newsreview.com/sacramento/nearly-nekkid-on-the-nile/content?oid=7506004

Review: World renowned Lovers at Nevada Theater, The Union, September 7th, 2012 http://www.theunion.com/entertainment/activitiesandevents/2483335-113/shakespeare-antony-cleopatra-costumes

Synthetic Unlimited turns Community Theater on Its Head, The Union, January 6th, 2013 http://www.theunion.com/news/4227307-113/synthetic-unlimited-mccammon-company

Review: Kingdom of Earth’s short run not to be missed, The Union, May 29th, 2013 http://www.theunion.com/entertainment/6716691-113/kingdom-williams-nevada-run

Synthetic Unlimited’s ‘The Maids’ is serious theater at its best, The Union, June 27th, 2013 http://www.theunion.com/entertainment/7067421-113/maids-madame-mistress-theater

Alcoholism, dysfunction on American stage, The Union, July 18th, 2013 http://www.theunion.com/entertainment/7895304-113/servant-fae-italian-bosses

Fae, Synthetic Unlimited produce strong show, The Union, August 29th, 2013 http://www.theunion.com/entertainment/7895304-113/servant-fae-italian-bosses

Review: ‘Betrayal’ a quality production, The Union, September 25th, 2013 http://www.theunion.com/entertainment/8273446-113/pinter-production-betrayal-wife

Synthetic Unlimited presents a successfully modern Othello, The Union, October 23rd, 2013 http://www.theunion.com/entertainment/8616926-113/othello-iago-cassio-desdemona

Re-inventing Classics in Contemporary Space, The Union, September 4th, 2014 http://www.theunion.com/entertainment/9665064-113/unlimited-synthetic-theater-space



Unlimited starts with U. Join us!
story_txt:
Synthetic Unlimited is an energetic performance art organization founded in 2006 by young actors, filmmakers, musicians and writers from Grass Valley, CA.Last year SU undertook our first official season, producing 8 plays in 8 months. We're proud to say our 2013 season was a smash hit, receiving critical acclaim from reviewers and several Elly awards and nominations.Our plans for the future are even more ambitious but we can't do it without you.As we launch our exciting 2014 season, your donation will allow us to continue bringing you rare and thought provoking entertainment with our signature style of fresh innovation.We're asking for some help to fund our first show of 2014. We are pulling all the rabbits out of their hats, by pre-selling tickets, season passes, memberships, and special perks for friends who give to our Indiegogo campaign.If we accomplish our goal, it will give us the head start we need to improve every show that follows, while keeping ticket prices affordable for our beloved patrons.Synthetic Unlimited is committed to giving rare, classic and alternative performance art a powerful voice in the modern generation, and we want you to join us.Learn More About
Synthetic UnlimitedNearly Nekkid on the Nile, Sacramento News and Review, September 6th, 2012 http://www.newsreview.com/sacramento/nearly-nekkid-on-the-nile/content?oid=7506004Review: World renowned Lovers at Nevada Theater, The Union, September 7th, 2012 http://www.theunion.com/entertainment/activitiesandevents/2483335-113/shakespeare-antony-cleopatra-costumesSynthetic Unlimited turns Community Theater on Its Head, The Union, January 6th, 2013 http://www.theunion.com/news/4227307-113/synthetic-unlimited-mccammon-companyReview: Kingdom of Earth’s short run not to be missed, The Union, May 29th, 2013 http://www.theunion.com/entertainment/6716691-113/kingdom-williams-nevada-runSynthetic Unlimited’s ‘The Maids’ is serious theater at its best, The Union, June 27th, 2013 http://www.theunion.com/entertainment/7067421-113/maids-madame-mistress-theaterAlcoholism, dysfunction on American stage, The Union, July 18th, 2013 http://www.theunion.com/entertainment/7895304-113/servant-fae-italian-bossesFae, Synthetic Unlimited produce strong show, The Union, August 29th, 2013 http://www.theunion.com/entertainment/7895304-113/servant-fae-italian-bossesReview: ‘Betrayal’ a quality production, The Union, September 25th, 2013 http://www.theunion.com/entertainment/8273446-113/pinter-production-betrayal-wifeSynthetic Unlimited presents a successfully modern Othello, The Union, October 23rd, 2013 http://www.theunion.com/entertainment/8616926-113/othello-iago-cassio-desdemonaRe-inventing Classics in Contemporary Space, The Union, September 4th, 2014 http://www.theunion.com/entertainment/9665064-113/unlimited-synthetic-theater-spaceUnlimited starts with U. Join us!

story:
THE BASiCS

We are the BASiC Theatre Project and we need your help. In April 2012 a group of guys got together and unknowingly created a truly powerful presence in the Downtown NYC Theatre world with a production of Moisés Kaufman's Gross Indecency: The Three Trials of Oscar Wilde. With that, Zi Alikhan (BASiC's Artistic Director) and Anthony Jackson (BASiC's Executive Director) saw a hell of a lot of dreams come true. With your support we are going to continue realizing dreams with a fully produced, four-show season in 2013.

What we're doing is important. We are here to create theatre that is a catalyst for social change. We aren't just making theatre. We're making theatre about contemporary issues, hot-button topics, stuff happening in the world right now, and inciting our audiences to actual change. We're collaborating with other artists to incorporate visual and mixed media to enhance the audience's experience and promote other artists striving to achieve the same thing. We're not the next broadway show. We are the next campaign for important social change.

When we reach our campaign goal we will have a huge portion of the funds we need to make awesome, mind-blowing, powerful, important theatre. We will be able to rent better performance venues, have real rehearsal space, print legitimate programs and advertising materials, build beautiful sets, find amazing props, and PAY OUR ACTORS.

The quality is already there. We just need you.

WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP

Making theatre is expensive and we're poor. Making good theatre is even more expensive (and we're still poor).

  • The average cost to rent a small downtown theatre is $4000 per week.
  • Rights to perform a show for a week can top $600.
  • An accurate production budget (props, set, lighting, sound equipment, costumes) tops $1500.
  • Without a full office, even the cost of printing just scripts for a show is at least $100.
  • And all of these costs still haven't included paying our actors.

Your donation will go toward all of those expenses and you get something in return! CHECK OUT OUR AWESOME PERKS ON THE RIGHT! ---------------->

MORE ABOUT BASiC

To find out more about us and what we do, check out our website: basictheatreproject.com. We'd love to talk to you about the project, about our lives, or about your day so please feel free to CALL US at (646) 535-1133. We love to tie up dad's phone line.

Every donation made through this Indiegogo campaign is TAX-DEDUCTIBLE. We are fiscally sponsored by the lovely folks at Fractured Atlas so you will be issued a tax receipt for the deductible portion of your contribution. For more info about Fiscal Sponsorship and Fractured Atlas click here.

Our first show Gross Indecency: The Three Trials of Oscar Wilde was picked up by an annual NYC Theatre Festival called GayFestNYC and will be remounted this summer. Click for more info about GayFestNYC and BASiC at GayFest.

Our next show is The Mistakes Madeline Made by Elizabeth Meriwether and opens in January, 2013. Click for more info about all of BASiC's shows this season. 

MONEY ISN'T EVERYTHING

If you can't give monetarily, we're constantly looking for help of all shapes and sizes. Get in touch with us at info@basictheatreproject.com if you'd like to help out.

WE'RE SOCIAL

www.facebook.com/basictheatreproject

www.twitter.com/basictheatre 

www.instagram.com/basictheatreproject

story:
The ensemble of nine Royal Academy of Dramatic Arts and classical trained actors embark on a deeply personal voyage through the storms of class disparity, jealousy, religion, and love.

PERFORMANCES:

JULY 10 - 8:00pm
JULY 11 - 8:00pm
JULY 12 - 2:00pm / 8:00pm

*The Production will be performed at The Chain Theatre in Long Island City, Queens, NY


THE CAST:

BIANCA : Alexa Ciera Adderley
BRABANTIO/LODOVICO: Devin Mae Conway
DUKE / MONTANO: Jefferson Reardon
CASSIO: Jorge Morales
DESDEMONA: Caroline Aimetti
EMILIA: Coral Pena
IAGO: Jack De Sanz
OTHELLO: Chris Brown
RODERIGO: Brian Evans


CREATIVE TEAM:

DIRECTOR: Dan Hasse

PRODUCERS: Devin Mae Conway, Christopher Brown, Caroline Aimetti

ASSOCIATE PRODUCER: Shakespeare In The Square


What We Need

The Production is operating on a tight budget so we are asking for $3000 to help support and fund the following investments:

  • Rental of The Chain Theatre in Queens, NY
  • Costumes
  • Props
  • Weapons
  • Insurance
  • Supplies and other resources

story:
Our Purpose

Tri-Valley Young Performers Academy is a non-profit 501(c)(3) that offers a nurturing environment where young students grow to become more confident in themselves and in the process become well-trained actors. We began in 2007 and since then we have produced a dozen musicals from Beauty and the Beast, Jr., to You're A Good Man Charlie Brown to last summer's hit Les Miserables School Edition and this year's Upstage show-Avenue Q School Edition. Through the City of Dublin we offer a 10 week performance workshop, where we showcase original work by local playwrights and KinderDrama for 4-7 year olds. 

This summer we will be offering two musical theatre camps: our 4 week Upstage camp of Rent School Edition and our 3 week camp of Xanadu, Jr. In addition we are offering a one week KinderDrama and Comedy Improv Camp through the City of Dublin.

Our Mission:
To provide hands-on learning in all aspects of theatre production
To build self-esteem, creativity and foster talent through classes, workshops, camps, plays and musicals.
To provide a safe environment for area youth. 
To build a sense of community to help further the arts in the Tri-Valley area.
In meeting this mission, TVYPA shall be mindful of the standards of its audience and maintain fiscally sound management through ethical business standards.

How Your Money Will Be Spent

Costs of theater:
Unfortunately our tuition and ticket sales do not cover the cost of putting on a show. The average cost of a musical can be between $15,000-$20,000 and up to produce. For our Upstage program we hire a band, commission music or may need to rent puppets (Ave. Q) or other integral pieces needed for the production. We do this to bring the experience of professional theater to our young actors who want to take their experience to the next level. The results are outstanding, our students keep raising the bar and we want to reward them with the finest experience we can. We are always mindful of our costs and strive to keep down costs whenever possible.

Your donations will help to cover some of the costs of our musicals and workshops. These are some of the average costs to produce a musical:
Royalties: $2000/musical
Rehearsal Space: $2000/musical
3 Directors: $6000-$8000/musical
Costumes, Sets, Props: $500-$1000 or more/musical
Storage: $8000/year
Insurance: $2500/year

The Impact

"It isn’t always about what they do on the stage. It’s about them growing and working together. Appreciating each other and respecting each other and realizing that true talent is in the heart." ~Carolyn Greer, Theatrefolk 

  • Theater helps young people overcome the number one fear of most people-speaking in front of an audience..
  • Theater builds a community of support and acceptance of everyone.
  • Theater teaches respect, teamwork and hard work in a fun environment. It's not all fun, rehearsals can be monotonous but the end result is something that the cast can take enormous pride in.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word about our company and our upcoming shows! Share our link on social networking and with your friends and family. If you are a business and have space that you can let us use or lease for a low rate for rehearsals or storage, please get in touch with us.

Like our Facebook page and our Indiegogo page. Use the Indiegogo share tools located below the video to send our campaign to others who might help out.

We encourage you to check back regularly and visit our TriValleyYPA.org and Facebook page. Stay up to date on the latest news! Tickets for Avenue Q School Edition are on sale now online at Brown Paper Tickets, so don't miss the show! 

Thank you!

story:
Hello! Thanks for visiting the "Istropolitana project" Indiegogo!

We want your attention. And a little financial help wouldn’t be bad either. This year we are organising the 20th anniversary of Istropolitana, international festival of theatre schools.

Istropolitana Project is an international festival of theatre schools, held at the Theatre Faculty of Academy of Performing Arts in Bratislava every two years. The oldest art school in Slovakia, where all of the  Slovak important actors, directors, theatrologists or movie makers have studied. This project gives a unique opportunity to young artists, theatre scientists and cultural managers to confront their work with an audience and professional public, which may result in future cooperations and making a worldwide network of cultural activities. This festival is one of its kind in Central Europe and has served as a place for meeting young promising actors and future theatre or movie stars since 1977 - some of whom are still waiting to be discovered. It is also a place where you can meet various  authorities for the industry from all over the world. During the 19 years of existence, our festival has presented students, educators and important figures from various countries, such as Czech Republic, Poland, Germany, France, Indonesia, Switzerland, Bulgaria, Great Britain, Macedonia, Moldova, Spain, Croatia, Russia, Latvia, Romania, Iran, Italy, Columbia, India etc.

Festival offers natural environment for developing international art projects. By its character and ambitions, it is an important event within the European culture with emphasis on theatre and art education. Our project has had remarkable outreach, during its existence we have hosted artists from more than 90 countries from around the world.

Within our festival, we as students are organising theatre displays, discussions, seminars, performances, new ways of education, intellectual reflection, presentation, confrontation, site specific space for the audience, off-program, afterparties (with your name and attendance ;)), workshop Jacques Copeau - New commedia dell’arte, Matthew Rogers workshop of modern-day dancing and physical theatre, creative workshops and various art workshops.

• VŠMU Stage,
• Student jury and its interaction with generationally congenial theatre enthusiasts
• Reflektor – a festival journal
• Professional culture - workshop of management skills for cultural managers
• On-off meeting )

About organisers:
Theatre Faculty of the Academy of the performing Arts is the oldest educational institution in Slovakia, which fosters all our stars in field of theatre, music, dancing, movies and tv production (for example Gabriela Marcinkova who has appeared in a movie with Jude Law...). Did you know that Angelina Jolies grandparents originated from Slovakia? We have got talent flowing in our blood ;)

Our school was established in 1949 in Bratislava. Theatre Faculty is independently and freely developing educational, artistic and scientific activities and creates suitable conditions for artistic production. We cooperate with art schools, cultural and social institutions at home and abroad. Our alumni are notable artists working in Slovakia and throughout the world. Our faculty offers study programs in: acting, musical acting, theatre directing and dramaturgy, theatre management, puppetry, puppetry directing, dramaturgy, scenography and techology, theory and criticism of theatre, scenic and costume production.

And what does the faculty offer to us? Opportunity for imagination and independent creativity.

That is the reason we came up with this video for supporting our project.

In terms of education, Theatre Faculty of Academy of Performing Arts produces 14-15  productions of drama or alternative character every year. A large amount of our productions were awarded at festivals at home and abroad and have received our most honorable theatre award - DOSKY..

In terms of international meeting, the festival gives an opportunity for artists to discuss their activities and discover new tendencies and aims of performance art and allows presentation of these productions.

It is a great place for presenting new creative methods and it can serve as the beginning of new creative relationships and further cooperation.

Festival Instropolitana 2014, by its wide artistic and non-artistic offer, brings an opportunity of cultural realisation for both professional and amateur public.

We have been working on it since September 2013! Let's make our work count!


We need 4321,- euro for whole project. Please support us, we have special perks just for you! :)

story:
#rundown

In the running time of 300 Snapchats (50 mins), #ArtistLife is a coming-of-age comedy that asks what it means to be an artist when everyone in your social stratosphere is online and #envy is trending. I mean, if you make art but don't post it, does it actually exist?

With smartphone in hand and flower crown in your heart, join Annie and Zara as they learn what is to be an artist before they #sellout. 

Cast 
Annie - Tiffany Hoy
Zara - Rebecca Day 
Special Guest - Frida Kahlo 

We've written the script, we have the venue. Now we need your help!

 

#weneedyou

#ArtistLife came from a place of constructive dissatisfaction. A few months ago, as actors we felt we were in a place where our careers were not our own. We were losing control and going to audition after audition, waiting on others to give us a magical ‘Yes’. We have big dreams and nothing that we could sink our teeth into was popping up.

We kept hearing the best way to keep working, growing and learning is to make your own work. So we signed up for #sydneyfringe in 2017.

We've been active in indie theatre for several years now, but this is the first time for both of us taking on producing, writing, performing and directing all in the one go.

We've set ourselves a pretty big task and up till now been financing the project ourselves. We're so close to being stage ready, and with the production just a month away we'd like to offer you some cool perks as you help take #ArtistLife to the next level.

Your donations will be used to subsidise the following production costs:
- Venue Hire
- Performance Rights
- Design Elements including Set and Costumes

We're excited about making the perks, so please check 'em out!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us get the word out, tell your BFFs, tell your cat, follow our journey and join the conversation on Facebook and the 'gram: @hashtagartistlife #ArtistLife #sydneyfringe

And, come and see #ArtistLife at the Sydney Fringe 2017!  We're playing September 12-16 at the Emerging Artist Sharehouse, Living Room, at the Erskineville Town Hall.

Tuesday September 12 (Preview) - 7pm

Wednesday September 13 (Opening Night!) - 7pm

Thursday September 14 - 7pm

Friday September 15 - 7pm

Saturday September 16 (Closing) - 7pm

At the Erskineville Town Hall, 104 Erskineville Rd, Erskineville NSW 2043

Excited to see you there!

#FridaOut.

And, come and see #ArtistLife at the Sydney Fringe 2017!  We're playing September 12-16 at the Emerging Artist Sharehouse, Living Room, at the Erskineville Town Hall.
Tuesday September 12 (Preview) - 7pm
Wednesday September 13 (Opening Night!) - 7pm
Thursday September 14 - 7pm
Friday September 15 - 7pm
Saturday September 16 (Closing) - 7pm
At the Erskineville Town Hall, 104 Erskineville Rd, Erskineville NSW 2043
Excited to see you there!
#FridaOut.

story:
I am excited to let you know about the NYC Premiere of the play Tomorrow in the Battle by Kieron Barry. This is a project near and dear to my heart in which I am both acting and producing, and will be Stripped Scripts® first fully produced venture. We are starting out with a bang by putting up this play in the much-heralded Ars Nova Theater for a three week run this October!

We have been developing our production in the hopes of bringing you a unique vision of this beautifully written work.

We are reaching out to all of you in an effort to raise the $35,000 we need to successfully complete our project.

What will your support mean to Stripped Scripts production of Tomorrow in the Battle?

Your generous donation will allow us to rent a prime NYC theater for a full three week run of this show and bolster our team with the talents of Executive Producer Greg Schaffert (producer of Peter and the Star Catcher) and Emily Owens, one of the top media relations experts in the off-Broadway scene. You will also be helping us to cover the cost of essential things such as insurance, advertising, costuming, and building and lighting a set that we feel helps evoke this story’s most poignant themes.

Please don't hesitate to contact us at StrippedScrtips.com with any questions. Thank you for your support!

To learn more about our cast and crew heck out our Broadway World Press Release!

If it’s not in your budget to make a donation – there are other ways you can help.

• Come see our show as part of the Ars Nova Fling between October 11th and 28th.

  • ‘Like’ us on Facebook page, follow us on Twitter and Instagram or join our mailing list to help us spread the word!

Our play opens on October 11th and runs through October 28th at Theater 511, presented as an Ars Nova Fling. Buy Tickets HERE

Thank you in advance for your generous support.

With Profound Gratitude, 

Allison Threadgold

Founder & Producer

StrippedScritpts@gmail.com

Stripped Scripts

The mission of Stripped Scripts® is to create a unique environment for collaboration between actors and writers telling stories in front of an intimate audience. Stripped Scripts has two branches: a Readings series and Productions.  Stripped Scripts’ Productions strives to identify and cultivate exceptional work hoping to explore new approaches to both new and previously produced works, as well as new spaces for presenting theater. Through an examination of the language & specificity of text, characters are voiced in fresh and potentially unexpected ways.  Founded in Santa Barbara, CA in 2014 by Allison Threadgold, Stripped Scripts® is now bi-coastal with a new home in New York.

story:
Who Is This Guy?  

My name is Donnie Cianciotto, and I am a transgender actor and director who will be helming"Pass/Fail" this summer in The Trans Theatre Festival at The Brick. Here's some random facts about me so you know I exist:

  • I was the subject of an Emmy award-winning documentary short titled "Donnie" that was shown as part of The Trans Theatre Festival in 2016 (currently in production to be turned into a feature length film.)
  • I made my off-Broadway debut in the musical "Southern Comfort" at The Public Theater (directed by Tom Caruso) playing a transgender character. 
  • I am the creator and producer of Trans Voices Cabaret (www.transvoicescabaret.com), a show starring a cast of all TGNC (trans/gender non-conforming) entertainers that performs regularly at The Duplex.
  • I've performed in cabarets at 54 Below, The Cutting Room, Le Poisson Rouge, The Slipper Room, and in improv shows at The People's Improv Theater and The Magnet.
  • I've shown up in videos for NowThis Media and McClatchy News talking about topics relating to transgender issues, and use my experience as a creator to advocate for trans, non-binary, and gender non-conforming visibility and representation in all forms of media.
  •  I have 3 cats and a Border Collie, twenty-something tattoos, and hail from Staten Island (who could really use to get their $h!t together.)
  • You can also go here for more proof of my existence: www.donniecianciotto.weebly.com 

 

What Do We Need?

Your donations will help us bring you the best production of "Pass/Fail" possible by helping us with costs like:

  • Printing scripts, schedules, posters, etc
  • Renting rehearsal space
  • Costumes, props, set pieces, etc
  • Graphic design and marketing
  • All those last minute things we won't realize we need until it's literally the last minute
  • Providing the cast & crew with a stipend to thank them for their hard work!

 

What Do You Get?

You get the satisfaction of knowing you helped a group of trans and non-binary identified creators put up a show where we had the opportunity to tell our stories with our own words and our own voices, and to share it with the public. REPRESENTATION MATTERS, and The Trans Theatre Festival at The Brick highlights the voices of those often over-looked by other forms of media and pushes trans narratives to the forefront of the festival instead of including us as an afterthought or a "token."

"Pass/Fail" was written by a transgender playwright, directed by a transgender director, and has multiple trans/non-binary people in the cast and on the crew. Your donations will help us to not only do what we love, but to tell a story that all people will find they can relate to while raising awareness of trans visibility. You're helping us make art!

You'll also get a big shout-out on social media and oodles of gratitude. :)

 

Who Else Is Involved?

Cast

Johnny Saleh - Sydney Ronis

Noah Ziegler - Marc David Wright

Sari Gelber - Hannah Roze

Lucy Morris - Emily Mervosh

Brynn O'Neill - Jane Marie Price

Will Brown - Jonathan Hernandez

Dan Moran - Jacob Michael

Carina Caruso - Rebecca Cianciotto

Michelle Lee - Emily McNally

 

JONATHAN HERNANDEZ (WILL): Jonathan (he/him) is excited to work on Pass/Fail. Prior to working on this awesome project Jonathan recently wrapped up a touring show for kids in Portland, Oregon, called 'Pedro's Path to Power'. When not acting, he spends his time writing and is in the works of publishing his first full length play 'Mijo'. Other hobbies include listening to music, dancing, and yes... meditating. 

EMILY MERVOSH (LUCY): Emily (she/her) is so excited to be part of The Brick's Trans Theatre Festival! She was most recently seen in The Bia Theatre's 24 Hour Play Festival and "The Transit Tales" at the St. Jean's Players.  She is especially interested in the intersection of arts and activism and was a 2017 Artist as Citizen Fellow with Artists Striving to End Poverty (ASTEP).

JACOB MICHAEL (DAN): Jacob (he/him) is a Brooklyn-based trans-masculine actor/writer. Theatre credits include: Max (Hir, Island City Stage), Orin Scrivello (Little Shop..., Workshop Theater), Caldwell B. Cladwell (Urinetown, Rhino Theatre), Rod (Avenue Q, Porch Light Productions). He is a Paper Mill Playhouse Rising Star recipient. For more information, please visit: www.jacobmichael.net

JANE MARIE PRICE (BRYNN): Jane Marie (she/her) is a recent honor graduate of NYU Tisch and moved to the big city from a small town in northeast Georgia. While she has performed in many off-off-off-off-off-off-Broadway productions in the Habersham Community Theatre, this will be her first show post-grad, and she couldn’t be more excited!

SYD RONIS (JOHNNY): Syd (he/they) is delighted to be part of the Trans Theatre Festival. For the past 14 years, he's had the extreme pleasure of portraying a multitude of roles ranging from Penny Pennywise (Urinetown) and Pseudolus (A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum) to roles such as Martha Dobie (The Children's Hour) and Kate (Brighton Beach Memoirs). He's also had the privilege of studying briefly at Hofstra University and Circle in the Square Theatre School. Syd is overjoyed to be part of such a terrific cast and would like to extend a huge thank you to all those who came to support the show.

HANNAH ROZE (SARI:) Hannah (she/her) is proud to hold a BFA in Drama from New York University’s Tisch School of the Arts, having studied through the Lee Strasberg Theatre and Film Institute. On stage she recently performed: at The Cherry Lane Theater in a reading of Joy Behar’s new play Chain Reaction, at Urban Stage’s ‘Lady Liberty Festival’ in Emma Goldman-Sherman’s Middle-East-set political/family drama Abraham’s Daughters, and in several one acts of the inaugural and international ‘The Future is Female Festival’. Prior to all of which, Roze made her Off-Broadway debut, originating the role of French can-can girl and painter’s muse, Marie Marville, in The Final Days of Vincent Van Gogh. On the silver screen: Roze’s film The Disenchantment of a Young Adult and a Wild Child, which she wrote, co-directed, and stars in, is about to hit the festival circuit! Other shorts in which she has acted have been featured at the New Hampshire FF, Lincoln Center’s NY Jewish FF, SAG-AFTRA’s New York Short Film Showcase, the Big Apple FF, the SNOB FF, and the LGBT Film Festival. Roze also reads tarot, works for the Film Fatales, and is certified in the use of eight weapons by the Society of American Fight Directors. www.hannahroze.com   www.thedisenchantment.com

MARC DAVID WRIGHT (NOAH): Marc (he/him) is a rising senior Acting Major in the Fordham University Theatre Program. Regional (Hangar Theatre): A Funny Thing...Forum, The Journey of Lewis and Clark, Pullman Car Hiawatha. Fordham credits include: The Winter's Tale (Polixenes), Weldon Rising (Marcel), Bent (Freddie), Amazons and Their Men (The Man). Support queer art!

SANDY GOOEN (Playwright): Sandy (they/them or he/him) is a queer, transmasculine, Jewish, and neurodivergent writer/performer and peer advocate. Sandy is a rising senior, majoring in music at Barnard College. Writing: It Takes a Village at the Glicker-Milstein Summer Theatre Festival, In Circles with Scott Feiner at French Woods Festival, and the orchestrations for Ooh Kill 'Em at Columbia University. Sandy has performed domestically and internationally, but mostly in New York City, including David GeffenHall, The Metropolitan Opera House, Jazz at Lincoln Center, and Carnegie Hall. Sandy's Twitter is @featSandyGooen.

 

When Can I See This Thing?

Excellent question. You can catch "Pass/Fail" during the Trans Theatre Festival on:

July 9th, 17th, 18th, and 21st, 2018 at The Brick Theater. More info coming soon!

story:
About me

I'm a Dancer, Teacher and Choreographer of Indian dances. Born in Poland , I grew up learning Polish national dances for 12 years. Meanwhile, I also trained in Ice-skating and Ballet for 6 years.
My love for Indian culture, especially Indian Music and Dance started at a very young age and it came along with our family interest and practice of Sahaja Yoga meditation. Since then, my only dream was to learn Indian dance. Unfortunately at that time, it wasn't possible for me to pursue my dream in Poland and I had to wait until 2007, when I started learning Kathak basics in Poland (under a Polish dancer Magdalena Niernsee, graduated from Kathak Kendra, New Delhi) and then finally visited India for the first time in 2009.
It happened naturally that my love and passion for dance became my profession. I graduated with a  Bachelor's degree in Choreography and Dance Techniques from the Music Academy in Lodz, Poland (2013) and continued Masters in Choreography and Dance Theory at University of Music, Warsaw, Poland (2015). Teaching and performing in Poland is definitely what I love to do, but deep in my heart there was unending desire to learn more and experience this beautiful tradition of Guru-Shishya parampara (Master - Disciple tradition) in India.
 So since 2009, I visit India every year for 2-3 months for my Kathak training. By God's grace and my immensely supportive friends, I had the opportunity to learn from the best Gurus - Pt. Arjun Mishra, Pt. Birju Maharaj, Mamta Maharaj and Saswati Sen and for the last 5 years I've been a part of Abhinava Dance Company, learning under Smt. Nirupama and Shri T.D. Rajendra in Bangalore, India. This year I decided to stay for 5 months for a more intensive training but especially to prepare for my solo performance LEELA.

About LEELA 

Traditionally, in Indian Classical dance, when the Guru deems a disciple ready after years of  training, he or she does a special dance performance called "Rangapravesh", which is a graduation, a celebration on the completion of formal training, a humble offering of gratitude towards the Dance Guru (teacher), family, friends, other dancers, art connoisseurs and special guests of honour.  It is a Dance Diploma, when after performing with a good review a dancer joins the professional circle of classical artists, and that the dancer can now move forward and pass on the art form to other aspiring learners of the art. 
So LEELA is my Rangapravesh, 2 hours solo stage performance with live music. It consists of 5 choreographies of traditional kathak repertoire.

Why do I need your support? 

The cost of this event in a city like Bangalore is more than what I can afford right now. I don't have a steady income, like most freelance artists, and I am simply running on my savings , especially for the last 5 months that I am in India, I am totally devoted to my training and gearing up for this performance, which frankly is one of the most important performances in my life! And you can help me realize this dream!

 

What We Need & What You Get

The funding will cover:

  • musician's fees
  • classes fees
  • stage & hall decorations & labour 
  • refreshments for the artists
  • photography
  • videography
  • invitation design, printing
  • new costumes & jewellery
  • dinner for the guests
  • IndieGoGo fees
  • Bank transfer fees
  • Tax

In case I don't reach my entire goal, I will still use whatever I collect and make it little more modest, for example by cutting out the dinner, new costumes & jewellery. 

I kindly ask for your help to contribute any amount you can and become a part of my dance dream. I've prepared some unique perks for you! 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

I realize that not everyone will be able to contribute to the project, but that doesn't mean you can't help! 

Spread the word

Make some noise about this Indiegogo fundraiser!! The most powerful force in this whole process is awareness! The more that people are aware of this project, the more likely it is to succeed! 

So share this page, and let's do this together!!

Thank you so much for taking the time to read this. We really hope you can help us make this program happen. Thank you for all of your love and support.

Social media:

YOUTUBE: https://www.youtube.com/user/MsKingha

FACEBOOK: https://www.facebook.com/KingaMalecDancer

INSTAGRAM: https://www.instagram.com/kinga.malec.dance

Email: kinga.malec@gmail.com

story:
What WDMC and Queens Shakespeare Are Up To Now

After another amazing season, with amazing work onstage, with amazing audiences, who were in turn….amazed in 2015, What Dreams May Co in partnership with Queens Shakespeare Inc. again shines the looking glass onto 2 of literature’s most famous characters, who on the surface appear to be complete opposites. One, a certain boy who will never grow up. The other; one of Shakespeare’s kings who has grown quite old. Yet they both seem to suffer a clear case of “Peter Pan Syndrome”; flying about from place to place, searching for a mother, and oblivious to the destruction they leave in their wake.  Join us for a season of flying, fighting, and crowing in the Spring and then in Winter make way for a very crazy, cranky King….or Queen (wink wink…nod nod) First up: The Terrible Tragedy of Peter Pan.

A reimagining of the classic children’s story adapted from the original J.M. Barrie play, The Terrible Tragedy of Peter Pan casts adults in the roles traditionally played by children. And explores through this new lens, what it really means to never grow up. Director Christina Sheehan’s sparse yet gritty design, institutionalizes each character in a way that lets us look into their psychology as we watch each “play” through their individual psychoses. A world made of “faith, trust, and fairy dust” that makes us ask ourselves are we in Neverland, or is Neverland inside all of us?

Please note: The Terrible Tragedy of Peter Pan is recommended for ages 13 and up.

Why Do We Need Your Help?

We are performing right in the heart of Times Square!  We are so excited to be producing at John DeSotelle Studio this winter!  Now that our rent is going up, any help you can give will be felt even more deeply.  Here's a breakdown of what you can do:

If you donate $90 you will be covering the price of a week of rehearsals.

If you donate $150 you will be covering the price of our programs.

If you donate $200 you will be covering the price of our photographer.

If you donate $500 you will be covering the rights to perform the play.

If you donate $1000 you will cover half a weekend of performances.

If you donate $2000 you will cover a full weekend of performances.

A contribution of any size will help us to make things happen, and makes you a part of the artistic process! So choose your favorite perk and join the team!

Who Is WDMC?

Founded in 2011, What Dreams May Co. is dedicated to making the classics accessible to all. Simple, minimalistic productions leave the focus on the language and characters, challenging the actors in the company to reach new levels and expand their knowledge of the classics. Passionate performances delve to the heart of the text, bringing the story to life in a way that connects with and immerses modern audiences. After all, “What dreams may come, when we have shuffled off this mortal coil, must give us pause.” With our productions, we hope every person has a chance to experience that moment to pause, be touched by the beauty of the language, and carry that experience with them into the world.

Who Is Queens Shakespeare?

Founded in 2005 by Nanette Asher, Queens Shakespeare, Inc. is a not-for-profit professional theatrical company, which serves Queens County and the greater New York City area. Its aim is to act as a laboratory for actors of all ages and experience levels to explore classical works and to perform in fully produced, accessible, and innovative productions. Each season one production is developed as an educational tour which is then presented at different venues throughout the state. Producing and touring in this fashion allows the company to actively contribute to the growth and vibrancy of the developing Queens arts scene, while at the same time exposing classical works to modern audiences through the educational tour.


Your friends at WDMC and Queens Shakespeare,

Chrissy and Jonathan
story_txt:
What WDMC and Queens Shakespeare Are Up To Now
After another
amazing season, with amazing work onstage, with amazing audiences, who were in
turn….amazed in 2015, What Dreams May Co in partnership with Queens Shakespeare
Inc. again shines the looking glass onto 2 of literature’s most famous
characters, who on the surface appear to be complete opposites. One, a certain
boy who will never grow up. The other; one of Shakespeare’s kings who has grown
quite old. Yet they both seem to suffer a clear case of “Peter Pan Syndrome”;
flying about from place to place, searching for a mother, and oblivious to the
destruction they leave in their wake. 
Join us for a season of flying, fighting, and crowing in the Spring and
then in Winter make way for a very crazy, cranky King….or Queen (wink wink…nod
nod) First up: The Terrible Tragedy of Peter Pan.
