story:
Aller au bas de la page pour la version française


Our project 

http://newyorklivearts.org/event/let-my-people
In Astrid Bas's latest creation, LET MY PEOPLE GO, second to a series initiated  by "Life or theater"  by Charlotte Salomon, the worlds of Sarah Kane—English poet and playwright, depressive, in and out of institutions, who took her own life at age 27—and Charlotte Solomon—German Jew from a prestigious family haunted by multiple suicides, a visionary and prolific painter, who died at age 26 in a concentration camp—The worlds of these two women collide, as have the voices of those such as Angela Davis, Nelson Mandela, and other courageous souls who have struggled and fought for the meaning of true freedom and liberty over bondage of all kinds.
Astrid Bas has worked predominantly within French Government subsidiary institutions and has well proven her worth as an artist. She is exploring the works of Charlotte Salomon and Sarah Kane, both oppressed, one by Nazism and one by her alienation, mental illness. 

In LET MY PEOPLE GO,  movement, text, and video (Ghiora Aharoni) blend together to express the poetry of life, love, creation, liberty. 

 Who we are 

Astrid Bas, actress, dancer, director has had a long career as an actress working with directors such as Georges Lavaudant, Anatoli Vassiliev, Jean Marie Patte, Frederic Fishbach, Raimund Hogues, Edward Niermans, Benoît Jacquot, Hélène Vincent, Christophe Perton, Frédéric Berthes, Nicolas and Bruno...As a director she has staged Tchekov's three Sisters (Odeon theater, Paris) , Duras's The lover and La musica 2, Life or theater, Materiau Platonov, Phaedra in India. As a dancer, she has worked with Peter Goss, Robert Moses, Raimund Hogues and Alonzo King, enriching and expanding her vision and ways of telling stories through the body.

 Frederic Moulin, Actor As a theater actor he has among others worked with E. Cerruti, Geiger, Nicolas Maury, Robert Cantarella...In film he was an actor with Pippo Delbonno, Robert Cantarella, Russ Holt, Soukourov, Dick Turner... He trained as an actor at International Center of Performing Arts in Paris. He also holds a master in translation studies. He is fluent in English and Italian.

Darrell Davis, Consultant, was a   Ballet dancer at the Dance Theater of Harlem, he then worked with Jean Claude Gallota for 14 years as a dancer,  assistant choreographer and trainer for the company. He has been teaching at the CCN in Grenoble, at the Australian ballet, at the CNSMD in Paris and at the DV8 company. In his teaching he uses a technique develloped by Balanchine and works on fast paced movement in space. 


What we have accomplished

After many efforts and much support from talented, generous, and committed collaborators, Astrid Bas and company have secured two performances at NY LiveArts on June 28th and 29th. 

Where we wish to go

Creating new work is always a challenge. Creating new work in another country is an even greater challenge. But creating a new work for New York is the greatest challenge of all! LET MY PEOPLE GO has been fully supported by the Gibney Dance Center, ODC in San Francisco, Alonzo King's Lines Ballet, Centre National de la Danse and generous individuals, moving the piece from workshop to a full fledged show. 

LET MY PEOPLE GO has been invited to perform at Joe Goode Annex in San Francisco. The funds from your generous support will be used to ensure further production costs and allow the show, through outreach and publicity, to be seen in New York, San Francisco and Paris.


                         JOIN THE TEAM                        

The Astrid Bas Company needs your support to realize these goals. 

Any contribution helps.

Come and see the show at New York Live Arts June 28th and 29th at 7:30pm.

More information about post-show talk backs, the NYLA show, and the show at the Annex will be forthcoming closer to the dates of the debut. We hope to see you there! 

Link to NY Livearts: http://newyorklivearts.org/event/let-my-people

Other way to give:  https://newyorklivearts.secure.force.com/donate/?dfId=a0n3100000DqOyTAAV

Please share the word and spread this campaign.

                                            Thank you and see you soon!


                                       VERSION FRANCAISE

Notre projet

LET MY PEOPLE GO est une création originale de danse théâtre d'Astrid Bas, seconde partie d'une série initiée lors d'une Villa Medicis hors les murs par "La vie ou le théâtre ?" de Charlotte Salomon.

Astrid Bas y poursuit sa réflexion sur l'univers​ de Charlotte Salomon, ainsi que  sur celui​ de Sarah Kane, deux femmes artistes toutes deux opprimées, l’une par le nazisme, l’autre par son aliénation au monde et  la maladie mentale, à la recherche de leurs propres voix.

Sarah Kane, poétesse et auteur dramatique britannique, sujette à la dépression, a vécu des séjours en hôpital psychiatrique et met fin à sa vie à 27 ans. Charlotte Salomon, juive allemande, née dans une famille prestigieuse hantée par de nombreux suicides, peintre prolifique et visionnaire, est morte à 26 ans dans un camp de concentration. 

Apr​è​s sa Villa Medicis hors les murs et  "La vie ou le théâtre" à ODC theater qui ont permis d’élaborer le travail, LET MY PEOPLE GO a été présenté en résidence à Gibney Arts Center et au Centre National de la Danse à Pantin en 2015. LET MY PEOPLE GO sera créé à  NY Livearts les 28 et 29 Juin 2016. 

Le mouvement, le texte et la video (Ghiora Aharoni) se rejoignent pour exprimer la poésie de la vie, l’amour, la création, la liberté…

Bios 

Astrid Bas, metteur en scène, comedienne, danseuse. Parallèlement à une carrière de comédienne avec Georges Lavaudant, Anatoli Vassiliev, Jean Marie Patte, Frederic Fisbach, Raimund Hogues, Edward Niermans,  Benoît Jacquot, Hélène Vincent, Christophe Perton, Frederic Berthes, Nicolas et Bruno, Astrid Bas a mis en scène Les trois sœurs de Tchekov  (Théâtre de l'Odeon),  Matériau Platonov, l’Amant et la Musica 2 de Duras, Phèdre en Inde, et Life of Theater. En tant que danseuse, elle a travaillé avec Peter Goss, Raimund Hoghes, Robert Moses et Alonzo King, ce qui lui a permis d’enrichir sa vision et ses moyens de raconter une histoire. 

Frederic Moulin, acteur.  Au théâtre  a travaillé avec, entre autres, E Cerruti, Geiger, Nicolas Maury, Robert Cantarella . Au cinéma il a joué avec Pippo Delbonno, Russ Holt, Sokourov, Dick Turner. Il a été formé au Centre International des arts de la scène. Il est titulaire d' un master en traduction. Il est bilingue en Anglais et en Italien..

Darrell Davis, Assistant/Consultant. Danseur classique au Dance Theatre of Harlem, New York, de 1978 à 1986, Darrell Davis arrive en France en 1986. Il travaille avec le chorégraphe Rheda et danse à la télévision et sur scène pendant de nombreuses années.   Il rejoint le CCN Grenoble en 1991 comme interprète puis devient l’assistant de Jean Claude Gallotta et répétiteur de la compagnie. Il assure la transmission de son répertoire auprès de nombreuses compagnies en France et à l’étranger. Il continue également a assister Jean Claude Gallotta dans ses choréographies avec le CCN Grenoble et assure la direction artistique pendant son absence. Titulaire du Diplôme d’Etat en 2009 en danse classique, il enseigne la danse au CCN Grenoble mais également à l’Australian Ballet, au Conservatoire National Supérieur de Musique et de Danse, et à la compagnie DV8...Les cours s’appuient sur la technique développée par George Balanchine, l’adage, la rapidité et le déplacement dans l’espace.

"Transmettre au mieux mon art à un artiste chorégraphique afin qu’il puisse trouver en lui les outils nécessaires pour acquérir un style et une technique au‐delà de la passion de la danse". 


                                       Rejoignez notre équipe

LET MY PEOPLE GO a été soutenu par Gibney Dance Center, ODC Theater à San Francisco, Alonzo King Line’s ballet, le CND de Pantin et des généreux donateurs. 

Le spectacle a été invité à jouer à San Francisco, à Joe Goode Annex.

Les ressources provenant de votre soutien permettront au spectacle, avec le support de la communication et de la publicité, d'avoir une actualité à New York, San Francisco, Paris... 

Le spectacle a été présenté les 28 et 29 Juin.

  http://newyorklivearts.org/event/let-my-people
 
Nous soutenir autrement  https://newyorklivearts.secure.force.com/donate/?dfId=a0n3100000DqOyTAAV


                                          MERCI et à bientôt!

story:
Ashes to Ashes by Harold Pinter

This is a senior project production of Ashes to Ashes by Harold Pinter. Produced in The Sub C "Underground" Theater of the Performing Arts Building on the SUNY Purchase College Campus from February 25-27. Show dates are as followed:
February 25th 7:30-8:30
February 26th 7:30-8:30
February 27th 2:30-3:30 and 7:30-8:30
The show deals with a married couple who struggle to maintain a normal life and relationship after suffering from traumatic events. Throughout the play these characters degrade and succumb to the realities of what has happened to them.
Can Rebecca and Devlin save their marriage while fighting back their demons?
Ashes to Ashes forces it's audience to look at victims of Post Traumatic Stress Disorder, Victims of War and Abuse, and the every day struggles of parenting and marriage. 
A mysterious and gripping short play promises to have audiences on the edge or their seat.
Cast:
Rebecca- Jane Coty (Senior Project)
Devlin- Michael Moray
Production Team:
Director- Alyssa Keller
Stage Manager- Jessica Rappaport
Scenic Designer- Annamarie Carcione
Lighting Designer- Cameron Reiss
Sound Designer- Zachary Dobryn


Why We Need Your Help

Funding Ashes to Ashes means we will get to produce a top notch show for audiences viewing pleasure. 
With your contribution we will be able to build a realistic and unsettling set that will draw you in and peak your interest. Money will go to purchasing wood, paint, props, furniture, set dressings, and other odds and ends needed to create a home onstage for our characters.
Funding will also allow us to buy period costumes for our actors, pay photographers and rights holders, graphic designers, and the numerous people involved in making this production happen.

Remember, admission is free for Ashes to Ashes! 
Other Ways You Can Help

We understand not everyone can help. A lot of us are students, recent grads, and parents with students in school. So here are some ways you can help us without spending any money!

  • Send this Indiegogo page to anyone you know. Spread the word. Entry is free for everyone, so there is no reason not to come! The play aims to reach anyone who is willing to hear the story it is telling. So send this page to everyone you know even if they don't know anyone involved. 
  • Use the Indiegogo Share Tools to share this campaign on social media!

We can't wait to see you! Enjoy the Show.

story:
What is this project?

I came to Spartanburg in 2015 as an artist-in-residence. One of the first things I did was to attend Speaking Down Barriers. I knew I wanted to make a play that interacted with this incredible organization that facilitates forums on race in America. By the summer, I befriended a librarian who showed me an incredible set of documents: transcripts from a Federal investigation into the Ku-Klux Klan in Spartanburg County in 1871. These transcripts held the words of Spartanburg county citizens, both black and white, who were brave enough to testify against the KKK, who terrorized them and their families. 

This spring, I embarked on adapting these transcripts into "Untitled Reconstruction Play" in collaboration with Speaking Down Barriers. The play is a mix of historical documents adapted for the stage, and original writing by an incredible ensemble of writers, actors, lawyers, and activists. The wonderful cast is made up of James Cheek, Chandler Crawford, Zach Ellis, Stephen Harris, Crystal Irby, Chauncey Meeks-Owens, and Cody Owens.  The production team includes Andrea Azumendi, Ada Bennett, and Lily Knights. Marlanda Dekine will facilitate a discussion after the performance. 

Already, "Untitled Reconstruction Play" has been supported by organizations like The Arts Partnership of Greater Spartanburg and the Spartanburg Little Theatre. With help from people like you, we will be able to make "Untitled Reconstruction Play" a true community effort. 

What impact will my donation have?

Giving to our campaign means paying local artists. That means a more vibrant Spartanburg. All of this money goes towards stipends for actors, producers, and designers. Every dollar makes a difference towards making Spartanburg a community where cutting-edge art is possible. The collaborators who are writing and acting in this play are incredibly talented, wise people, and they deserve to be compensated for their efforts. 

"Untitled Reconstruction Play" explores a moment in Spartanburg's history that is not easy, comfortable, or simple. We believe that by discussing this moment, by hearing the words of these people, by adding them to the historical narrative, we make Spartanburg a community that is more honest, open, and ready for progressive dialogue about race in America.

What else can I do?

Get your tickets on eventbrite and come see us on May 20 & 21. 

If you can't share the wealth right now financially, we'd love it if you shared this campaign socially! Indiegogo is easy to share on Facebook, Twitter, and any other platforms where you're very famous. Thank you!
story_txt:
What is this project?I came to Spartanburg in 2015 as an artist-in-residence. One of the first things I did was to attend Speaking Down Barriers. I knew I wanted to make a play that interacted with this incredible organization that facilitates forums on race in America. By the summer, I befriended a librarian who showed me an incredible set of documents: transcripts from a Federal investigation into the Ku-Klux Klan in Spartanburg County in 1871. These transcripts held the words of Spartanburg county citizens, both black and white, who were brave enough to testify against the KKK, who terrorized them and their families. 
This spring, I embarked on adapting these transcripts into "Untitled Reconstruction Play" in collaboration with Speaking Down Barriers. The play is a mix of historical documents adapted for the stage, and original writing by an incredible ensemble of writers, actors, lawyers, and activists. The wonderful cast is made up of James Cheek, Chandler Crawford, Zach Ellis, Stephen Harris, Crystal Irby, Chauncey Meeks-Owens, and Cody Owens.  The production team includes Andrea Azumendi, Ada Bennett, and Lily Knights. Marlanda Dekine will facilitate a discussion after the performance. 

Already, "Untitled Reconstruction Play" has been supported by organizations like The Arts Partnership of Greater Spartanburg and the Spartanburg Little Theatre. With help from people like you, we will be able to make "Untitled Reconstruction Play" a true community effort. 
What impact will my donation have? Giving to our campaign means paying local artists. That means a more vibrant Spartanburg. All of this money goes towards stipends for actors, producers, and designers. Every dollar makes a difference towards making Spartanburg a community where cutting-edge art is possible. The collaborators who are writing and acting in this play are incredibly talented, wise people, and they deserve to be compensated for their efforts. 
 "Untitled Reconstruction Play" explores a moment in Spartanburg's history that is not easy, comfortable, or simple. We believe that by discussing this moment, by hearing the words of these people, by adding them to the historical narrative, we make Spartanburg a community that is more honest, open, and ready for progressive dialogue about race in America.
What else can I do?Get your tickets on eventbrite and come see us on May 20 & 21. 
If you can't share the wealth right now financially, we'd love it if you shared this campaign socially! Indiegogo is easy to share on Facebook, Twitter, and any other platforms where you're very famous. Thank you!

story:
Fire on Babylon* tells the story of two New Yorkers each locked in personal crisis, while the city is having one of its own: the 2003 blackout. Reclusive novelist Hugo Thomas hasn’t written anything in years. After accepting an advance for a new book, he’s assigned a beguiling yet challenging young editor to assist him at his downtown apartment. When Hugo's apartment is plunged into darkness, secrets are revealed and the two men launch into a psychosexual game of cat and mouse. 

Setting: New York, August 2003

Cast:

Hugo Thomas...................Jeffrey Hayenga

Christian Snow.................Michael Raver

*Semi-finalist for The O’Neill Conference, 2015
*Nominated for The Robert Chesley/Victor Bumbalo Foundation Playwriting Award

Tuesday July 12th, 9pm

Friday July 15th, 6pm

Sunday July 17th,  5pm

The WILD Project Theater

195 E 3rd St, New York

For tickets, visit www.freshfruitfestival.com

"I'm delighted that Michael Raver's compelling play, Fire on Babylon, has been selected for this year's Fresh Fruit New Play Festival," says director Paul Mason Barnes. "Michael's is a unique voice in the American Theatre.  His wit, intelligence, sense of tension and surprise combined with his knack for writing dialogue that sounds like what real people actually say make his plays a pleasure to direct. I'm excited that this new work will be shared with a wider audience; very happy to get to work with Michael as both playwright and actor; and honored to help Fire on Babylon take this next step forward."  

"Fire on Babylon is passionate, it is ABSOLUTELY fearless, it is beautifully, and professionally, written and it announces a genuine playwriting talent. It is a story of the very many complexities involved in any passionate love between two people. And the meanings of it unfold, constantly. In other words, it unfolds with a seriously developed dramatic sense."

                                              -Austin Pendleton (actor/director/playwright)

"One of the richest and most riveting plays I've seen in a long time, grounded in the power dynamics of age difference, but universal in a very soulful way."

                                                -Stephen Greco (author, Now and Yesterday)

(Jeffrey Hayenga & Michael Raver in FIRE ON BABYLON. Photo by Lloyd Mulvey.)

What this is for...

This campaign is to raise the funds to cover all of the production costs for the run of Fire on Babylon at the Fresh Fruit Festival this summer. 

The first draft of this play was written in 2012 and has since undergone a series of incredible transformations. It served as a great life raft for me during the more difficult experiences I've had in the last four years and I am fortunate to have emerged from that time with something beautiful (the script), which I value tremendously.

Paul Mason Barnes came aboard the project in 2013 and has been an unbelievable collaborator and friend. Supportive, generous with his attention and his energy, he's helped shape the play in it's current form in ways that are too many to list. Needless to say, I love him very much and I'm honored that he is taking part in this project.  It means a great deal to us to finally share a staged version of the play, in full performance, with everyone. The funds donated here will go toward paying all of the artists involved, as well as all of the production costs (the set, costumes, props and so on).

For your generosity, we've assembled a really great collection of rewards, and over the course of this campaign, will be updating to that collection. So check back regularly for more information on that!
Much love. Much gratitude.  
                                               -Michael Raver

(Photo by Lloyd Mulvey)

Here is Marc Wheeler's gorgeous rendering for our super slick set:

Who we are...
We've assembled a fantastic team to have this play storm The Fresh Fruit Festival:
Paul Mason Barnes (director) is an award winning director whose work has been seen at major regional theaters and festivals, and at leading training programs across the country. The founder of the Oregon Cabaret Theatre and the Great River Shakespeare Festival, Barnes has been Conservatory Director/Associate Artistic Director at PCPA Theaterfest and Education Director at the Oregon Shakespeare Festival in Ashland, Oregon, where he makes his home. Recent/upcoming directing credits: Georama, a new musical by West Hyler, Matt Schatz, and Jack Herrick (Great River Shakespeare Festival); Macbeth (Chesapeake Shakespeare Company); Peter Pan (Syracuse Stage); Of Mice and Men (Clarence Brown Theatre); The Glass Menagerie (GRSF); A Midsummer Night's Dream (Repertory Theatre of St. Louis).

Donny Repsher (Producer) is Signature Theatre's Individual Giving Manager. In December he produced Barrier Islands, a world premiere play written by Lizzie Vieh at The Wild Project.

Michael Raver (playwright/Christian Snow) is an actor, playwright and journalist. His performance as a young Richard Feynman in the film How We Built the Bomb received rave reviews. His Off-Broadway debut was in Ellen McLaughlin's adaptation of The Persians with Tony Randall's National Actor's Theater. His most recent television appearance was on "TURN: Washington's Spies." As a playwright, his adaptation of The Picture of Dorian Gray was produced by Sonnet Repertory Theatre at the Signature Theatre Center in 2012, and a reading of his pre-WWII adaptation of Chekhov's The Seagull was seen at the Pearl Theatre Company. His play Fire on Babylon, was nominated for The Robert Chesley/Victor Bumbalo Foundation Award for Playwriting, as well as being named a semifinalist for The O'Neill Conference in 2015. He has also served, for three years, as a judge for the Ferro-Grumley Award for LGBT Fiction. He regularly contributes cultural arts journalism for Classical TV, as well as pieces for Hamptons Monthly, Dance Magazine, Cool Hunting and Nature's Post.

Jeffrey Hayenga (Hugo Thomas) Roundabout: The Man Who Came To Dinner, The Importance of Being Earnest, Harvey, and the National Tour of Twelve Angry Men. Other NY Stage credits include: The Elephant Man (title role), Jeffrey (title role), Two Rooms (Signature Theatre), Hapgood (Lincoln Center), As Bees In Honey Drown, Sister Mary Explains It All For You, Burkie, Hamlet, Mother Courage, King Lear. Regional: Salome (Shakespeare Theatre DC), The Winslow Boy (St. Louis Rep), The Dream of the Burning Boy (Malibu Playhouse), Good Boys (ACT Seattle), Nicholas Nickleby (Missouri Rep), Emma (Pioneer Theatre, Salt Lake), Love! Valour! Compassion! and A Question of Mercy (Intiman, Seattle), Pride's Crossing and Breaking Up (Old Globe, San Diego). TV: “Bones,” “Law and Order,” “Law and Order: Criminal Intent,” “Star Trek: The Next Generation,” “Enterprise,” “JAG,” “Trinity,” “Bodies of Evidence,” “NY Undercover,” “Jack and Bobby,” “In The Heat of The Night,” “Matlock.”  Film: Other People's Money, And The Band Played On, Memron, The Unborn, The Prince of Pennsylvania, Center Stage.

Marc Wheeler (Set Design)

Edward Ray Kiely (Costume Design)

Mike Billings (Lighting Design)

Strapped for Cash?

We understand that times are tough and for those who are unable to give, there are still things you can do to help! Share this campaign on social media and spread the word!

story:
Hello Friends, Family and Fans!

John Ryan and Dani here of Rosemont Post! We have an exciting project ahead and we need your help! We have an opportunity to produce our very first Music Video for our newest single "Mel" We are talking CONCEPTS, VISUALS, DANCERS, choreo by the amazing Aaron Medina of Soundbox Studios (@yasaaronyaaaaas), Make up By Arturo Carvajal (@byarturocarvajal), and plenty of ATTITUDE! We are so proud of this song and would love to give it the video it deserves and with the possibility of it reaching new audiences!

Your Impact

 Each dollar you give will go an an artist making art 

  • We all know we need some queer, body positive and inclusive art in this world right now.
  • We have 3 singles with over 10k streams per song and Mel is climbing higher each day.
  • We feel as if this video will not only be a platform for us both but for every artist involved and for your contribution as well.

Challenges

This time has been difficult for everyone including freelance artists all around the world. Throughout we have maintained a positive attitude, wrote songs, performed virtually and recorded safely and continued to pursue what we believe in.

We have a chance to push through these challenges with your help!

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share this page and tell your friends! Spread the word and please stream our songs on all major platforms.
  • Follow us at @rosemontpost ! Hopefully we will have some exciting content to share!

story:
Short Summary

This is T. James Callahan on behalf of Pan's Flute Productions, we are asking for your support in helping a young fellow Musician/Writer to get a musical up onto the stage. Through out my entire life, I’ve had this burning passion to write shows and now I finally got the chance to sit down and finish an amazing concept. I am a HUGE fan of Rock Musicals and classic folklore. POISONED encompasses both of these passions as a Snow White Rock Musical about Love, Anxiety, and Acceptance! It’s a dark retelling that touches on many topics like how fame and power can become an addiction, how to overcome abuse, and believing in hope in the darkest of times.  

With your support this Campaign will help contribute to production expenses (set, costumes, and sound), Venues (theater rentals and rehearsal spaces), and to an amazing creative staff that's putting their time and effort to make this show happen. 

Please spread the word so you can see this show live in a town near you. 

The Impact

I’ve always been told, “Be the change you want to see in world.” That’s what this musical is: my vision of that change. It features strong female characters, LGBT representation, and diversity, as well surviving abuse, holding on to hope in darkest of times, and standing up for what’s right.

Risks & Challenges

In producing theatre there are always some risks. We are planning for a successful run.  In putting all the puzzle pieces in place, we need your support. Live theater is a collaboration of many talents on and off the stage.  Your financial support is needed and ask that you contribute to this project and join us on this journey.  We are committed to bringing this amazing production to the public. Our ultimate goal is a long, beneficial run of Poisoned!

Meet the Team!

T. James Callahan is the Creator, Writer and Director.  Ever since Tyler was a young child, music has always been apart of his life! Throughout his childhood Tyler was involved with his church choir and then was taught to dance at Bataille Dance Academy! It wasn’t till later in his youth that he discovered the world of musical theater and ever since Tyler has been apart of many shows and many productions throughout the Chicago Land area. Later, he studied music and jazz vocals technique at the Bloom School of Jazz with David Bloom himself and Spider Saloff. Tyler is currently studying vocals with the fabulous Christine Shelton and now Tyler’s true love and passion is writing and being involved with music! No matter where he goes Tyler wants to give all his love and thanks to his friends and family for their inspiration and support. Tyler always look forward to dedicate his life to music and most of all to the theater.

Michael Galloway is the Producer. When Michael was in the 3rd grade he played the guard at Emerald City in the Wizard of Oz.  That little Theater Bug germ blossomed into a full blown addiction to being on stage.  After acting in numerous school and community theater shows through his school and college years (proud to be an alum of AMDA and including dancing in a grass skirt and coconut bra), he turned his attention to the dark side..well, working off the stage.  He is able to boast many accomplishments in acting, directing, stage management, and lighting design,  but his passion lies in producing live theater. Now, in his early 50's and having successfully produced over 50 shows in his career (including American Idiot, Nunsense, Billy Elliot the Musical, Legally Blonde, Bleacher Bums, Waiting for Godot just to name a few). He now turns his talents to Poisoned: A Snow White Rock Musical! He would like to thank his family and loved ones for always supporting him and believing in the productions he loves.

Aaron Kaplan is the Musical Director.   Aaron enjoys a multifaceted musical career as a conductor, musical director, cellist, music educator, and arranger. Aaron has been the music director/conductor for over 65 musicals (with complete orchestration) including West Side Story, On the Town, Les Misérables, Sweeney Todd, Of Thee I Sing, RENT, Chess, Guys & Dolls, Fiddler on the Roof, and The Producers.  He is the assistant orchestra director at Glenbrook North and Glenbrook South High Schools in Northbrook and Glenview, IL, is on the faculty at the Music Institute of Chicago and is the assistant director of the Chicago Suzuki Institute.  As a cellist, he is currently a member of Sinfonia da Camera and the Heartland Festival Orchestra. Aaron earned a master’s degree in orchestral conducting from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign under the tutelage of Donald Schleicher, in addition to a bachelor’s degree in cello performance and bachelor’s degree in music education. 

Annie Snow is the Choreographer.  Annie is a Chicago based teaching artist, choreographer, and performer. Recent choreography credits include: Elf Jr. (Big Deal Productions),  Xanadu  (Big Noise Theatre-Lou Recommended-BWWW Nominee for Best Choreography                      Non-Equity), Sister Act (Mundelein High School Theatre), Oklahoma! (Glenview Theatre Guild), Elephant and Piggie We're In a Play! (Northbrook Theatre for Young Audiences) and Big Fish (Big Noise Theatre-BWW Nominee for Best Choreography-Non Equity). Annie is the Program Manager for Chicago Lights Dance Academy which services under privileged youth in Chicago. She also enjoys teaching dance at Studio 83 Dance Academy, where her choreography for the Studio 83 Dance Company has received many regional and national accolades. She is excited to be on board for Poisoned. Annie is so thankful to her family and friends for their unwavering support of her work over the years. 

Where's The Money Going?

With all original music, 11 actors, crew and a six piece band--it’s going to take a lot of hard work, time, and money to get Poisoned to the stage and beyond. So here’s the Breakdown:

Venue. The cost of the venue as well as rehearsal space.

Personnel. We believe that the hard work, dedicated time and creative talents of our actors, staff and musicians should be compensated. So that’s what we’re doing. We’re paying them a percentage and hope it grows in time.

Operations. This money will be used for insurance, merchandise and office supplies. 

Costumes. Set & Props. Sound. All the things we need to make sure our actors and musicians look and sound good on stage.

Marketing. Development. Printed materials and strategy to get people to see our fabulous show.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t donate right now, we’d still love your help! You can:

Like us on Facebook!

Follow us on Instagram  and @poisonedarockm1 on Twitter

Buy TICKETS TO THE SHOW

Share this page with people you know who would be interested in Poisoned! and encourage them to donate.

Reach out! We could always use a hand to help build set pieces, props, and more.

We are also looking for investors for the production. If you would like to be involved in that capacity, please contact our Producer, Michael Galloway at pansfluteproductions@gmail.com

Please show your support and spread the word!

Now, in his early 50's and having successfully produced over 50 shows in his career (including American Idiot, Nunsense, Billy Elliot the Musical, Legally Blonde, Bleacher Bums, Waiting for Godot just to name a few). He now turns his talents to Poisoned: A Snow White Rock Musical! He would like to thank his family and loved ones for always supporting him and believing in the productions he loves.Aaron Kaplan is the Musical Director.   Aaron enjoys a multifaceted musical career as a conductor, musical director, cellist, music educator, and arranger. Aaron has been the music director/conductor for over 65 musicals (with complete orchestration) including West Side Story, On the Town, Les Misérables, Sweeney Todd, Of Thee I Sing, RENT, Chess, Guys & Dolls, Fiddler on the Roof, and The Producers.  He is the assistant orchestra director at Glenbrook North and Glenbrook South High Schools in Northbrook and Glenview, IL, is on the faculty at the Music Institute of Chicago and is the assistant director of the Chicago Suzuki Institute.  As a cellist, he is currently a member of Sinfonia da Camera and the Heartland Festival Orchestra. Aaron earned a master’s degree in orchestral conducting from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign under the tutelage of Donald Schleicher, in addition to a bachelor’s degree in cello performance and bachelor’s degree in music education. Annie Snow is the Choreographer.  Annie is a Chicago based teaching artist, choreographer, and performer. Recent choreography credits include: Elf Jr. (Big Deal Productions),  Xanadu  (Big Noise Theatre-Lou Recommended-BWWW Nominee for Best Choreography                      Non-Equity), Sister Act (Mundelein High School Theatre), Oklahoma! (Glenview Theatre Guild), Elephant and Piggie We're In a Play! (Northbrook Theatre for Young Audiences) and Big Fish (Big Noise Theatre-BWW Nominee for Best Choreography-Non Equity). Annie is the Program Manager for Chicago Lights Dance Academy which services under privileged youth in Chicago. She also enjoys teaching dance at Studio 83 Dance Academy, where her choreography for the Studio 83 Dance Company has received many regional and national accolades. She is excited to be on board for Poisoned. Annie is so thankful to her family and friends for their unwavering support of her work over the years. Where's The Money Going?With all original music, 11 actors, crew and a six piece band--it’s going to take a lot of hard work, time, and money to get Poisoned to the stage and beyond. So here’s the Breakdown:Venue. The cost of the venue as well as rehearsal space.Personnel. We believe that the hard work, dedicated time and creative talents of our actors, staff and musicians should be compensated. So that’s what we’re doing. We’re paying them a percentage and hope it grows in time.Operations. This money will be used for insurance, merchandise and office supplies. Costumes. Set & Props. Sound. All the things we need to make sure our actors and musicians look and sound good on stage.Marketing. Development. Printed materials and strategy to get people to see our fabulous show.Other Ways You Can HelpIf you can’t donate right now, we’d still love your help! You can:Like us on Facebook!Follow us on Instagram  and @poisonedarockm1 on TwitterBuy TICKETS TO THE SHOWShare this page with people you know who would be interested in Poisoned! and encourage them to donate.Reach out! We could always use a hand to help build set pieces, props, and more.We are also looking for investors for the production. If you would like to be involved in that capacity, please contact our Producer, Michael Galloway at pansfluteproductions@gmail.comPlease show your support and spread the word!

story:
Support Community Engagement & the Arts in Brooklyn

Generator Theater Company presents Ryan Conarro's SAINTS OF FAILURE, October 24-November 9, in Fort Greene, Brooklyn. The SAINTS team seeks your funding support to make possible our site-specific residency at Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church, and to support our community engagement initiatives.

SAINTS OF FAILURE is Ryan Conarro's performance work featuring storytelling, music, and live makeup transformations, exploring the collision of queer and Christian identities in America. Ryan's stories weave with Risha Rox’s makeup design and Andrew Drannon's live organ accompaniment to invite audiences into memories of loss, discovery, and liberation. Presented by Generator Theater Company, SAINTS is presented in a site-specific production, in the sanctuary of Fort Greene, Brooklyn's historic LAPC. Ellie Heyman directs; Mary Ellen Stebbins, Haydee Antuñano, and Eric Sluyter design. Check out the show page here!

The SAINTS team seeks your funding support to make possible our site-specific residency at LAPC, and to support our community engagement initiatives. We're cultivating partnerships with Brooklyn Community Pride Center, The Door, and the Brooklyn Intergenerational Community Arts Council. We'll offer special workshops and facilitated dialogues to each of these organizations, as well as to members of our host venue, LAPC. We're also committed to offering regular post-performance discussions with all audiences.

This production will be presented in Juneau, Alaska in winter 2020 (the home town of our producing organization, Generator Theater).

Your donation will help by supporting the cost of our space rental at LAPC, and by sustaining our team of producers, artists, & facilitators for their planning, organizing, and facilitating our community engagement workshops, dialogues, and post-show discussions. With your donation, we'll be able to offer these opportunities free of charge to community participants.

What We Need & What You Get

We seek to raise $8500 through this campaign.

$3500 will be directed toward venue costs at LAPC

$1250 will cover the cost of one community dialogue event, including preparation, collaboration with partner organizations, materials, local travel, and facilitation - &, most importantly, free access for community participants.

$1250 will cover the cost of a second community dialogue event - including, again, free access for community participants.

$1500 will cover the cost of one practical arts and storytelling workshop, including preparation, collaboration with partner organizations, materials, local travel, and facilitation - & free access for community participants.

$500 will cover the cost of regularly scheduled post-performance discussions, including preparation, additional space time, collaboration with special guest moderators, and facilitation.

Our two community dialogues will offer supported space for LGBTQ+ people and their allies to reflect on and share personal experiences of the intersections of sexual and gender identities with religious and spiritual cultures and practices. Our practical workshop will offer young people and other participants practical tools for exploring and sharing their own personal stories through interdisciplinary art forms.

We welcome any amount you're able to give, of course! 

If you contribute $50 or more, you'll get a social media shoutout from Generator Theater.

If you contribute $100 or more, you'll get that shoutout, plus one ticket to Opening Night of the show (or any performance of your choosing).

If you support at $250 or more, receive all of the above, plus a 2nd ticket to any performance of your choosing, and a personalized thank-you note from the artistic team. 

If you support at $500 or more, receive the above, and your name will appear in the program as a Production Patron. 

We are committed to the community engagement offerings named above, and we'll fulfill these commitments whether or not we reach our funding goal. Your support will help make it possible for us to sustain engagement efforts like these, as well as to cover the other production costs associated with this project.

The Impact

Brooklyn Community Pride Center's Director of Programs recently told Ryan Conarro that the Center is seeking new ways to invite interaction between its Queer constituents and faith communities, to explore the complex intersections of spiritual and LGBTQ+ identity. We're glad to be planning these SAINTS OF FAILURE engagements with the Pride Center, and with our other community partners, to help fulfill that mission. By supporting this campaign, you can play your own role in advancing such mutual understanding in our communities.

Ryan is leading our engagement and facilitation efforts, in collaboration with our community partners. He's an experienced facilitator, including through his ongoing work as Artistic Collaborator in Residence at Ping Chong + Company. He's a neighborhood resident of Fort Greene and a member of Lafayette Ave Presbyterian Church, and he's invested in cultivating positive relationships in the neighborhood.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute...

  • Please come to the show! Invite your friends and family. October 24 to November 9.
  • Please spread the word about this campaign! Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Thanks for reading this far! ;)

story:
Who is Outsider's Inn Collective?


Outsider's Inn Collective is an itinerant illegitimate micro-theatre company dedicated to producing provocative new plays and early-modern plays of the Jacobean/Caroline eras. The Outsiders are Gregory Berry and Vladimir Verano.

Our desire is to create a peoples theatre by enlisting the support of our friends and the public at large to become producers--making this a 'collective' enterprise. Those who financially support us are playing an active role in bringing this new play to the stage. Together we create a community.


Our latest production?

A world-renowned Intellectual is harangued for his social and political views by a media demagogue and those with a conservative social agenda that threatens to destroy his career and marriage. 2011? Think again:


In 1940, philosopher and mathematician Bertrand Russell was accused of corrupting the youth of America; Radio and newspapers were marshaled by Christian moralists to confuse and coerce the American public: legal battles pitted the country's intelligentsia against the 'nice' people in a discussion about the limits of freedom of speech and the purpose of a democracy.

Sidney Norinsky's play, Bertie (Bertrand Russell's Excellent American Adventure) evokes and explores this shameful chapter in the American Experience and serves to remind us that those who forget the past are...

Sidney's play was the recipient of a semi-finalist award in the 2008 Eugene O'Neill Playwright's Competition. Outsider's Inn Collective is proud to present the West Coast premiere of this timely and engaging play.


Directed by Greg Berry 

Stage Manager: Anna Curtiss

Starring: Raymond Burke, David Carlson, Gerald Alejandro Ford, Kelly Johnson, Ashley Mauerhan, Abby Stein, and Andrew Tribolini

Performances: August 18,19,20 and 26&27  7:30p

at The Ballard Underground (Seattle, Washington) 2220 NW Market Street
 

Sidney Norinsky (playwright)

After years as an advertising copywriter, scriptwriter/director/producer of industrial/promotional films at Mobil Oil, sundry public relation, journalism, and ghostwriting stints  Norinsky turned full-time playwright in the 1990s. At last count, he says, he has eight (or maybe nine) full-length and five or six short plays in his repertoire. "Bertie" was a semi-finalist in the Eugene O'Neill National Competition in 2008 and had a sold-out performance in Hudson NY in 2009. One of his short satiric pieces, "Paradise Gained" was performed at the Fire Rose Theater, N. Hollywood, CA; another short "Unintelligent Design" was recently performed in Buffalo NY. (In Middleborough, Massachusetts that play became the center of controversy in 2007 when it was censored from performance by a church-affiliated board member of the local "Herring Run Theater Festival," an act that led to the protest resignation of the theater company's artistic director.) Another play, "Giordano Bruno" ran two performances in Kingston NY. Back in 1997 a 40-minute one-act play, "Triple Play" was performed at the Douglas Fairbanks Theater on 42 Street in New York City. The playwright lives in a small town 90 miles north of NYC in a house on the north side of a hill with his artist wife, Lynne Friedman, and Puff, a magic kitten. 


Our aims with this production?

Our expectation from the campaign is we will be able to reach a wider audience and increase our visibility. By doing so, we can encourage and produce more new plays. It is vital for playwrights to have a forum for their work that goes beyond the staged reading--full productions are a necessary part of the equation. Unlike other forms of writing, plays and playwrights are dependent on public performance--closet drama is no drama at all.

Truly, the main consequences of the campaign not happening are the continued difficulty of producing new work. We will soldier on, but we hope that out of this campaign we can move to another level in being an advocate for and  producer of new plays.


What We Need & What You Get:

This is an opportunity for you to join with us to create the Collective. To do theatre, one needs a commons or a community; theatre doesn't exist without the audience/supporters to tell the story to--the spectator completes the circle. We want the public to be our producers.

For a contribution of $25(a unique way to become a theatrical producer, get five friends contribute $5 a piece and you have $25--you all can be producers)  or more you will be Credited as a Producer. You share in the creation with us which in turn makes the Collective. There are many things in our technologically driven age which separate us or give us the illusion of connection; the live theatre performance puts us in a room or gathering place with others where we share a sense of community.

 

Production Costs for "Bertie"

Theatre Rental- $930

Royalties- $300 (5 performances x $60)

Rehearsal Space Rental- $300

Set and Costumes- $300

Posters/Programs- $170
               Total       $2000


Other Ways You Can Help

~ Share this Indiegogo campaign with others!

~Join our Facebook Fan page and invite your friends to join us.

http://www.facebook.com/pages/Outsiders-Inn-Col...

~Our greatest form of advertising is word of mouth!

story:
Wit's End Theatre has a new play-in-development!

Science Inaction [working title] is set to receive a workshop and performances this June in Halifax, NS but we need YOUR help to do it!

THE PROJECT

A TV-obsessed young grad student studying amphibian neurobiology can’t help but be charmed by the gawky doctoral candidate visiting her lab. But when he doesn’t turn out to be all she had hoped, she takes matters into her own hands, making him an object of scientific experimentation. Set in the height of civilization that was 1997, the play reimagines the so-called Science Wars of the 1980s and 90s as a War of the Sexes.

Science Inaction will receive a two week workshop with performances in late June, 2012 at the Bus Stop Theatre in Halifax. 

ABOUT WIT'S END

The Long:

Halifax-based Wit’s End Theatre creates, produces, and presents new and classic comedic plays. We promote the role of comedy in theatre and enrich our community by facilitating educational outreach programs and providing opportunities for local artists. Our goal is to provoke thought and discussion through and about humour, wit, and laughter.

Wit’s End is not just out for shallow laughs. The organization recognizes the inherent value in laughter for laughter’s sake and privileges the role of comedy in artistic and intellectual exploration. Often something is funny because it’s out of the ordinary: comedy points us to the bizarre, the unexpected, and the extra-ordinary.

The Short:

We make funny theatre.

Read more about us at witsendtheatre.ca or our Facebook page at http://www.facebook.com/WitsEndTheatre.

What We Need & What You Get

TV is kind of a big part of the project. Like, a BIG part of the project. Here's what we need to pay for:

  • A dozen televisions
  • Half as many DVD players
  • Technical equipment
  • A film designer and director
  • Editing time
  • Film operator
If you help us pay for all this stuff, you get access to the great perks on the right PLUS a CHARITABLE RECEIPT! What a deal!

To Donate

  1. Choose one (or more!) of the PERKS to the right, and click CLAIM THIS PERK.
  2. Indicate in the PayPal payment that the purchase is for Wit's End Theatre.
  3. Make sure to include your full name and address in the PayPal payment information, and Theatre Nova Scotia will send you your charitable receipt!

Chester Getaway

Perk #7, the "HBO Miniseries" features a "mini" seaside vacation for you and a friend in a chalet in beautiful Chester, Nova Scotia, on the province's South Shore. The chalet has full running water and electricity and overlooks the town's back harbour and famous island-studded Mahone Bay.

Attractions Chester is home to: the world-famous Race Week,the largest fixed-keel sailboat regatta in Canada; the Chester Playhouse and annual Summer Theatre Festival; tours of remote Tancook island; heritage tours; museums; dozens of beaches and islands; and access to the rest of Nova Scotia's South Shore. For more about Chester and its surroundings, check out chesterareans.ca.

Food This perk also features two breakfasts prepared to your liking by Wit's End artistic co-director Griffin McInnes. While the chalet has no kitchenette, Chester has fantastic restaurants and cafes that cater to its many visitors and summer residents. 

Travel Located approximately an hour South-West of Halifax, travel by car can be arranged for you and your guest, however bringing your own vehicle will allow you to explore the South Shore's scenic Lighthouse Route and nearby Mahone Bay and Lunenburg. 

Timing The chalet will be available for a single weekend, from Friday afternoon to the following Monday morning. The weekend can be arranged to fit your schedule, depending on availability. This perk must be used by September 2012. 

Charitable Receipts

Wit's End Theatre is member of Theatre Nova Scotia (TNS) and a participant in their theatre partnership program. TNS is a registered charitable organization (charitable tax number 11906 3394 RR0001). When you make a donation to Wit's End Theatre through TNS, you get a charitable receipt for the amount indicated in the PERKS section (your donation minus the value of the perk).  

The Impact

By donating to Wit's End Theatre, you'll:

  • Help us pay for the people and equipment we need to build an incredible show.
  • Contribute to the growth of some of Halifax's best emerging artists.
  • Become a part of the Wit's End team!

Other Ways You Can Help

10 Bucks is just about the most affordable way you can help a young theatre company, get a charitable receipt, and overall feel great about yourself! 

But if you just can't bring yourself to click that button, there are other ways you help:

  • Tell your friends! Share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, and everywhere!
  • Come see the show (duh!).
  • Donate your time. We have lots of volunteer opportunities. If you're interested, email us at witsendtheatreco@gmail.com.

Timing The chalet will be available for a single weekend, from Friday afternoon to the following Monday morning. The weekend can be arranged to fit your schedule, depending on availability. This perk must be used by September 2012. 

Charitable Receipts
Wit's End Theatre is member of Theatre Nova Scotia (TNS) and a participant in their theatre partnership program. TNS is a registered charitable organization (charitable tax number 11906 3394 RR0001). When you make a donation to Wit's End Theatre through TNS, you get a charitable receipt for the amount indicated in the PERKS section (your donation minus the value of the perk).  


The Impact
By donating to Wit's End Theatre, you'll:

Help us pay for the people and equipment we need to build an incredible show.
Contribute to the growth of some of Halifax's best emerging artists.
Become a part of the Wit's End team!



Other Ways You Can Help
10 Bucks is just about the most affordable way you can help a young theatre company, get a charitable receipt, and overall feel great about yourself! 
But if you just can't bring yourself to click that button, there are other ways you help:

Tell your friends! Share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, and everywhere!
Come see the show (duh!).
Donate your time. We have lots of volunteer opportunities. If you're interested, email us at witsendtheatreco@gmail.com.

story:
Hallo!

Facing Page Productions is producing our next event! It is Company’s Marathon 2013: a reading of all of Shakespeare’s plays… in a row!

That’s right everyone. We are going to read the entire canon, 24/7 starting Tuesday, April 16th at 8pm (kickoff party at 7pm) through Saturday, April 20th at 10am! This event, created by Gordy Hoffman in 1998, has been done in Chicago and Los Angeles. Company’s Marathon 2013 will mark its New York debut!

For our inaugural year in NYC, we asked André Braugher to set the reading order for us. He’s put together an exciting line-up: keeping the Histories in historical order and alternating the Comedies and Tragedies throughout.

There are two goals to the Marathon: create a community of folks to honor the Bard by reading his words aloud and to finish the Marathon by reading the entire canon without stopping. Anyone can sign-up to read in any play they want. Just come with a positive attitude and an interest in Shakespeare! It’s free to sign up and since we are reading for 86 hours in a row, there is bound to be a time that works for you!

We need YOUR HELP:

We need funders to help us raise money to make this event a reality. Right now, Winnie and Ryan are using their own coffers because they believe in the importance of bringing the words of Shakespeare to as many people as possible. And, to be honest, it’s exciting to be building a community of people in New York who love Shakespeare and are willing to help us reach our goals.

We’ve created an Indiegogo campaign. With Space Rental, staffing, postcards, swag (yes, swag!), etc. It will cost us about $6000 to produce this event. Please join us in making this a reality and donate!!! No amount is too small!

                                 Please Help (or we’ll starve…literally)!

                                                  Love, Winnie & Ryan

story:
Kid Brooklyn Productions is gearing up for its first KB Lab Series in Spring/Summer of 2014 and we can use your help. Following the success of the American Premiere of Unbroken by Alexandra Wood,the World Premiere of WILD by Crystal Skillman, and the World Premiere of The Gin Baby by Sarah Shaefer (co-production with Mermaid Sand Productions) we excited to announce the launch of KB Lab! KB Lab is a series of developmental readings and workshops to aid in the creation of new plays and theatre projects.

When you ask a playwright and/or director what they need for a new play they will say "A PRODUCTION!", you ask what the second thing they need is and they'll say "development". That is what we want to offer with KB Lab, a safe and creative environment to aid in the growth of new plays. This series will give playwrights time in the room with a great director, actors, creative team and no pressure to experiment and further develop (we love that word and use it a lot) the play.

We will kick of the series with two major projects:

-A workshop/reading of Crystal Skillman's beautiful play Another Kind of Love. Crystal is the playwright of WILD (which Kid Brooklyn Productions had the honor to produce the World Premiere of in 2012), as well as GEEK, Cut, Follow, and other amazing plays. Another Kind of Love is a beautiful, raw, and heartbreaking play about family, secrets, and Rock and Roll!!

-A public workshop presentation of Encounters: the la ronde project. In this modern adaptation of Arthur Schnitzler’s play Kid Brooklyn Productions has commissioned ten playwrights to each write part of this theatrical series of encounters between different couplings in modern day New York. The project will have ten days of rehearsal, minimal design elements, and seven fully staged workshop performances. Encounters features the work of playwrights Micheline Auger, Evan F. Caccioppoli, Troy Deutsch, Emily DeVoti, Charlotte Miller, Kristen Palmer, Sarah Shaefer, Crystal Skillman, and Ken Urban. The public workshop will presented June 26 to July 6 at IRT Theater!

We will also present readings of several new plays.

We feel this series fits with our company's mission "Kid Brooklyn Productions’ mission is to create theatrical work that is unique, thought provoking, fearless, relevant, provocative, entertaining, raw, humorous, and honest. We want to create theatre that explores every aspect of the human experience light and dark, heartbreaking and joyful, beautiful and broken. We want to challenge ourselves as artists and break our boundaries in the stories we tell on stage." Your donation will go towards rental of a performance and rehearsal space, hiring of actors, directors, stage managers, technicians, and house staff, basic rehearsal/production costs, marketing and publicity.

We have some amazing perks available (check them out!!) and every little bit helps!

Thank You!!

Kid Brooklyn Productions

story:
For her tenure as the Reigning Queen of Burlesque, Trixie Little is creating a new play that combines the art of burlesque with classic theater in a fuckloric folktale for the ages. Opening March 17th in Baltimore, April 1 in NYC.

The Queen of Everything tells the story of milk maid, Trixie Litttlewurst, who is slave to the demands of a giant Cuckoo Clock and taunted by her shadows, The Nightmares. Until one day, a chance encounter with an old beggar woman launches Trixie on the ultimate heroine’s journey to retrieve the crown that will buy her freedom.

WHAT IT IS

Conceived by a genius group of women, The Queen of Everything is a striking, visual immersion into a charmingly twisted fairy tale landscape of the imagination. Performed with raw physicality to a live original score by the psycho-Mambo band, Gato Loco, the show is a true fusion of physical, visual and traditional storytelling. Starring Trixie Little, Edie Nightcrawler, Georgia Sanford, and directed by Justine Williams.

WHAT WE NEED!

We need $18,000 to make this show. Our work/build space and theater rentals in New York and Baltimore are 50% of our budget alone. The rest of our budget is going to fund an original score with an incredible band and set and costume builds by a creative team assembled from the New York performance community. Your funds help support:

  • Theater for 9 Performances in NYC and 3 Performances in Baltimore
  • 3 Months of Space Rentals
  • Original Music by Mambo Band, Gato Loco
  • Materials for Sets, Costumes and Props
  • Lighting, Puppeteering and Stage Hands

WE NEED IT NOW! (LIKE REALLY)

The Queen of Everything opens this spring. The theaters are booked, the website is up, our team is hard at work every single day trying to give this show the attention it needs. We need a timely infusion of cash to keep all of the energy and momentum flowing without interruption. We are directly asking you to support the project’s completion in any way you can.  If you believe in innovative new theater, in your queen (Trixie Little), and in art itself, WE NEED YOUR HELP!

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

  • Share the link to this fundraising campaign with your friends! Spread the word!
  • Buy tickets to see the show:  March 17-19 in Baltimore and the first 3 weekends in New York City. Visit queenofeverythingshow.com

THE TEAM

  • Trixie Little (Trixie Littlewurst, Queen of Everything, Creator & Imagineer)
  • Edie Nightcrawler (Nightmare)
  • Georgia Sanford (Nightmare)
  • Justine Williams (Director)
  • Sapphire Jones (Producer)
  • Jenny C'est Quoi (Art Director)
  • Boo Bess (Production Coordinator)
  • Cheeky Lane (Set Designer & Prop Master)
  • Elena Delgado (Wardrobe)
  • Juanita Cardenas (Wardrobe)

story:
"And what's my problem? GUESS!"

House, by Daniel MacIvor is a story that I am passionate about. A man on the brink, House explores Victor's life and loss in a one act play. House will appeal to you if you are:

  • Experiencing sadness in any capacity.
  • Wanting a change in your dull, sad life.
  • Want an answer to that one question you can't bring yourself to ask anyone.
  • Are a friend of Caleb Gordon's.

I am Caleb Gordon, artistic producer of Seadreamer, and I have the honour of presenting you with House, a story that I became acquainted with nearly three years ago. We met in my yurt, I read it aloud and wept with it, laughed with it, and eventually gave it a piece of my heart. It needs a brave audience, and some money to get me to The Birds and Stone Theatre in Calgary by February 4th!

What We Need

Theatre is expensive -- the cost of tickets covers nearly one quarter of expenses. we need $1500 to cover the costs of the following:

  • Rights to the show -- the playwright deserves some money for the amazing story he penned.
  • The venue -- The Birds and Stone theatre has been kind enough to give us a discount, but we still need to raise enough money to rent the space.
  • Creative crew -- The Director, Stage Manager, and Designers are all being paid a fee for getting this project off the ground. While they are worth far more than we could ever hope to pay them, we'd still love to give them something worthwhile.
  • The set -- Conrad Belau has some amazing ideas for our set, and we hope to give him the opportunity to create a no-holds-barred design, free of financial worries.

"Art is a lie that makes us realize truth"
-Pablo Picasso

I've been a student of the arts for nearly 7 years. One of the most important things I've learned is that Acting is not using lies to tell the truth. Acting in particular is using truth to tell the Truth.

  • The truth is, I see a lot of sadness. Depression, rage, betrayal -- everyone's got something.
  • The truth is, I see a capacity for hope. We're all pursuing happiness in one form or another. The problem is perspective.
  • The truth is, this is a heartbreaking, heartwarming show about a man who is searching for a home, not just a house. A place where he can feel comfort, joy, and belonging. 
  • It's abstract, 
  • It's messy, 
  • It's hard to understand. 
  • It's easy to connect to. 
  • It's paradoxical.
  • It's intensely intellectual,
  • It's far too close to my reality,
  • And I love it a lot.
By investing your money in my show, you invest in an artist with a message. It's a powerful thing in this day and age. You give me a metaphorical soapbox to stand on top of and shout "HEY I'VE GOT SOMETHING IMPORTANT TO SAY and it's funny and it's sad." 
And then people listen. And then people change. And then we watch them together and smile.

"But what if I fall?"

I'm not gonna lie, I'm scared. I'm scared of failing, of not raising enough money, of my message being misheard, or worse, people hating it (and me). I'm scared we won't be able to do this play justice. House is not an easy play. But it is good. 

And here's the thing: I've got my friends and family working on it with me. It's not just me trying to string all these elements together (Thank God above). It's Shannon Klassen, my best friend. It's my mother and father, accomplished builders. It's Conrad Belau, with his crazy designs that fill me with excitement. It's Nathan Schmidt directing, with his immense understanding of acting as a craft, and his meagre understanding of me over 4 years. It's Brad G. Graham, whom if you've never met, would be pleased to meet you -- he's the best stage manager in Alberta.

My biggest fear is not that I'm going to fail. My biggest fear is that I will succeed.

"I'm strapped for cash, mate!"

I completely understand if you're saving your hard earned money for a ticket at the door ;)

That said, if you cannot donate, if you wouldn't mind sharing this on Facebook with that handy-dandy link down there, that'd be great. AND

Mention me to your friends! Gather them all and bring them out to see my show!


House runs February 4th, 5th and 6th at the Birds and Stone Theatre on 16th Ave N.

Street Address: 1703 1 St NW, Unitarian Church of Calgary

story:
'Journey' is an overused, overly-sentimental word in our cultural lexicon, BUT, used in its proper context, I can think of none other to describe the making of my documentary theater play, THE HAZE. 

When I first began this project in 2012, I naively thought I would be doing what I do best: writing and creating theater. What I have learned in this corporate run, commercially sales! sales! sales! based economy is that I - the playwright, actor, and activist - must raise the production money myself. 

In raising development funding for THE HAZE, I've been very fortunate to find sympathetic benefactors who have donated without attaching any political strings. But given where money trickles down from these days, these philanthropists are rare, and tracking them down is probably the hardest part of making theater and, frankly, not the kind of work I ever saw myself doing - I suppose I preferred simply to do the job I know best - writing and performing.

But I added this job responsibility to my resume and I kept at it.

THE HAZE is finally a completed piece and had a 12 date run at American Conservatory Theater in San Francisco last September 2014. 

It is one of the rare works in The American Theater that has actually created marked legislative change around the story it tells. 

The story it tells is legit(not some hollywood or media sensationalized story); and although I can't speak for others' experiences, it is a nod to the countless women whose rape investigations have been and are still being mishandled or ignored entirely at the hands of our country's police departments. 

THE HAZE bravely shines a light on the total systemic failure (our culture, our government, our media) that exists in our country around the crime of rape. 

And it does this in 60 darkly-humored, engaging, illuminating minutes. 

So without further ado, I present that cliche moment that you all know is coming on these crowdfunding sites -- "The ASK"!

I met survivor and activist, Meaghan Ybos about a year ago. She has been through hell and back and continues to agitate against and expose a corrupt Memphis Police Department. She, like me, is demanding that the MPD and the rest of our country's police departments  REFORM their entire system when it comes to rape investigative and prosecution protocol.  In 2014, she wrote, lobbied for, and galvanized public support for a bill to remove the statute of limitations for rape in Tennessee. (At the time of Ybos' rape, the SOL was 15 years; police apparently did not investigate her case or utilize her rape evidence kit until 9 years after her attack.)  In April 2014, the Tennessee legislature unanimously approved the bill, removing the statute of limitations for rape. She is a modern day warrior with respect to the very same issues THE HAZE addresses and I am so lucky to have such a fierce ally  to team up with.

Meaghan and I have teamed up to co-produce THE HAZE for "VDAY" week in Memphis. Meaghan will also be doing a highly informative talkback after the show that is not to be missed. 

Date TBA. 

The very fair sum of money we are raising will cover these costs:

1) Administrative pre-planning time - Meaghan and Heather

2) Fundraising outreach - Meaghan and Heather

3) Marketing Production/Ticket Sales - Meaghan

4) Tech and Lighting Rehearsals - Heather

5) Pre-Memphis rehearsals + Dress Rehearsal - Heather

6) Performance - Heather

7) Talkback - Meaghan and Heather

8) Travel and Incidental Expenses 

This is where you come in to help bring THE HAZE to Memphis for "VDAY".

Meaghan and I are grateful for any donation you make. 

For this you'll have made a vital contribution to a play and a talkback whose disclosure and warning are, we believe, urgently needed. 

It will also allow us to grow our work. 

We're hopeful that you agree. 

Thank you for your support and see you at showtime!

She is a modern day warrior with respect to the very same issues THE HAZE addresses and I am so lucky to have such a fierce ally  to team up with.Meaghan and I have teamed up to co-produce THE HAZE for "VDAY" week in Memphis. Meaghan will also be doing a highly informative talkback after the show that is not to be missed. Date TBA. The very fair sum of money we are raising will cover these costs:1) Administrative pre-planning time - Meaghan and Heather2) Fundraising outreach - Meaghan and Heather3) Marketing Production/Ticket Sales - Meaghan4) Tech and Lighting Rehearsals - Heather5) Pre-Memphis rehearsals + Dress Rehearsal - Heather6) Performance - Heather7) Talkback - Meaghan and Heather8) Travel and Incidental Expenses This is where you come in to help bring THE HAZE to Memphis for "VDAY".Meaghan and I are grateful for any donation you make. For this you'll have made a vital contribution to a play and a talkback whose disclosure and warning are, we believe, urgently needed. It will also allow us to grow our work. We're hopeful that you agree. Thank you for your support and see you at showtime!

story: Perpetual Motion Dance has been accepted into the 2015 Houston Fringe Festival with our original concert Fault Line but we need your help getting there! The Fringe Festival provides a discounted venue and theater technicians, however the cost of getting our dancers, equipment and sets to Houston is very high. Performing at the Houston Fringe is a great opportunity for Perpetual Motion to reach a new audience, expand our community and share Fault Line which we have worked incredibly hard on. Any donations small or large are greatly appreciated!

story:
Summary

It's been over ten years since Tacoma has had a local, professional, theater company...

The wait is over!!

Here comes Tacoma Actors Repertory Theatre!

  • Tacoma Actors Repertory Theatre (TART) will not only bring an engaging new voice to Tacoma Theatre, it will also expand what “Theatre” means in the community. It will embrace music and dance and a wide variety of live performance. It will seek to draw audience members into their own experience of theatre, one that will be entertaining and rewarding.

What We Need & What You Get

  • PAUL ALLEN!!!! You can do this from pocket change!!!! Until we get Paul's attention, we need ONLY - stressing ONLY - $50,000 - in grassroots increments. Some guy got that for making and eating a sandwich, and this is far more valuable and worthwhile.
  • We are raising $50,000 to help cover the initial costs of leasing and modifying a venue to suit our unique needs, renting or purchasing sound and lighting equipment, seating, purchasing production rights, and hiring designers, technicians, actors and other staff.
  • Depending on your donation level, we show our appreciation with everything from a complimentary ticket to a premiere season show to a full package that includes your name in every show program, your name on a custom seat plaque, discounts for education classes, invitations to private dress rehearsals and receptions, Donor Concierge services, private after-show receptions with the artists, and even your named billed as co-producer for a show that you sponsor. See our list of perks for full details.
  • Even if something occurs that causes us to fall short of our goal, rest assured that your contribution will go directly to the product you see on stage. Your funds will always go directly to your TART production.

The Impact

Your contribution to this campaign will help change the artistic landscape of Tacoma:

  • Every significant study of arts impact on a community has produced the same results: an uptick in educational levels, increased community value with the addition of cultural assets, broader attraction to people outside the community to visit to attend arts events, and even increased business and personal incomes. Arts do not solely bring in arts dollars in ticket prices; surrounding and ancillary businesses benefit from the expanded customer base, particularly nearby food establishments and retail shops - not to mention parking fees. Yes, one small theater company can evince a significant impact.
  • There has been no professional theater company local to Tacoma since 2004! TART will fill this unique void with high-quality productions.
  • While initially, many positions will be filled with volunteer workers, TART's business plan includes development of a broad range of full and part-time employment positions, from box office personnel and ushers to office staff to outside sales and special event planners to building and shop maintenance to education instructors and outreach, and not forgetting theatrical directors, designers, musicians and actors. TART's goal is to fill these positions with as many Tacoma and South Sound locals as are qualified. We want to keep dedicated workers of the area here with their expertise and skills
  • Tacoma Actors Repertory Theater aims to provide involving entertainment plus education and event services within a comfortable, relaxed environment, open to all comers in a fully accessible location.

Risks & Challenges

  • Virtually any era and location presents business challenges. The Staff and Board of Directors for Tacoma Actors Repertory Theater are broadly knowledgeable of SHOW and BUSINESS. Note the larger word. TART is well aware that without firm business footing and management, there can be only limited show. By addressing planning and potential issues well in advance, and working with established local business associations including Tacoma Space Works and Tacoma Chamber of Commerce, we can assess risks and correct course before they grow into problems.
  • In Las Vegas, Nevada, a city well known for its entertainment offerings, Jen created Greenhouse Productions and successfully produced shows in small (60 seats), medium (200 seats) and large (1100 seats) venues from Off-Off-Broadway scale all the way through full Broadway scale productions. She hopes to bring the same level of success to TART and Tacoma, beginning with this intimate, unique 99-Seat venue with the goal of growing a significant regional professional theater.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute financially, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Get the TART word out! Post the link to the TART IndieGoGo page everywhere you have access. Theater IS communication, so help TART communicate every way you can. Tell your barista. Tell your co-workers. Tell your friends. Tell random people on the street!  And use the Indiegogo share tools! And, if you happen to encounter Paul Allen... Don't hesitate to tell him to get in touch.


Special Thanks To:

Jen Jidov

Reesa Nelson

Gina Kegel

Blue Melon Productions

Terese Cuff

Sean Begley

Imogen Love

Derek Sanders

Amy Shephard

Byron Tidwell

Gloria Tidwell

Spaceworks Tacoma

Heather Joy

Gabriel Brown

story:
YoungCastle Theatre Collective

YoungCastle Theatre Collective began in 2016 with the idea that there should be no bounds to theatrical creativity. Founding artists Rebecca Anne Muhleman and Hannah Polaski wanted to share that belief with the community and thought who better to go on a crazy creative journey than young people! Since 2016 we and the newly formed board (comprised of youth ages 16-20) have created and produced numerous shows, workshops and concerts to benefit local charities. Now we would like to ask for your help to produce full length work, starting with their summer show, Grave Myth-Takes.  

This campaign will help us fund the venue, costuming, prop, sound design, make-up and set costs for our August show, Grave Myth-Take, but will also allow us to plan and implement a 2017-2018 season. You see, we want to be a resource for young people who have the passion and desire for story telling, performance and art, but we also want to contribute and be an outlet for all disciplines of visual and performance art in our community. We want to create connections with people. We want to inspire people to chase their dreams. And we want to offer a safe and welcoming home for young artists to express themselves and to see their art resonate within society. 

But all of that, unfortunately takes funding. Nearly $1000 of our goal will go directly to fund Grave Myth-Takes in August. That breaks down to:

$750 to rent Art Works (www.artworksrichmond.com) for 3 nights

$100 for costumes and make-up

$100 for set dressing and display of the original visual art that is being CUSTOM made by local youth artists for the show

And the remainder will go to sundry things like printing and promotional needs.

The second $1000 will enable us to create a costume storage, pay dedicated talent, and will help us secure rehearsal and performance venues for our 2018 mainstage season. 

What You Get

We are SO grateful for any donations, big or small!

$5 donations will receive a cool, limited edition YoungCastle button!

$10 donations will receive a signed picture of the cast of Grave Myth-Takes, and a button!

$25 donations will receive a voucher for a complimentary ticket for any night of Grave Myth-Takes, and a button!

$50 donations will receive a behind the scenes look at Grave Myth-Takes, including a private look at fight call, and the make-up and costuming that brings the show to life! And you'll get a button!

$100 donations or more will receive a piece of art that was CUSTOM made for the show! And of course a button!

The Impact

Your donation to YoungCastle's campaign is so appreciated! It will impact the artistic and creative dreams of dozens of teens in the central Virginia area by giving a safe place for them to express, collaborate, create and connect. It will show them that their opinions, and their messages are important and deserve a voice. It will also help us to reach out to the community and to show them that the meaning of art is truth, connection and love.

Other Ways You Can Help

We can not thank you enough for considering our campaign, but we know that not everyone is in a place to give financially! No donation is too small, and donations of time and connection are SUPER valuable! If you are able, please consider SHARING this campaign with others who might be interested! Facebook, Twitter, Insta, Snapchat---We NEED help getting the word out about our mission! And if you want to drop by our Facebook page, @YCTheatreCollective, or visit our Instagram page, @yctheatre, and say hi, get info, connect with us or just check out or pics---We WELCOME you!

Thank you so much again!

Most Sincerely-Rebecca, Managing Director of YoungCastle Theatre Collective
