story:
Summary

 

 Logan Narayanasamy, 29, Independent Dance Artiste/Choreographer

Dance Experience:

     15 Years

Dance forte: 

   Hip Hop

   Krump

   Introductory to contemporary

Have been performing Commercially for shows in Singapore in the Indian Community. 

  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you. 

Campaign Motive: To achieve the desired amount of fund to travel to Europe, Poland and to cover the accomodation for the stay throughout the competition.

 

Importance Campaign: To help an Independent Artiste grow not only as a Dance performer but also as a Choreographer. This competition will add to my experience. Through this experience I can also connect with fellow dancers from around the world and share not only our knowledge of Arts but also the culture. 

Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Your contribution will help build the local talent in Singapore and will pave ways for younger Artist to follow their passion and seek recognition worldwide.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you. $3500 USD for flight and accomadation.

 

  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal:   Even partial funds will be directed for this cause as I am determined to compete for this Event.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Who we are! 

Hi there! I’m Liz Flemming, the founder and producing artistic director of Out of the Box Theatrics. I’m here to tell you how you can support this unique, Off-Broadway theater company; but first, let me explain what we’re all about! Diversity has been, and continues to be, one of the biggest issues in the theatrical community. Artists of different races and ethnicities; artists with disabilities; artists whose voices need to be heard, but rarely get the chance to speak out. After working for five years professionally as an actor and witnessing this firsthand, I decided that I needed to do something to help shape the future of the industry I love. So, two years ago, with this in mind, I founded Out of the Box Theatrics. Committed to the principles of diversity and challenging our audiences with site-specific works, we are proud to embark on our second season! We will be kicking things off with Master Harold… and the Boys being performed at Alice's Tea Cup!

This campaign is unbelievably important. As a not-for-profit theater company, we rely on your donations to produce our work. We have set a goal here of $2,500 to help fund the costume design, publicity, and prop design of our first production. Master Harold... and the Boys is a stunning, inspiring play, and with your help it is sure to be a success!

What’s in it for you!

$5.00 or more = social media shout out!

$50.00 or more = social media shout out and a program shout out!

$100 or more = social media shout out, program shout out, and a free ticket to Master Harold... and the Boys!

$500 or more = social media shout out, program shout out, and a free season subscription (2 tickets per show)!

$1,000 or more = social media shout out, program shout out, a free season subscription (2 tickets per show), and a meet and greet with the cast of Master Harold... and the Boys (Starring Doug Plaut of Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt)!

 

 

The impact you could make!

Our company is a valuable contributor to the world, and not just because we strive to hire a diverse company regardless of one's ethnicity, race, creed, or physical disability. We make sure that our actors are employed with health and pension so that they are protected by the Actors Equity Association. OOTB promises to put the money you generously donate to good use, and invest every dollar into the productions we mount and the artists we hire. We like to think outside the box, and we hope that you do too! You will not be sorry you donated to us today, and thank you for your support.

www.ootbtheatrics.com

story:
Who We Are:

Marie-Christine Giordano Dance (MCGD) is a Brooklyn based dance company. In celebration of its 15th anniversary, the company is developing a new evening-length work to premiere at BAM Fisher on June 2nd and 3rd, 2017. MCGD is a non for profit (501)(c)(3) and your donation is tax-deductible to the full extent provided by law.

Giordano has developed her own technique over the years, based on principles of modern dance and ballet that she values. It strives to develop a powerful core in dancers by strengthening the muscles of the trunk, granting them the freedom to explore the full potential of their physical and artistic expression.

"Ms. Giordano is clearly a choreographer committed to constructing a personal dance vocabulary.”  -Gia Kourlas, The New York Times.

Building on our continual outreach to the community we serve, prior to our BAM premiere we will present excerpts of our work in progress followed by a Q&A session to multiple Brooklyn public schools. Additionally, we will offer them discounted and free tickets to the BAM Fisher event. 

The Work:

Our society and the Earth are at a crossroad. We face questions that may be difficult to answer and challenges that seem overwhelming. For all that, there remains the transformative power of the breath, the mystery and exhilaration of energy in motion and being alive now.

Where Your Support Goes: 

It goes without saying that the impact of your support is invaluable.

Your donation will be used to contribute to:

Dancer Pay: This project will provide an opportunity for seven dancers to perform professionally at BAM. Some are recent graduates of B.A. or B.F.A. programs at universities and will thus make their stage debut. With your support, the project will provide a unique opportunity for these young dancers to grow artistically. The training of the cast for this project is thorough and precise, and requires extreme dedication and hours for the dancers to master its sound principles and technique. Since the  artists are devoting so much of their time, it is vital we provide them with compensation.   

Free & Discounted Tickets for Students: Our work seeks to engage our community. With your help, we can provide public school students tickets.  It is our hope that the work will inspire these young attendees and demonstrate to them how discipline, perseverance, resilience and love leads to an artistically relevant and satisfying end, and your support lends a helping hand. 

Technical Fees: Your support will help us literally make it to the theatre! Rehearsal space fees, costumes, lighting designer, transportation of ourselves and materials, you will help ensure we get to the stage. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help:

We value your donations, but you can also contribute by spreading the word through social media. Please share this campaign with your friends and colleagues. Stay connected with our activities by liking our Facebook page. If you live in New York, we look forward to seeing you at our show at BAM Fisher!

Giordano has developed her own technique over the years, based on principles of modern dance and ballet that she values. It strives to develop a powerful core in dancers by strengthening the muscles of the trunk, granting them the freedom to explore the full potential of their physical and artistic expression.
"Ms. Giordano is clearly a choreographer committed to constructing a personal dance vocabulary.”  -Gia Kourlas, The New York Times.
Building on our continual outreach to the community we serve, prior to our BAM premiere we will present excerpts of our work in progress followed by a Q&A session to multiple Brooklyn public schools. Additionally, we will offer them discounted and free tickets to the BAM Fisher event. 
The Work:
Our society and the Earth are at a crossroad. We face questions that may be difficult to answer and challenges that seem overwhelming. For all that, there remains the transformative power of the breath, the mystery and exhilaration of energy in motion and being alive now.
Where Your Support Goes: 
It goes without saying that the impact of your support is invaluable.
Your donation will be used to contribute to:
Dancer Pay: This project will provide an opportunity for seven dancers to perform professionally at BAM. Some are recent graduates of B.A. or B.F.A. programs at universities and will thus make their stage debut. With your support, the project will provide a unique opportunity for these young dancers to grow artistically. The training of the cast for this project is thorough and precise, and requires extreme dedication and hours for the dancers to master its sound principles and technique. Since the  artists are devoting so much of their time, it is vital we provide them with compensation.   
Free & Discounted Tickets for Students: Our work seeks to engage our community. With your help, we can provide public school students tickets.  It is our hope that the work will inspire these young attendees and demonstrate to them how discipline, perseverance, resilience and love leads to an artistically relevant and satisfying end, and your support lends a helping hand. 
Technical Fees: Your support will help us literally make it to the theatre! Rehearsal space fees, costumes, lighting designer, transportation of ourselves and materials, you will help ensure we get to the stage. 
 
Other Ways You Can Help:
We value your donations, but you can also contribute by spreading the word through social media. Please share this campaign with your friends and colleagues. Stay connected with our activities by liking our Facebook page. If you live in New York, we look forward to seeing you at our show at BAM Fisher!

story:
Right now, we face the worst refugee crisis since World War II. Yet our national conversation about it is paralyzed – caught between overwhelming statistics of misery on one side, and nativist fear-mongering on the other. Maybe the only way to escape this paralysis is through stories that can connect us to the crisis’s human dimensions. 

Director Jessica Bauman has been developing “Arden/Everywhere” through research, workshops and outreach to refugee communities since early 2015. She has directed a workshop for New Feet Productions, a Drama League “Rough Draft” residency, and a retreat at the Holes in the Wall Collective. Her work with refugee communities in New York includes teaching drama workshops at Catholic Charities, the Arab American Association of New York, the International Center, and at the IRC’s Refugee Youth Summer Academy. In May 2016, she taught a two-week theater workshop with 40 refugees at Kakuma Refugee Camp in Kenya through international NGO Film Aid. In the fall of 2016, she began a collaboration with Baruch Performing Arts Center, teaching a Workshop for Immigrant Actors to train possible cast members for a full production.

We believe that it is crucial that this story be told by a diverse company, for a diverse audience, including both traditional theatergoers, and immigrants and former refugees. Our cast includes actors from nine different countries. Rich with non-verbal storytelling, music and the international language of soccer, this production will actively welcome audiences unfamiliar with the play. We have spent months reaching out to communities whose experiences resonate with the story we are telling – engaging in conversation, teaching workshops to introduce the play and its themes, enticing their members to join us at the show.

In collaboration with The Portal Project and Baruch College we will also open The Portal before and after most performances to expand our audience’s experience beyond the walls of the theater. What is the Portal Project?  When you enter a special space called a Portal – in our case, an inflatable gold tent! – you are linked via live-stream on a huge screen to a Portal somewhere else in the world, allowing you to connect in the most immediate and human terms with someone in a refugee community. Ask what they did that afternoon; tell jokes; talk about music or food or the play you just saw. 

Every dollar we raise is a dollar we do not have to charge for a ticket. Contributions will support access to audiences regularly unable to attend performances because of language or economic barriers. Your donation will support:

  • Subsidized tickets for audiences otherwise unable to attend due to economic barriers.
  • Production and curation efforts with The Portal Project to facilitate connections through the Portal in other countries and states.
  • Translation of programs, and other information about the production for non-native English speakers.

MAKE A CONTRIBUTION TODAY TO HELP US REACH OUR $10,000 GOAL!

“As reimagined by Ms. Bauman, this story of exiles in love and in conflict becomes a meditation on immigrants and refugees today…an approach that might well have warmed the heart of that prescient champion of multiculturalism in the arts – Joseph Papp.”

- Ben Brantley
The New York Times

story:
HERE WE ARE NOW, ENTERTAINERS... 

What is 13th Grade?

13th Grade is an original musical comedy about a bunch of kids in community college, during the year 1998, who are struggling with finding love and growing up. We're a part of the 2017 Hollywood Fringe Festival!

  • 13th Grade was created by two friends from the East Coast: Dan Testa and Pamela Eberhardt and it's being produced by two friends on the West coast: Emily Clark and Pamela Eberhardt.
  • This campaign hopes to raise money so that we can make sure that 13th Grade not only survives the Hollywood Fringe Festival, but that it also thrives in it. "Survive" and "Thrive" rhyme. Just a little taste of the lyrical genius you'll hear in 13th Grade.
  • Donating to this campaign will ensure that 13th Grade will provide its audiences with the best show it possibly could and it will help continue to make The Unknown Artists and Ruckus Rockwell reputable groups of entertaining excellence. 

Our Needs, Your Wants

WHEN WE'RE NOT WITH YOU WE LOSE OUR MINDS,  GIVE US A SIGN.....

  • US: Fringe Registration, Space Rental, Insurance, Equity Fees, Advertising, Cast, Crew, Sound, Printed materials...
  • YOU: Fun Perks, listed to the Right of the campaign-------->
  • YOU: Helping a bunch of responsible musical theatre nerds achieve a dream.

Who THE HECK are We?

WE SING THE SONGS THAT REMIND US OF THE GOOD TIMES, WE SING THE SONGS THAT REMIND US OF THE BEST TIMES

Emily Clark and Pamela Eberhardt met in New York in 2006 and started a theatre Company called The Unknown Artists in 2007. Their premiere show was called "It's About Time" (Now titled "Right Together, Left Together") and since then, under the Unknown Artists name, they created a play reading group called Play Club which has branches in New Orleans, Los Angeles and New York. While Emily continued the build of The Unknown Artists out west, Pam developed Ruckus Rockwell ( a playground for artists) which works on both coasts! Through Film, comedy and theatre, Ruckus Rockwell has been the brain behind several successful events over the years including: Drunk Sing Thrus, I Spit on your Podcast and a new VIP cold reading group called Ruckus Readers.

Dan Testa and Pamela Eberhardt met in New York in 2008 and have not stopped laughing since. His band "Basement View" inspired an original musical comedy that Pam wrote, brilliantly titled "Basement View." This collaboration was fated to reoccur with 13th Grade.

Risky Risks & Challenges

WE TRY TO HIDE IT SO THAT NO ONE KNOWS, BUT I GUESS IT SHOWS...

It's tough when you're one theatre show out of a thousand that's just tryin' to make it in Hollywood. It's challenging to stand out above the crowd. We know that if people got the chance to see 13th Grade, they'd get to see something unique and fun, nostalgic and catchy .

Funding is always a hurdle for any project, especially theatre because it often costs more to make than it brings in. But our passion for it is SO real. It's hard to put a price on that. But we do. And it's $13.

Other Ways You Can Help

THIS IS HOW WE DO IT....

  • Tweeting the indiegogo link
  • Instagramming
  • Facebook Sharing
  • Private Messaging (We find this to be the MOST effective)
  • Blog it!
  • Bling it!
  • Mmm Bop it!

13th Grade is SOMETHING UNPREDICTABLE, BUT IN THE END IS RIGHT. WE HOPE YOU HAD THE TIME OF YOUR LIFE...

story:
What we're all about.

Optic Theatre was founded to give more opportunity to women within the arts without writing a play specifically for women or revising a play and gender swapping the roles. At the end of the day we are all human; raw, messy, caring, beautiful humans. ​We want to make theatre that is both challenging and exhilarating to perform. Stories that come from our guts and our impulses. 

Beautiful Little Fools is a unique piece exploring how media can manipulate the human mind. In todays turbulent times this couldn't be more relevant.

As you may know, producing  a play can prove to be very expensive so we are aiming to raise £1350. This just about covers venue higher and set. With your help we will be able to make this visually and audibly stunning  for you guys. We have such an incredibly talented cast and creative team who are putting their heart and soul into making this production the best it can be. Your donation will be of immense support towards their hard work.

We have created some perks as a way of saying a massive thank you in supporting the work we do.

As well as donating you can also contribute to our production by:

•BUY A TICKET: http://thecockpit.org.uk/show/beautiful_little_...

•FOLLOW US: Twitter https://twitter.com/OpticTheatre, Instagram @optictheatre

•LIKE: Our facebook page https://www.facebook.com/OpticTheatre/

•SPREAD THE WORD: Share this campaign on facebook and tell your friends. 

•WEBSITE: Have a cheeky scroll https://www.optictheatre.co.uk/

story:
Short Summary

  • I am a graduate of the Writing Seminars (Creative Writing) and Theatre Arts & Studies programs at Johns Hopkins University, where I also was the president of the student-written theater group Witness Theater. As a theater-person out in the world in search of a stage, I am constantly being reminded that there is nothing like the theater to bring people together and share stories of our lives.
  • Sharing stories with an audience is very important in my household: my wife, Michelle -- a poetry MFA candidate -- and I are both trained actors, improvisers and writers. We read Robert Frost to each other at home and argue over aesthetics and value and everything else about art after leaving any venue (in a museum, a cinema, a theater), sometimes agreeing and often not...
  • I've tried my hand at other disciplines (fiction, humor writing, filmmaking), but theater is my thing. It's what I'm good at and what I have the most passion about. Human moments and stories played out right in front of an in-person audience -- we're the ones that say it to their faces! It's exhilarating to start my own company, doubling-down on the theater and how important it is in my life and how vital an art form it is to a community.
  • Nothing is more important to me than to present credible, honest work that is engaging, exciting, funny (!) and true--in short, work that is a thoughtful and truthful reflection of life.
  • I've been fortunate enough to be a part of the community at the Steel City Improv Theater for the past several years where I have been given the opportunity to perform and produce shows on a regular basis. I also served as the Lead Producer for the Fall 2017 Season. I have been overwhelmed with the enthusiasm for this project from my peers and friends there and have been able to bring many of them into the fold for the BSE inaugural production this Spring: Pigeon (3.5).
  • The original ensemble members for the project, each an equal member in the production of Pigeon (3.5), are: Jon David, Elizabeth Hildreth, Jane Hyland, Jeremy Lesifko-Bremer, Michelle Lesifko-Bremer, Emily Naples, and Andrew Yankes.

What We Need & What You Get

  • For this production we have two goals: to put on an awesome, excellent, exciting, funny (!), moving (?) play and  to bring in as large an audience with whom we can to share that experience.
  • We are looking to raise funds for our modest prop, set, and costume needs and our advertising costs, to get the word out about our show and the BSE mission.
  • Whatever level our funding we achieve will help us in these areas. The more that we're able to raise, the greater the impact of the show on the Pittsburgh theater community and BSE's ability to mount more ambitious, original works in the future.
  • We have a number of giving levels that come with some great perks including specials thanks, hanging out at the cast party and -- of course -- merch!

The Impact

  • BSE's goal is to connect with individual people on a local level, both those that are interested in creating theater and those that want to experience it.
  • By contributing to BSE, you're investing in the belief that the theatre is a safe space in which all people can take refuge; that theater is a home and a sanctuary, where we can all drop our daily defenses and indulge in contemplation and introspection.
  • To paraphrase our laureate, of sorts, Robert Frost whose poem ‘Birches,’ gives us our name, it is our mission to take our audience away from earth awhile when things are too much " like a pathless wood" and allow them to come back to it and begin again, with a fresh perspective.

Risks & Challenges

  • We are starting from the ground up. We have no budget, no reputation, and no followers (on social media or otherwise).
  • This is also our first show: we don't know what we can expect.
  • I feel equipped to handle all the unexpected challenges due to my boot-strapping shows into existence for the better part of the past decade.  Some examples:
    • At Hopkins, I directed multiple outdoor Shakespeare productions on the library steps, with every actor playing multiple roles, no budget, and Mother Nature's whims to contend with (aka: that time it rained...).
    • With Witness Theater, I've led multiple entirely-student written, produced, and acted productions.  I have experience in lighting design, set construction, directing, acting, and playwriting that easily transfer to my role here at BSE.   
    • I've created new show concepts at Steel City Improv Theater over the past two years that have gone from relative obscurity to reliably bankable, including Just a F@cking Improv Show and my work with my beloved improv team The Deep End.
  • I've also put together a great team of collaborators with a variety of experiences to help me along the way.  By investing in BSE, you're not just investing in me--you're investing in all of them, too.  You can count on the entire ensemble to help make this company and our inaugural production a success.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • You can help us in so many ways without giving to the campaign:
    • Share the Indiegogo link, like our Facebook page, and/or join our mailing list by contacting us at birchswingerensemble@gmail.com!
    • Help us with costumes, props, and set construction.  If you're interested, email us at birchswingerensemble@gmail.com!
    • Visit our new website at www.birchswingerensemble.com
    • Come see our inaugural production at Steel City Improv Theater May 24th--May 27th!  Check our Facebook page for details about when tickets go on sale, directions to the theater, and parking.

At Hopkins, I directed multiple outdoor Shakespeare productions on the library steps, with every actor playing multiple roles, no budget, and Mother Nature's whims to contend with (aka: that time it rained...).
With Witness Theater, I've led multiple entirely-student written, produced, and acted productions.  I have experience in lighting design, set construction, directing, acting, and playwriting that easily transfer to my role here at BSE.   
I've created new show concepts at Steel City Improv Theater over the past two years that have gone from relative obscurity to reliably bankable, including Just a F@cking Improv Show and my work with my beloved improv team The Deep End.


I've also put together a great team of collaborators with a variety of experiences to help me along the way.  By investing in BSE, you're not just investing in me--you're investing in all of them, too.  You can count on the entire ensemble to help make this company and our inaugural production a success.


Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:
You can help us in so many ways without giving to the campaign:
Share the Indiegogo link, like our Facebook page, and/or join our mailing list by contacting us at birchswingerensemble@gmail.com!
Help us with costumes, props, and set construction.  If you're interested, email us at birchswingerensemble@gmail.com!
Visit our new website at www.birchswingerensemble.com

Come see our inaugural production at Steel City Improv Theater May 24th--May 27th!  Check our Facebook page for details about when tickets go on sale, directions to the theater, and parking.

story:
About Inda

I'm a writer. It's taken me some time to say that confidently, but it's true. Dammit.

I'm also a wife, mother of two, part-time waitress, and full-time graduate student. I decided almost a few years ago that in order  to pursue writing as a career, I needed to learn more of the craft and legitimize my credentials so that calling myself a writer didn't just sound & feel like a pipe dream. I applied to, and got accepted at University of Southern California's School of Dramatic Arts. I'm 2/3 of the way to my MFA in Dramatic Writing and I'm a Teaching Assistance there as well.

One of the many amazing opportunities for graduate playwrights is the Intiman Theatre's Emerging Artist Program. It's "designed to prepare a diverse group of theatre makers for a successful future in the industry." At the encouragement of my professors, I applied. I submitted one of my plays — Black Super Hero Magic Mama — and received an overwhelmingly positive response to the play and an invitation to train, work and "emerge" at this Summer's Intiman EAP! This is a huge opportunity to study in masterclasses, collaborate, and network with other emerging artists and theatre professionals. It is an opportunity to further develop my play (which has recently won three other development opportunities), and to introduce my work to the Seattle theatre industry.  

Why I Need Your Help

Well, all that sounds perfect. Except, Intiman is in Seattle, WA, and the program is 7 weeks long. I live in Northridge, CA, where I wait tables part time. I need to get to Seattle, fund living there for that month and a half, and maybe eat something. And wash my clothes.

About Intiman

From the Intiman site, here's info on this incredible 7-week program:

This summer 20-30 Emerging Artists (including actors, directors, writers, stage managers, and producers) will participate in workshops and masterclasses led by distinguished theatre professionals, receive guidance and mentorship from experts in their field, collaborate with peer Emerging Artists, and gain exposure and connection to the inter-workings of Intiman Theatre. This year’s selected Emerging Artists will also create a showcase that features and celebrates great American playwrights who also happen to be black women.

Last year’s “emergers” are working with Intiman, Seattle Repertory Theatre, Village Theatre, ACT, 5th Ave, Book-It Repertory Theatre, Seattle Musical Theatre, ArtsWest, Annex Theatre, Taproot, Tacoma Musical Playhouse, Storybook Theatre, D.A.S.H. Center for the Arts, Akropolis Performance Lab, Yellow Fish, The Horse In Motion, The Upfront Theatre, and more.

The program – IEAP –  runs June 27 through August 12, and is a great way to get a few steps closer to becoming part of the Intiman Theatre “family” and consideration for future festivals. 

Emerging Artist Program goals include:

1) Recruiting a diverse pool of candidates based on talent and potential. In the spirit of Intiman’s mission to “produce theatre that is relevant to our time and as diverse as the community in which we live,” and to be a more community-engaged professional theatre, the Emerging Artist Program will train a diverse group of talented theatre artists to lead the next generation.

2) Training to prepare artists to work professionally. The Emerging Artist Program will cultivate and train a diverse pool of artists who might not otherwise have access to professional theatre opportunities.

3) Placement within the industry. The final goal of the program is to get participants hired or engaged in future Intiman mainstage productions, or other professional opportunities in Seattle and nationally. This is an ongoing goal with Emerging Artists who successfully graduate IEAP. We want to help you succeed!

Emerging Artists Program graduates will gain measurable and quantifiable skills in their selected area of concentration, and complete the program with increased connectedness to Intiman, other theatres, and the greater Seattle Arts Community. 

What I Need & What You Get

Here's where the money goes once I reach my $2500 goal:

  • $2,000 rent to sublet an apartment
  • $140 transportation from Los Angeles to Seattle
  • $300 meals & groceries
  • $60 laundry & incidentals
  • Perks: If you're in Seattle, you can come see the end-of-program performance! It's free, but I'll make sure you sit with me. Or you can have a  character named after you in my next play!
  • Even if I don't reach my entire goal, any/all funds raised will be used toward the above. Additionally, I might be on a no-fail diet (due to lack of food). I also might be giving handies in a parking lot but don't feel guilty.
  • Did I mention I write comedy? I write comedy. Don't take the last bit seriously. Unless it prompts you to give more money.

Risks & Challenges

I will miss my family immensely. I could go broke. I might be overwhelmed. But I feel like that every time I shop at Ikea. I'll be fine.

Since committing to whole-heartedly following my lifelong dream of being a writer, I've seen doors open up to me that I'd never imagined. I'm banking on this professional development to lead me closer to my ultimate goal of being a produced playwright and a television writer.  I've gotten through the first two of three years of graduate school. I got this!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Help me to get the word out. Tell somebody. Post to your social media.
  • You can use my Indiegogo link: https://igg.com/at/IndaTheWriter

Thank you!
story_txt:
About Inda I'm a writer. It's taken me some time to say that confidently, but it's true. Dammit.
I'm also a wife, mother of two, part-time waitress, and full-time graduate student. I decided almost a few years ago that in order  to pursue writing as a career, I needed to learn more of the craft and legitimize my credentials so that calling myself a writer didn't just sound & feel like a pipe dream. I applied to, and got accepted at University of Southern California's School of Dramatic Arts. I'm 2/3 of the way to my MFA in Dramatic Writing and I'm a Teaching Assistance there as well.
One of the many amazing opportunities for graduate playwrights is the Intiman Theatre's Emerging Artist Program. It's "designed to prepare a diverse group of theatre makers for a successful future in the industry." At the encouragement of my professors, I applied. I submitted one of my plays — Black Super Hero Magic Mama — and received an overwhelmingly positive response to the play and an invitation to train, work and "emerge" at this Summer's Intiman EAP! This is a huge opportunity to study in masterclasses, collaborate, and network with other emerging artists and theatre professionals. It is an opportunity to further develop my play (which has recently won three other development opportunities), and to introduce my work to the Seattle theatre industry.  

Why I Need Your HelpWell, all that sounds perfect. Except, Intiman is in Seattle, WA, and the program is 7 weeks long. I live in Northridge, CA, where I wait tables part time. I need to get to Seattle, fund living there for that month and a half, and maybe eat something. And wash my clothes.
About IntimanFrom the Intiman site, here's info on this incredible 7-week program:
This summer 20-30 Emerging Artists (including actors, directors, writers, stage managers, and producers) will participate in workshops and masterclasses led by distinguished theatre professionals, receive guidance and mentorship from experts in their field, collaborate with peer Emerging Artists, and gain exposure and connection to the inter-workings of Intiman Theatre. This year’s selected Emerging Artists will also create a showcase that features and celebrates great American playwrights who also happen to be black women.

Last year’s “emergers” are working with Intiman, Seattle Repertory Theatre, Village Theatre, ACT, 5th Ave, Book-It Repertory Theatre, Seattle Musical Theatre, ArtsWest, Annex Theatre, Taproot, Tacoma Musical Playhouse, Storybook Theatre, D.A.S.H. Center for the Arts, Akropolis Performance Lab, Yellow Fish, The Horse In Motion, The Upfront Theatre, and more.
The program – IEAP –  runs June 27 through August 12, and is a great way to get a few steps closer to becoming part of the Intiman Theatre “family” and consideration for future festivals. 
Emerging Artist Program goals include:
1) Recruiting a diverse pool of candidates based on talent and potential. In the spirit of Intiman’s mission to “produce theatre that is relevant to our time and as diverse as the community in which we live,” and to be a more community-engaged professional theatre, the Emerging Artist Program will train a diverse group of talented theatre artists to lead the next generation.

$300 meals & groceries
$60 laundry & incidentals Perks: If you're in Seattle, you can come see the end-of-program performance! It's free, but I'll make sure you sit with me. Or you can have a  character named after you in my next play!

Did I mention I write comedy? I write comedy. Don't take the last bit seriously. Unless it prompts you to give more money.

story:
Collective Unconscious Performance is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the purposes of Collective Unconscious Performance must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

WHO WE ARE
Founded by David Hanzal and Katharine Sherman in 2014, Collective Unconscious Performance creates original, multidisciplinary performance works in Minneapolis/St. Paul.

David and Katharine met as graduate students at the University of Iowa’s Theatre Program, through their collaboration in the nationally-recognized Iowa Playwrights’ Workshop. Originally bonding over a mutual love of fairy tales, ancient mythology, autobiographical performance art, glitter, and blood, they began to create work together during their graduate studies.

David and Katharine are now ready to present their first full-length performance work in Minneapolis, which they have been developing together since spring 2013.


WHAT IS YOUR SHOW ABOUT?
Dark fairy tales and puppets collide at love-sick Victor von Valentine’s Cabaret for the Broken-hearted. Directed and conceived by David Hanzal. Written in collaboration with Katharine Sherman, and loosely inspired by the life and stories of Hans Christian Andersen.

This new performance work is a dream about a dreamer. Celebrated storyteller Victor von Valentine secretly morphs his tortured life story and failed love affairs into beautiful and tragic fictions, which he performs exquisitely with his handmade puppets. Accompanied by his whiskey-slinging, side kick Emma the duck, Victor crash lands into the final performance of his world tour. There’s something off about Victor’s performance tonight, and as he weaves his bittersweet tales with his intricate puppets, his stories change shape and the moods shift.

Ice maidens, mermaids, sequins, blood, glitter, red dancing shoes, and a bottomless sea of whiskey: a meditation on isolation, creativity, transformation, and why sometimes it seems we only write with broken hearts.

With your support, this new work will run for a week of performances at the Bryant-Lake Bowl Theater in Minneapolis, MN, in summer 2015.


WHY DO WE NEED YOUR HELP?
Our work is made possible by our generous supporters. Creating visually-driven theatre from scratch in any urban arts community is expensive, and as emerging theatre artists in a new city we rely on charitable contributions for a portion of our funding.

Every penny we receive from you goes directly into bringing our new production to life. We have a lot of work to do before then, so any help you can offer will go a long way.

This is a very ambitious project that is unlike anything that you’ve ever seen before, and if we don’t raise enough money for the production, you never will!


WHAT ARE WE DOING WITH THE MONEY?
While we have self-funded the creation of many of the puppets and masks in this visually-driven production, we still need your support to cover additional production expenses. 

We are asking for $3,000 to help cover the cost of renting rehearsal space, costumes, props, scenery, promoting the show, and paying the performers and designers!

Any donations above and beyond our goal will be used toward our next production, to be presented in 2016.


OUR MISSION
Inspired by the universal human experience found in dreams, fairy tales, myths, and ritual, Collective Unconscious Performance creates original, multi-disciplinary works of theatre that integrates text alongside movement, puppetry, mask work, and music.
Our core artistic values include:
*Pursuing interdisciplinary artistic collaborations
*Promoting non-hierarchical integration of design, movement, text, and music
*Experimenting during the process of creation, juxtaposing multiple genres and performance styles
*Nurturing a process-based work environment
*Creating a spirit of inclusion for all participating artists and viewers

story:
Short Summary

Hi! I'm Katie Atcheson, the writer and producer of the new play, VERANO PLACE - and I’m thrilled to share this play with you!


Thisbe Productions Presents

VERANO PLACE
by Katie Atcheson
directed by Josh Hecht
with Jessica Brown, Bradford Cover, Helen Coxe, Will Dagger, Chet Siegel, Samuel Stricklen and William Sturdivant

1976 is a tough year for Emily. Since moving to California, her academic parents have embraced an open marriage, her only friend digs drugs and sex, and her potential boyfriend is way too old. A play about finding love, getting lost and growing up in the Me Decade.


Performance Schedule:

  • SUN, AUG 16th @ 8:15pm 

  • TUE, AUG 18th @ 2:00pm 

  • FR, AUG 21st @ 7:00pm

  • SUN, AUG 23rd @ 12:00pm

  • TUE, AUG 25th @ 5:15pm


Location:  

Venue #10: THE KRAINE THEATER

85 East 4th Street (btw Bowery & 2nd Avenue)


I grew up in the 70's in a very unconventional family. In the era’s newfound spirit of openness, Dad (who was gay) and Mom (who was hungry for adventure) decided to have an open relationship, and they both invited boyfriends to live in the house with us. My hip parents took us to nude beaches, had us fix drinks at their cocktail parties and (on the advice of a psychologist) introduced us to marijuana. I was 13.
People have always told me, “Katie,write about this!” After putting it off for a few decades, I finally did - in VERANO PLACE… but I secretly figured no one would relate. Imagine my surprise when this play was selected for a professional staged reading as part of ESPA*Drills at Primary Stages and received a hugely enthusiastic response from the audience. We did another reading at Ensemble Studio Theatre… and received another dy-no-mite response from the sold out crowd. Holy cow! I learned there are a lot of us 70's kids out there (and a lot of people with their own wacky families) and I realized I had to keep working on it. I dreamed that one day my theatrical baby would have a full production.

And now that day has come!

VERANO PLACE has been selected to premiere in the esteemed New York International Fringe Festival (FringeNYC) this August!

It’s the perfect venue to launch this play. Edgy, eclectic and exciting, FringeNYC is the largest multi-arts festival in North America, with more than 200 companies (selected from over 800 entries) from all over the world performing for 16 days in more than 20 venues.  We will be given 5 performance dates at the East Village    99-seat Kraine Theater between August 14th – 30th. This festival guarantees us reviews and we’ll be doing everything we can to attract pre-festival press and attention from theatre industry. Previous FringeNYC entries have transferred to regional theaters, off-Broadway and even Broadway. Our dream is to become one of these success stories and see Verano Place in theaters across the country.

All we need is your support.  With your generous financial donations, we can bring this funny and poignant tale to vivid life - in even more vivid 70’s polyester costumes - and give it a chance to take flight! We literally cannot do this without you!

Why We Need Your Help

While acceptance into FringeNYC is an honor and comes with amazing supports like a fantastic venue and far greater visibility than we could ever achieve on our own, the actual nuts and bolts producing of the show falls to each company.

And producing theater in New York City is expensive, as you can imagine. Even with the tightest of budgets, to do this play justice we need to raise money for:

• 3 Weeks of Rehearsal Space 
• Great 70's costumes for 7 actors
• Stipends for 12 artists (including costume, sound, lighting and sets designers, director, actors)
• Stage Manager
• General Manager
• Publicist
• Board Operator
• Set
• Props
• Marketing/Advertising
• Website
• Graphic Design
• Postcards
• Programs
• Script Copying
• Transportation
• Insurance
• Flameproofing
• Festival Fees

The 70’s were the Me Decade, so make your donation today and get yourself featured on our website, program and more. And great news! VERANO PLACE is sponsored by Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts organization, so your donations are all tax-deductible.

The Impact

I believe the timing is perfect for this show. We’re in the age of the "helicopter parent" and "trigger warnings.” It’s startling to see just how much times have changed since the 1970's when some of us (who refuse to admit to our age) were set loose after school to fend for ourselves while Mom and Dad went to a key party. It's no surprise to me that we children of the 70’s became anxious helicopter parents. For all its craziness, though, I believe the lesson of that decade (and my play) is that no matter how “unique" the family, no matter how great our parents' foibles or how unusual their philosophy, if we are loved, we're gonna be okay. No matter what happens in those early years, a whole lot of unforeseen crap is gonna go down in each of our lives. In the end, the secret to happiness (in my humble opinion) is resiliency, forgiveness and love. And I certainly learned that in spades from my colorful family.

I have found that audience members of every age really resonate with this message in the play - and everyone seems to enjoy a lot of laughs along the way.

Your contribution will enable a unique piece of theater to come to life and will give amazing artists the opportunity to practice their craft and bring joy to the masses. Helmed by our Drama Desk Award-winning director Josh Hecht, our cast includes multiple Broadway actors and downtown darlings. A professional actress with off-Broadway credits and a full resume of on-camera commercials myself, I’m also a newly minted playwright who specializes in plays with female protagonists. My work has already been produced or developed by New Georges, the SoHo Playhouse, Naked Angels, Ensemble Studio Theatre, the Axial Theatre, Core Artists Ensemble and more. My first ten-minute play was made into the short film THE DUCK INCIDENT, directed by Emmy Award-winner Barbara Rick.

Thisbe Productions has a track record for successfully bringing women-centered stories to the stage. We had great success in the 2009 Midtown International Theatre Festival when we produced Jennifer Fell Hays' SEAL SONGS, directed by Kathy Gail MacGowan. That play garnered rave reviews, a sold out run and a Best Actress Award nomination for moi, Katie Atcheson. Thisbe Productions also brought IN TRANSIT - written by Matt Hoverman, directed by Padraic Lillis and starring yours truly - to FringeNYC 2006. The production sold out its run and won the Best Playwriting Award.

Other Ways To Help

If you cannot make a financial donation, no problem. If you can share the campaign on social media or recommend the play to your friends, that would be a HUGE help and get some buzz going for the show.

Thank you SO much and hope to see you at the show in August!!

story:
Short Summary

Coming this Fall from a galaxy far, far away is an epic adaptation to one of the most beloved films in sci-fi fantasy history! Come with us aboard the Millennium Falcon and witness Star Wars: A New Hope told through the whimsical wonder of Musical Theater. 

Greetings and welcome to Redwood Theater Co.'s first ever live theater production! To put it simply, we are a bunch of friends who share a passion for all things considered theater and musical. With a good majority of us being college students who are practically head over heels for Star Wars, we typically had the awesome idea of putting on a show that combines our two favorite things in the whole wide galaxy! But to do this we need your help.



What We Need & What You Get

Since our production will be set in an intimate space with limited seating, our funding will be projected at a minimalist realization for the show.

Our goals will be met for our simple budget in terms of Costuming, Props, Settings, Light Fixtures, Rehearsal Time, Followed by equipment for shooting the final production. As our Funding increases the sheer quality of the production increases, for every penny and credit chit goes directly towards the aesthetic, sound, look and feel to the show!

In exchange for your support we have a pretty sweet lineup of rewards and perks for your choosing. Simple donations are a great help as well!


Music? 

We've got it covered! The Musical cast will be singing to an original accompanying soundtrack composed by an open-source media site located here.



The Impact

Ever since the dawn of time, man's constant struggle to search for the ultimate truth in what his purpose in life is: to watch Darth Vader star in his own dance number accompanied by his fleet of Stormtroopers. Seriously though, among the amazing choreography, the dashingly handsome actors and catchy music, Star Wars the Musical is turning out to be the most ambitious and outright fun adventure any of us had ever seen. With your help in contributing, we will be one step closer to this wonderful work becoming a spectacle for all to see!


Risks & Challenges

While this is our first show as a collective company, and we can be flexible in terms of what we use for the production, it would help us so much by having some financial security for the production and the company as a whole. This production is NOT affiliated with LUCASARTS LTD. or any licencing entity affiliated with the STAR WARS licence. 

The productions only purpose is to serve an awesome show parodying Star Wars episode IV, and initially falls under the category "For Funsies."


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word faster than doing the Kessel Run in 12 parsecs! Post to facebook or twitter, tell your friends, tell your parents, tell your theater buddies! If you weren't convinced to donate by this indiegogo, come to our show August 3,5,10,11, and 13 at the Santa Rosa Dance Theater 569 Summerfield Road!
By donating and spreading the word of our indiegogo campaign, you are not only helping the conception of our flagship production, but also giving support to our company's ability to function later this year with our other future production of "12 Angry Men", coming later this year!

Short Summary Coming this Fall from a galaxy far, far away is an epic adaptation to one of the most beloved films in sci-fi fantasy history! Come with us aboard the Millennium Falcon and witness Star Wars: A New Hope told through the whimsical wonder of Musical Theater. 
Greetings and welcome to Redwood Theater Co.'s first ever live theater production! To put it simply, we are a bunch of friends who share a passion for all things considered theater and musical. With a good majority of us being college students who are practically head over heels for Star Wars, we typically had the awesome idea of putting on a show that combines our two favorite things in the whole wide galaxy! But to do this we need your help.


   
What We Need & What You Get Since our production will be set in an intimate space with limited seating, our funding will be projected at a minimalist realization for the show.
Our goals will be met for our simple budget in terms of Costuming, Props, Settings, Light Fixtures, Rehearsal Time, Followed by equipment for shooting the final production. As our Funding increases the sheer quality of the production increases, for every penny and credit chit goes directly towards the aesthetic, sound, look and feel to the show!
In exchange for your support we have a pretty sweet lineup of rewards and perks for your choosing. Simple donations are a great help as well!



Music? 
We've got it covered! The Musical cast will be singing to an original accompanying soundtrack composed by an open-source media site located here.

    
The Impact Ever since the dawn of time, man's constant struggle to search for the ultimate truth in what his purpose in life is: to watch Darth Vader star in his own dance number accompanied by his fleet of Stormtroopers. Seriously though, among the amazing choreography, the dashingly handsome actors and catchy music, Star Wars the Musical is turning out to be the most ambitious and outright fun adventure any of us had ever seen. With your help in contributing, we will be one step closer to this wonderful work becoming a spectacle for all to see!   
Risks & Challenges
While this is our first show as a collective company, and we can be flexible in terms of what we use for the production, it would help us so much by having some financial security for the production and the company as a whole. This production is NOT affiliated with LUCASARTS LTD. or any licencing entity affiliated with the STAR WARS licence. 

The productions only purpose is to serve an awesome show parodying Star Wars episode IV, and initially falls under the category "For Funsies."
   
Other Ways You Can Help
Spread the word faster than doing the Kessel Run in 12 parsecs! Post to facebook or twitter, tell your friends, tell your parents, tell your theater buddies! If you weren't convinced to donate by this indiegogo, come to our show August 3,5,10,11, and 13 at the Santa Rosa Dance Theater 569 Summerfield Road!
By donating and spreading the word of our indiegogo campaign, you are not only helping the conception of our flagship production, but also giving support to our company's ability to function later this year with our other future production of "12 Angry Men", coming later this year!

story:
Who We Are

Act Too Studio is a small, family-run performing arts studio serving the Pioneer Valley.  We offer private and classroom study, workshops, and master classes for students of all ages who wish to pursue excellence in the the areas of voice and acting.  The studio's founders, Bob and Jan Klump, have been training performing artists for over fifty years, and many of their students have gone on to prestigious university programs and professional performing careers.  Joining them is their daughter, Melinda Beasi, a seasoned professional now teaching and coaching full-time, as well as a host of professional guest artists. 

Though we are, first and foremost, a teaching studio, we're now launching our first production: Polly Pen and Peggy Harmon's Goblin Market, adapted from the narrative poem by Christina Rossetti. 

This intimate chamber musical is written for just two characters—sisters Laura and Lizzie—portrayed in our production by students Anna Plummer and Meagan Raker, directed by Melinda Beasi, with choreography by Connie Flachs and musical direction by Lemuel Gurtowsky.  

The script is entirely in verse, and the music has a classical sensibility, appropriate to the poem's victorian setting. It is a challenging, beautiful, and occasionally dark work, filled with rich, vivid language and fantastic imagery that must be evoked solely by its two young actresses and the small musical ensemble.  We're thrilled to be able to work with such fine young performers, and are anxious to match their commitment with equal care and dedication. 

What We Need 

At Act Too Studio, we believe that the arts are vital to the health of our community and all the people in it.  To that end, one of the motivations always driving us has been to keep our services affordable for anyone with the will to move forward in the arts.  This means that we charge only what we need to operate on a very basic level. So when we realized that we wanted to try to offer this unique performance opportunity to Anna and Meagan, we also realized that we'd have to raise money to do it.  

Your donations will help us pay for rights to do the piece, rent performance space, build our small set, acquire period costumes, and pay technical and artistic staff, including the  choreographer, musical director, and musicians to support the talent of these two girls, and to help create something truly beautiful and empowering for them as young performers.

What You Get

While it is difficult to provide incentives beyond heartfelt thanks to contributors outside our local area, those who are able to attend performances can claim VIP reserved seating at the performance of their choice. Performances will be held at PVPA (Pioneer Valley Performing Arts Charter Public School). Further incentives may be forthcoming! 

Beyond incentives, however, what we hope you'll gain from contributing to this project is the satisfaction of not only supporting the arts in a small community like ours, but also providing a unique opportunity for two very promising young artists, whose thoughtful minds and considerable talents are poised to enrich all our lives. 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    We understand that it is not always possible to lend financial support, but if you'd like to help us make this production beautiful, you can help enormously simply by spreading the word!  Share the link to this campaign via email and social media, and help us harness the power of word-of-mouth! We're grateful for every mention!

    Performances: August 9th & 10th at Pioneer Valley Performing Arts Charter Public School.  See our website for details, or join our Facebook event!

story:
Join us as we change the world, one play at a time.

Our campaign to raise $20,000 is ON! For our first season, Quick Silver Theater Company is collaborating with Classics in Color to produce Proof by David Auburn.  In keeping with both theater companies' mission statements, our production is cast with actors of color. We will deliver this contemporary American classic differently from what you've seen before - through an ethnically diverse prism.                                               
                    

Lizan Mitchell and Tyrone Mitchell Henderson 

Co Founders of Quick Silver Theater Company

This coming September, bear witness to this relevant story  conveyed by a dynamic cast, braced by a team of female designers and led by Tony nominated actress 
Johanna Day as she makes her directorial debut. 

                                  



Here's how you can help.  

Your contributions will be used 

in the following ways.

Thanks to everyone who has donated so far.  We really appreciate it.  Your donations have helped us take care of the following BOLD financial concerns.

  • Rights to produce the play 

  • Rental of a rehearsal space for 3 weeks in August

  • Theatre space rental for 2 weeks in September

  • Set building (including lumber costs, carpenter and shop to build)

  • Costumes

  • Props

  • Insurance

  • Director, Actor Salary, Stage Manager and Designer Fees

  • Additional Lighting equipment

  • Marketing: Graphic designer, Posters, Postcards and Programs

  • Transportation of Set, Costumes and Lighting equipment.

  • Any additional funds remaining will stay in Quick Silver Theater Company's account and go toward our 2016 projects which include: Our inaugural Playwrights of Color summit, our QST-Theater Gym and our next production.

Within a flash, life changing moments may occur.

Part of our mission is to generate conversation.  This production of Proof will be a launch point to support our work within the community.  We will change the complexion of the audience at large by diversifying the stories that are being told.

#herestheproof

The biggest way to realize this mission is through our first production. Proof is cast with actors of color, a telltale sign that our rendition of this story is different. The issues - the absence of women in STEM-programmed studies, mental illness and elderly care - are the same, but when the focus lands on an ethnically diverse group, specifically, a woman of color as the protagonist of the story, we up the ante and reflect the mirror back to the audience to face the discrepancy of Women of Color in exclusively male-dominated areas of scholarship. Are we alright with this void? Are we doomed to let our daughters just play with toys, rather than create, design, improve upon and/or invent the next best thing the world has to offer? Let's explore the possibilities together. Donate. Support. See our Proof.

Other Ways You Can Help

In kind donations will be greatly appreciated.  Set pieces, Props, reclaimed wood and transportation are examples of how you can help. Join us for any of our UPCOMING EVENTS leading up to our production of Proof.

story:
PEN, a musical by Leo Schwartz and DC Cathro, is about love at a distance, behind prison bars. The world premiere of this new musical takes place during the Chicago Musical Theatre Festival this August. With a brilliant cast and insightful direction, PEN is sure to be one of the “must-have” tickets for the festival.

The production budget of PEN is $3,000 and we need your assistance to stage this heartfelt story.  You can become a producer at any level. All levels of support have terrific benefits associated with each, and any and all support is encouraged.

Your help will pay the salaries of the cast and crew, cover production costs, and generally enable the show to be mounted.

I hope you will participate and become a Producer of PEN, today.

story:
Short Summary

In 2014, TURN TO FLESH PRODUCTIONS (TTF)  co-sponsored the extended run of MAY VIOLETS SPRING by James Parenti.  Now, TTF is bringing back this exciting new verse play back to NYC for a four week run from September-October 2016...but we need your help to bring women's voices to the stage!

Why Ophelia?  Why Now?

TTF aims to bring True, Good, and Beautiful theatre to life.  We aim to foster plays that will endure, that are universal in scope.  While we're sure May Violets Spring has a long life ahead of it, we're also aware that this time we're playing in 2016 right before a crucial moment in our nation's history.

We are excited to stage the story of a young woman's journey to self-determination.  Far too often, we see our peers struggle with self-esteem, allowing others to dictate their futures, or believing they have no future at all. This play chooses life, in all it's dangerous and dizzying complexity - using gorgeous language - old and new.

Since we are performing the other-side of Hamlet in New York City, it seems only right to hold up a true mirror to nature, and our goal is to cast primarily if not entirely with actors of color.  We also aim to reach out to New York City schools, to encourage young women and men to see themselves on the stage.

What We Need

TTF is committed to producing a high-quality productions, creating vibrant roles for women on-stage and off, with new plays written in classical styles.  We hold to a "people first" business model: which means that every choice we make is geared towards creating a positive experience for those behind the scenes and in the audience.  However, to do that, we need your help!

  • $10,000 - 4 Weeks Performance Space
  • $1750 - Crew & Creative Stipends
  • $1750 - Actors' Stipends
  • $1500 - Lights, Sets, Costumes
  • $1500 - Transportation, Labor
  • $1000 - 3 Weeks Rehearsal Space
  • $1000 - Publicity
  • $1000 - Indiegogo and Fractured Atlas Dues
  • $500 - Scripts, Printing, Overhead

What You Get

We have many exciting perks for you - from tickets, to couplets, to dinners with the playwright himself!  Check them out and pick your perk today!

Other Ways You Can Help

Want to help out?  You can boost the signal by sharing this link!

TTF is a sponsored project under Fractured Atlas, and all donations made are tax deductible.

A Word From Our Playwright

Everyone has a relationship with Hamlet.  It's one of the most studied, most produced, and (arguably) best pieces of English theatrical literature we have.  Shakespeare's done such incredible work presenting one of the most fully-realized depictions of the human psyche in the title character. But Hamlet's dominance of his play leaves only so much room for the other characters in his life- characters which, I believe, have just as much at stake as he does.

In my own study of Hamlet, I became excited and frustrated by Ophelia's place in the story and in the world of Denmark. What was her relationship with Hamlet like? How much did she know about the Ghost and its accusations? What did she see that drove her mad?

And so she shared the soliloquies. Lines were cut and re-assigned so that they became conversations: Ophelia talking Hamlet into bating the King with a play, the two of them debating the nature of mortality, and so on. And once she had this new life, her story became more interesting to me than his. It quickly became very clear that Ophelia was the heroine of a new story running parallel to Hamlet's.

The completed text of the play is a collage of Hamlet, my own verse, and a number of other plays in the canon: The Winter's Tale, Twelfth Night, Richard II, Othello, King Lear, The Tempest, Love's Labour's Lost, Romeo and Juliet, All's Well That Ends Well, and Cymbeline, to name a few. Lovers of Shakespeare will find the words of their favorite plays echoed here, finding new and rich resonance from being placed in a new context.

Finally, it's my hope that the piece flows seamlessly and stands alone as a completely new piece of theatre, which tells the story of a young woman fighting to make her own place in the world.

- James Parenti

TURN TO FLESH PRODUCTIONS is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of TURN TO FLESH PRODUCTIONS  must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Following our incredibly successful production of Catch Me If You Can last spring, Tisch New Theatre (TNT) will mount another cross-departmental, cross-school musical for a one- weekend engagement in The Grand Hall this November, with this year’s show selection being Sondheim's Company.

Over the next few weeks, we intend to bring the NYU community together in an unprecedented way by bridging the gap between the many schools and departments within the university. Developing a cross-school musical of this size will give students, regardless of their field of study, the opportunity to exercise their passion for the arts with other students they would not normally interact with. West Side Story marked a great change in the way NYU students can collaborate together on a project with the cast containing students from four of NYU's schools.

The collaboration that happens when performers of these different backgrounds come together is something truly outstanding, with every single person bringing something completely unique to the process. This year, we have taken that idea of cross-school collaboration and have attempted to maximize its full potential, with students from six of NYU’s schools being represented in our cast and on our production team.

We truly want to make this the production that students can get behind and be proud of. We believe that the NYU community is ready for a project of this caliber to be a yearly tradition, and we are eager to share this with the NYU community this November.



Tisch New Theatre (TNT) was born out of a pressing need for a participatory theatre outlet for all NYU students. After successfully meeting that need, TNT has become the premiere student theatre organization at NYU. It has established itself as an avenue for students to work in all facets of the theater: performance, management, direction, production, and other technical and design aspects. With an ongoing relationship alongside the NYU Skirball Center, TNT recently produced the 2009 production of Marc Blitzstein's The Cradle Will Rock and the 2011 production of Leonard Bernstein's West Side Story. 

Last spring, TNT brought Marc Shaiman and Scott Whitman's Catch Me If You Can back to the New York stage to great acclaim. The production put TNT back on the map, and was even featured on the front page of Broadway.com. 

Now under the leadership of producer Jason Arnold and director/choreographer Marc Anthony Ferre, TNT is committed to developing ambitious work intended to entertain, inspire, and unite the artistic efforts of the Tisch community with the entire NYU student body.

story:
THE PROJECT

Salty Brine's Spectacular Living Record Collection Cabaret brings audiences brand new cabaret shows every month, crafted lovingly from the track lists of popular music's most iconic albums.  Each month, a different creative team brings its talents to the project and we work together to build a compelling new piece, incorporating dynamic musical arrangements along with dazzlingly hand-crafted costumes and props.  The series, which has been called "highly addictive" by TimeOut New York, began in 2015 and has produced 8 shows to date.

Now in our second year running, we are so excited to continue the magic and share our cabaret creations with you.  We have a whole lineup of mind-blowing shows coming your way this year, using some of your favorite albums as inspiration and featuring some of New York City's brightest musicians, designers and directors. We can't wait to show you what we have in store.  But we need your help getting there.

Your contribution to our campaign will go directly toward funding production costs for the second season of Salty Brine's Spectacular Living Record Collection Cabaret, and will help ensure the future of one of downtown New York's most ambitious cabaret series.  Your contribution will allow Salty and the countless artists that he works with every month to continue honing their craft while creating explosive new music theater.  

Please support our project today and become part of the Spectacular Living Record Collection family.  


THE TEAM

Salty Brine (Creator/Performer) is a New York-based actor, playwright, and cabaret artist that Time Out New York has called “the love child of a Paul Lynde, Liza Minnelli and Joel Grey in Cabaret threeway”. NY Credits: Clown Bar (Pipeline, The Box), How Did I Get Here? (Bowery Arts & Science), Vera; Or The Nihilists (HERE), Shannon Foy (Bowery Arts & Science), The Poor Of New York (Connelly Theater), Backstage At Horror Drag (Animals, Incubator Arts Project), Thanksgiving! A! Pageant! (Ars Nova), The Infernal Machine (CSV Cultural Center), Straight Talk (Dixon Place), Taylor Mac’s The Lily's Revenge (HERE), Oh The Horror! (Naked Angels). Regional: The Baltimore Waltz (Cape Rep), Dead From New York (Diversionary Theatre). He is co-creator (with Justin Levine) of the vaudeville duo Pepper 'n Sam (Ars Nova, Joe's Pub). Salty is currently a member of Pipeline Theatre Company’s 2015 Playlab, a resident cabaret artist at The Red Room, and faculty, Playwrights Horizons Theater School, NYU. 

Reed Whitney (Producer) is an independent creative producer working in theater, cabaret and comedy. He serves as the Producing Director for Theater Reconstruction Ensemble, and is currently producing Rhinbecca, NY, his fifth show with the company.  He has also produced work at Ars Nova, Dixon Place, HERE, Joe's Pub and Walkerspace.



THE NUMBERS

Through the generous support of our donors and other fundraising efforts, we have been able to cover a significant portion of our production costs for the year ahead. We need your help to cover the final stretch of funding for our upcoming season.

In order to keep Salty Brine's Spectacular Living Record Collection going for its second year in a row, we must raise a minimum of $5,000:

  • $750 - Costumes
  • $750 - Props
  • $3500 - Music Rehearsal Space




RISKS & CHALLENGES

Unexpected hiccups come with the territory of producing cabaret, but the show must go on!  Whether it's a lighting issue, a missing costume piece, a delayed musician or a prop that gets lost in the mail, Salty Brine's Spectacular Living Record Collection Cabaret is prepared to tackle setbacks in the creative process.  With eight full cabaret shows already under our belt, we are confident that we can bring the series to new heights in 2016. 


The Spectacular Living Record Collection Cabaret is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-­profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of The Spectacular Living Record Collection Cabaret must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.
story_txt:
THE PROJECT
Salty Brine's Spectacular Living Record Collection Cabaret brings audiences brand new cabaret shows every month, crafted lovingly from the track lists of popular music's most iconic albums.  Each month, a different creative team brings its talents to the project and we work together to build a compelling new piece, incorporating dynamic musical arrangements along with dazzlingly hand-crafted costumes and props.  The series, which has been called "highly addictive" by TimeOut New York, began in 2015 and has produced 8 shows to date.
Now in our second year running, we are so
excited to continue the magic and share our cabaret creations with you.  We have a whole lineup of mind-blowing shows coming your way this year, using some of your favorite albums as inspiration and featuring some of New York City's brightest musicians, designers and directors. We can't wait to show you what we have in store.  But we need your help getting there.
Your contribution to our campaign will go directly toward funding production costs for the second season of Salty Brine's Spectacular Living Record Collection Cabaret, and will help ensure the future of one of downtown New York's most ambitious cabaret series.  Your contribution will allow Salty and the countless artists that he works with every month to continue honing their craft while creating explosive new music theater.  
Please support our project today and become part of the Spectacular Living Record Collection family.  






   THE TEAM Salty Brine (Creator/Performer) is a New York-based actor, playwright, and cabaret artist that Time Out New York has called “the love child of a Paul Lynde, Liza Minnelli and Joel Grey in Cabaret threeway”. NY Credits: Clown Bar (Pipeline, The Box), How Did I Get Here? (Bowery Arts & Science), Vera; Or The Nihilists (HERE), Shannon Foy (Bowery Arts & Science), The Poor Of New York (Connelly Theater), Backstage At Horror Drag (Animals, Incubator Arts Project), Thanksgiving! A! Pageant! (Ars Nova), The Infernal Machine (CSV Cultural Center), Straight Talk (Dixon Place), Taylor Mac’s The Lily's Revenge (HERE), Oh The Horror! (Naked Angels). Regional: The Baltimore Waltz (Cape Rep), Dead From New York (Diversionary Theatre). He is co-creator (with Justin Levine) of the vaudeville duo Pepper 'n Sam (Ars Nova, Joe's Pub). Salty is currently a member of Pipeline Theatre Company’s 2015 Playlab, a resident cabaret artist at The Red Room, and faculty, Playwrights Horizons Theater School, NYU. 

Reed Whitney (Producer) is an independent creative producer working in theater, cabaret and comedy. He serves as the Producing Director for Theater Reconstruction Ensemble, and is currently producing Rhinbecca, NY, his fifth show with the company.  He has also produced work at Ars Nova, Dixon Place, HERE, Joe's Pub and Walkerspace.
