story:
THE BEGINNING
In 2013, Birds on a Wire Dance Theatre debuted its first work, Falling: Public Spaces and Private Thoughts at the Performance Garage in Fairmount, Philadelphia.  The work featured five dancers, an original sound design, original costume design, and original lighting design.  We worked together for several months, playing and experimenting, developing as an ensemble, and building all the little pieces to form a cohesive whole.  Over 250 people witnessed Birds on a Wire's first work, and the response we got was overwhelming!  Since then, we've begun to develop and refine our programs and our vision for the company.  We're ready to take the next steps in growth and achievement, and we need your support to take flight!



OUR PLAN FOR NEXT YEAR (AND WHAT YOU WOULD BE SUPPORTING!)
We believe really strongly in the power of dance to communicate, to express, and to move people.  We value collaborating with artists of different mediums.  We love being part of the powerful and supportive Philadelphia dance community.  We think it's important to create opportunities for Philadelphia dance artists to learn from each other, work together, and make the dance scene even stronger.  We believe that dance is intrinsically -- that is, by its very nature -- accessible and because of this, we consider artist-audience dialogue an integral part of the creation of new and relevant danceworks.

Administratively, we are committed to sustainability AND accountability.  We want you to know what you're investing in!  We've developed a season budget that projects 
  • earned income of 30% 
  • foundational support of 20%, and 
  • contributed income (THAT'S WHERE YOU COME IN!) of 40% 
  • with an additional 10% raised in in-kind donations and event income.
That means, we're counting on the support of individuals (like you!) to make things happen!  We figure if you're willing to support us with your hard-earned dollars, it probably means we're doing something right (or just that you like us a lot, which is also okay by us!).


With these beliefs at our core, here is how we envision our third season.  With your help, we can make all of these programs happen!
  1. HATCH: A ten month long program focused on serving emerging choreographers in developing and presenting new dance works. HATCH provides the technical resources, contacts, networking, and production support so new dance artists can spread their wings!  
    Total Program Cost: $6,217
  2. Dance Flight: Dance Flight brings together a half-dozen instructors for a full-day dance workshop, so dancers can sample the techniques and styles of several of Philly's best dance teachers. Consolidated into a single day, Dance Flight is a unique opportunity for professional Philly dancers to gather, get in shape, and be inspired.  We like to say it's about being moved and getting moving!
    Total Program Cost: $645 
  3. Works in Development: Birds on a Wire is constantly experimenting with and developing new dance works and evaluating them for production.  We work year-round with dancers, designers, and collaborators.  
    Total Program Cost: $4,000
  4. An Ode to Something - a new dance film  In May of 2014, Birds on a Wire presented  An Ode to Something - a work-in-progress performance that took viewers through a moving, musical, perspective-shifting tour of our rehearsal space, the Performance Garage.  Birds on a Wire is currently preparing to adapt the work into a dance film with the help of filmographer Meredith Nutting.
    Total Program Cost: $2,695
  5. Company Classes: Before rehearsals, company dancers must warm-up to prevent injury and continue to develop technique.  Birds on a Wire will host open company classes that will employ educators in the Philly area and allow local artists to participate.
    Total Program Cost: $960
Then, of course, there's everything else!  While Birds on a Wire is entirely volunteer-run, we still have expenses like...general liability insurance, website hosting, postage, membership fees, and fundraising expenses.  Your donations also help support the not-so-fun but entirely necessary costs of being a responsible, efficient, and most importantly, effective company.
Total FUNraising Cost: $1,325
Total Admin/Overhead Cost: $1,433
Birds on a Wire Dance Theatre 2016 Total Operating Budget: $17,275

IN AN EGGSHELL

Maybe you came to see our first HATCH, an evening of new dance works by female emerging artists.  Maybe you saw our work-in-progress site-specific traveling performance An Ode to Something.  Maybe you saw us Dance in Public Spaces.  Maybe you rocked out with us as we danced to the cover band On a Sunday performing Radiohead's Hail to the Thief.  Maybe you saw Artistic Director Melissa Cameron dance a duet with her (in utero!) Bubba in our evening of duets From Our Living Room.  Maybe you're a professional dancer and joined us for an intense day of sampling contemporary dance classes at Dance Flight in June.  Maybe you've been to all of our events since summer of 2013.  Maybe you've never seen any of our work and you just like what we stand for.  Whatever your experience, we hope you'll contribute to the next stage of Birds on a Wire Dance Theatre.  Help feed our developing programs!  We'd love for you to fly with us. 

Birds on a Wire Dance Theatre is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Birds on a Wire Dance Theatre must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
The Midwest premiere of 35MM: A Musical Exhibition opens May 7th at the Goodman Community Center. The songs and stories in the show were written based on photographs. We've had photographers take photos based on the music and ideas.  Works of art capture moments and memories, and this season that's what MTM is focused on. 

This year MTM is very focused on financial accessibility. Two of our six performances of 35MM will be "Pay What You Can" performances, meaning any amount is welcomed and appreciated.   While we're keeping prices affordable and including these low-cost initiatives, we are still compensating every artist for their time and talent.   Your contribution of any size to this campaign helps make that possible! 

We want to make it quick and easy for all of our patrons to help make 35MM a big success, so we're running this campaign. Every dollar counts when you make a donation to MTM!  

 A $10 contribution to 35MM via this campaign gets you a personalized photo thank you posted to our Facebook page and Twitter. And not just any photo.  We're MTM, so we'll go out and find something weird and awesome just for you! 

Think $10 can't help? Here are a few things $10 gets us: 

  • 50-100 postcards
  • 10 programs
  • A day of use for the Goodman Center's projector, which will display the 35MM photographs during the show. 
  • A few props
...and more! 
Thanks for supporting the weird stuff!

story:
Short Summary

Geeksdanz will once again scare the pants off their audiences with Manifestations II: Ambitions Running Cold, at The Maker Theater (formerly Steel City Improv Theater) on November 1st, 2014. Two performances of the (PG-13) show at 7 and 9:30 pm comprise the second year of Geeksdanz's collaboration between dance and storytelling.

Featuring a whole new selection of ghost stories told live by our featured storyteller Stas' Ziolkowski, Manifestations II melds dance, music and story to create an intensely atmospheric performance that will chill your blood and make your skin crawl. From a cottage on the beach to a mansion in the country, from a cursed monkey paw to a ghostly biker gang, the dancers weave through Stas's words and your deepest fears come to life as the theater fills with sound and movement.

Geeksdanz presented an excerpt of this new work at the Three Rivers Storytelling Festival on Saturday, August 9th, as part of the festival's Ghost Stories concert.  The excerpt was very well-received and many people were eager to see more. So now, we need your help to present the whole concert!

Manifestations II: Ambitions Running Cold

November 1, 2014

7:00 pm  and 9:30 pm 

(PG-13)

presented at The Maker Theater (formerly Steel City Improv Theater)

5950 Ellsworth Avenue

Pittsburgh, PA 15232

What We Need & What You Get

Most of the funding for this project goes towards paying the artists.  We can't put on this show without our dancers and our spectacular storyteller, and we can't pay them without you!

Some of the funding will go towards promotional materials such as posters, flyers, etc.  We need your help to get the word out and fill the seats!

If we surpass our goal, our artists will receive a larger, more appropriate stipend, and we as a company will be better able to continue creating and presenting even more new works!

In return, you get to choose from a host of goodies.  From a coffee date with the artistic director or the storyteller to a poster signed by the whole cast, there's sure to be something you'd like in the list over there.  Go ahead, take your pick!

If you've donated to a previous campaign you'll notice that we're once again offering the official Geeksdanz T-Shirt, included in all perks above the $25 level.  As we did last year we have another shirt option that's exclusive to this show, so if you don't feel the need to have an entire rainbow of Geeksdanz shirts, please be sure to mention that you want the Manifestations shirt instead!

The Impact

Geeksdanz’s mission is to introduce dance to audiences that would not normally be drawn to it, and to illustrate the universality of dance as a means of emotional expression. Geeksdanz achieves this by systematically applying the context of dance to an enormous variety of topics and interests, and targeting performances towards the specific audiences who share those interests.

In April of 2013, we presented Challenge Mode, a concert about video games, to an audience comprised of both dance patrons and gamers.  As part of our mission, we presented an excerpt of Challenge Mode at Tekkoshocon X-2, a Japanese Pop Culture convention, and Artistic Director Ellen Deutsch led a discussion panel titled "An Artist's Views on the Games-As-Art Debate." Through these events, we encouraged attendees to think critically about the difficulty of defining art, and where and how video games might fit into the art world.  

We presented the first edition of Manifestations last year, after also showing an excerpt at the Three Rivers Storytelling Festival.  Our second feature work, "Up to Chance," was a real-time dance interpretation of a live Dungeons and Dragons game, which we presented at the Pittsburgh Fringe Festival in May.  Both of these works continued our mission to introduce dance to other audiences.

Our performance at the 3 Rivers Storytelling Festival sparked interest in our work among the storytelling community, and we're looking forward to an audience of tellers and storytelling enthusiasts in addition to dance patrons.  Your contributions will help us broaden our audience yet again, and encourage even more people to consider dance as an exciting evening's entertainment.  Plus, you get to help us scare the pants off of our audiences!  What could be better?

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute, don't sweat it!  Here are some other ways you can help:

  • Spread the word on facebook, twitter, etc. and make some noise about our campaign!
  • Tell all your friends, especially those who live in Pittsburgh, and encourage them to come see the show!
  • Come to the show yourself!

Come to the show yourself!

story:
We are afraid of what we don't understand. What is hidden in the dark. It’s time to bring mental illness into the spotlight. Sharing our light through storytelling, we can stop the stigma and save lives.

One in four adults and one in five youth in the United States lives with a mental illness in any given year. Yet the culture of our society is to sweep it under the rug and to speak in whispers when discussing mental health disorders.

This stigma prevents people from seeking treatment. Individuals fear discrimination at work, rejection from friends and family, even damage to their reputation - all because of an illness in their brain. We wouldn't be afraid of these consequences if the condition was cancer or diabetes, would we?

We believe this needs to change - and that together, we can do it. 

This Is My Brave - The Show  was born of the idea that no one should be ashamed of talking openly about living with a mental illness. Instead we should be applauded for our bravery by allowing ourselves to be vulnerable in order to help other people know they are not alone. The show simply provides a space for it to happen. 


Last year, This Is My Brave was launched by two passionate mental health advocates, Jennifer Marshall and Anne Marie Ames. Together they reached out to their local community within the Washington, DC metro area to recruit and cast thirteen men and women who were willing to stand up on stage and share their story of life with mental illness through poetry, music or essay. In front of a sold-out, 400 seat theater, we took to the stage on May 18th, 2014 during Mental Health Awareness month to show the world our brave.

The show was a tremendous success.

In the months after the show, Jenn and Anne Marie continued reaching out to the mental health community. This Is My Brave became a 501(c)3 non-profit organization to continue our mission of igniting and actively promoting―through community programs and social media― a positive, supportive national conversation about mental illness for those who live with, or love someone who lives with, a mental illness.

Your tax deductible contributions will allow us to produce a show in the Washington, DC area for a second year, with a whole new cast of courageous truth-tellers, AND the funding will allow teams of volunteers to bring This Is My Brave shows to Boston, Massachusetts and Iowa City, Iowa! 

What We Need & What You Get

Give and you shall receive, right? :)

Our major expenses to produce three shows include:

  • $8000 - Theater rentals in all 3 cities (includes rehearsal time, performance day rental, theater technical staff on the day of the show)
  • $3000 - Printing, marketing & publicity
  • $3500 - Reward fulfillment
  • $1050 - Indiegogo & FirstGiving fees (7% if we meet our goal, 10.75% if not!)
  • TOTAL = $15,550 to produce This Is My Brave shows in 3 US cities in May, 2015

The Perks of Supporting Our Mission

We've lined up some super fun and enticing perks which will be gifted to our generous donors, including (some pictured below):

    • Tickets to the show in May in the city of your choice - reserve yours before they go on sale to the general public! (Remember, we sold out last year!) 

    • Our newly designed This Is My Brave tee-shirts which feature our message:  #BeBrave - Storytelling Saves Lives (our logo in small print is on the back of the shirt just below the shirt collar). Available in a fitted Ladies v-neck style, a Unisex crew-neck style, and a Unisex v-neck style.


  • “Be Brave” bracelets - in 3 styles, and 3 colors.  Show your support for our organization’s mission by wearing your BRAVE!

      • NEW PERK!!! added 11/3/14 - This Is My Brave MAYA Bravelet in Light Blue! Limited Quantities available!

      • Brave Beads - we have our own version of Greek “worry beads” - handmade from Brazilian rainforest Acai beads. Hold or keep these in your pocket for when you’re anxious or scared, to remind you of your strength and bravery.

      • Brave notebooks - for the writers, songwriters and poets out there, a place to craft your story! At 5"x 7" it's small enough to carry with you ― 40-pages of lined paper waiting to be filled with your truth.

      • Sponsorship packages for businesses looking to support us through the purchase of advertising space in our show-day program and the sponsor section of our website.
    So look to your right, find the perk(s) of your choice, and make a tax deductible donation today!  (This Is My Brave, Inc. is recognized by the IRS as a tax-exempt 501(c)3 not-for-profit organization. This Is My Brave's EIN number is 20-8944419 and mailing address is 43300-116 Southern Walk Plaza, #652, Broadlands, VA 20148.)

    The Impact

    This Is My Brave is a theater show like you've never experienced. It allows the audience to put themselves in the shoes of someone who lives with a mental illness - if only for a brief moment ― to experience their struggles and triumphs. You'll walk away with empathy and hope ― and a passion to stop the stigma!  

    Our communities NEED This Is My Brave so that our friends and neighbors, local leaders and educators understand the impact of the stigma around mental illness.

    This Is My Brave gives individuals living with mental illness a platform on which to express themselves, to educate and enlighten, and to heal by sharing their truth. 

    Risks & Challenges

    This is our first growth year. It's our first year as a non-profit organization. We've had a successful year, but to grow, you have to take a leap! Shows in three cities is a leap for us ― a leap we hope is only the beginning. 

    • We have put together a phenomenal team of energetic, giving, passionate volunteers who are dedicated to producing successful shows. 
    • We know we have the ability and talent to do this, the hurdles we face are strictly financial, which is the drive behind this collaborative fundraiser.
    • Our success from year one of This Is My Brave provides us with the experience to do it all again only on a bigger scale with the show's message reaching triple the audience.
    • Our goal is to raise all the funds we need for 3 shows through this campaign, but if we're unable to do that, we will create other means of financing the shows through off-line fundraisers, reaching out for pro-bono services, or good old fashion bartering.  

    Other Ways You Can Help

    We understand if contributing financially isn't in the cards for you right now. There are plenty of other ways you can help! Would you be so kind as to consider:

    • Sharing our campaign via email with your friends and family, telling them why it's important to you
    • Sending out a message on your social networks with our campaign link - Indiegogo has easy-to-use share tools!
    • Tell friends and family at in-person gatherings, share with colleagues at work
    • Post flyers about our campaign in your local library, coffee shops, cafes, anywhere people gather and would see it & potentially donate

    And that's all there is to it.
story_txt:
We are afraid of what we don't understand. What is hidden in the dark. It’s time to bring mental illness into the spotlight. Sharing our light through storytelling, we can stop the stigma and save lives.
One in four adults and one in five youth in the United States lives with a mental illness in any given year. Yet the culture of our society is to sweep it under the rug and to speak in whispers when discussing mental health disorders.
This stigma prevents people from seeking treatment. Individuals fear discrimination at work, rejection from friends and family, even damage to their reputation - all because of an illness in their brain. We wouldn't be afraid of these consequences if the condition was cancer or diabetes, would we?
We believe this needs to change - and that together, we can do it. 
This Is My Brave - The Show  was born of the idea that no one should be ashamed of talking openly about living with a mental illness. Instead we should be applauded for our bravery by allowing ourselves to be vulnerable in order to help other people know they are not alone. The show simply provides a space for it to happen. 

Last year, This Is My Brave was launched by two passionate mental health advocates, Jennifer Marshall and Anne Marie Ames. Together they reached out to their local community within the Washington, DC metro area to recruit and cast thirteen men and women who were willing to stand up on stage and share their story of life with mental illness through poetry, music or essay. In front of a sold-out, 400 seat theater, we took to the stage on May 18th, 2014 during Mental Health Awareness month to show the world our brave.


The show was a tremendous success.


In the months after the show, Jenn and Anne Marie continued reaching out to the mental health community. This Is My Brave became a 501(c)3 non-profit organization to continue our mission of igniting and actively promoting―through community programs and social media― a positive, supportive national conversation about mental illness for those who live with, or love someone who lives with, a mental illness.

Your tax deductible contributions will allow us to produce a show in the Washington, DC area for a second year, with a whole new cast of courageous truth-tellers, AND the funding will allow teams of volunteers to bring This Is My Brave shows to Boston, Massachusetts and Iowa City, Iowa! 


What We Need & What You Get

 Give and you shall receive, right? :)
Our major expenses to produce three shows include:

$8000 - Theater rentals in all 3 cities (includes rehearsal time, performance day rental, theater technical staff on the day of the show)
$3000 - Printing, marketing & publicity
$3500 - Reward fulfillment
$1050 - Indiegogo & FirstGiving fees (7% if we meet our goal, 10.75% if not!)
TOTAL = $15,550 to produce This Is My Brave shows in 3 US cities in May, 2015

“Be Brave” bracelets - in 3 styles, and 3 colors.  Show your support for our organization’s mission by wearing your BRAVE!








NEW PERK!!! added 11/3/14 - This Is My Brave MAYA Bravelet in Light Blue! Limited Quantities available!



Brave Beads - we have our own version of Greek “worry beads” - handmade from Brazilian rainforest Acai beads. Hold or keep these in your pocket for when you’re anxious or scared, to remind you of your strength and bravery.




Brave notebooks - for the writers, songwriters and poets out there, a place to craft your story! At 5"x 7" it's small enough to carry with you ― 40-pages of lined paper waiting to be filled with your truth.


Sponsorship packages for businesses looking to support us through the purchase of advertising space in our show-day program and the sponsor section of our website.

So look to your right, find the perk(s) of your choice, and make a tax deductible donation today!  (This Is My Brave, Inc. is recognized by the IRS as a tax-exempt 501(c)3 not-for-profit organization. This Is My Brave's EIN number is 20-8944419 and mailing address is 43300-116 Southern Walk Plaza, #652, Broadlands, VA 20148.)

Sending out a message on your social networks with our campaign link - Indiegogo has easy-to-use share tools!

story:
Welcome to MMT's fundraising campaign for Sweeney Todd!!! 

Our company has been part of the McMaster community for 32 years and our annual goal is putting together a beautifully crafted musical for family, friends, students and the Hamilton community to attend. We began over the summer and we will be working diligently until February when the show will be performed. We thank you for your time and any contribution you can make to our company's success.

A Letter from the President : What is MMT?

Since 1983, McMaster Musical Theatre (MMT) has been fostering the talents of individuals with a passion for performing arts, not only as actors or actresses, but also as musicians and technicians. Comprised primarily of members from the McMaster University community, but also with those around it, MMT consistently awes audiences with professional grade productions from many dedicated volunteers. in order to continue this trend of high caliber productions, we are seeking donations in whatever you or your business can provide, no matter the size. 
These contributions, whether monetary or otherwise, will be put to good use throughout the entire production to enhance elements such as costuming, makeup, props, and audio-visual technologies, just to name a few. MMT is entering our 32nd season, and we know that it will be a memorable one. As an organization that prides itself on being one  of the longest lasting student-run clubs at McMaster, I would personally like to ensure that this organization continues to make a positive image both within McMaster, as well as Hamilton as a whole. 
Matt Clarke (President, MMT)
For our campaign, we are looking to raise $2,500. This money will go towards costumes, props, set building materials, advertisement and many other technical elements. We have big dreams for this production and every dollar counts towards making it all a reality. If monetary support is not the way you want to go, we also would love any in-kind donations you would be willing to offer! We will happily create a package suited to whatever you can offer. For more information, or to donate, contact: 
Hannah Fuaco (Producer, MMT)
(905) 546 6366 
hannah_fuaco@hotmail.com
or
Matt Clarke (President, MMT)
(905) 484 2161
mmt.exec@gmail.com

The Show: Notes from the Director

Sweeney Todd is about human nature. At least in the sense that it explores 

that it explores very common human emotions and reactions. Now, of course, as with all art (theatre and otherwise) these feelings and reactions are exaggerated; they're made into a larger than life representation of the real world. Through Sweeney Todd, we explore vengeance, fear and obsession. It reminds us to meter our responses in situations like those that Sweeney, Lovett, Judge Turpin, Anthony and Johanna face. 

I can personally guarantee that this show will not only be worth seeing, but worth supporting as well. Our production team has spent the last few months working tirelessly to prepare for the show, even prior to casting. It's a labor of love: we all love working together and we love the idea of creating something bigger than us - an experience that will stay with our actors and the audience alike. 

I hope that you decide to support our efforts. I am eternally grateful for your attention and anything you are willing to do to help. 

Andrea Pohlmann (Director, Sweeney Todd)

    The Sponsorship Levels

    We understand that not every business is alike and there are friends and students that want to help our company during this season. That is why we have created many levels of sponsorship to fit all the types of people that want to donate.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Even if you can't contribute, as a volunteer run and McMaster affiliated company, we rely greatly on the student population and friends to get the word out about  our show. Please share this campaign through any social media platform and let all your friends know we are working hard and looking for support to make this production amazing.

story:
A Quick Summary

 

Welcome to our Indiegogo Campaign!

Imagine Project is a new theatre company dedicated to bringing dynamic stories with modern & relevant messages to young audiences, with a focus on gender equity, diversity and inclusion. #ChildrensTheatre #TYA

We are proud to be LA County's only union theatre dedicated solely to children's programming, and introduce to you our inaugural production of The Tale of Turandot – a multi-media commedia dell’arte experience with puppets.

In our World Premiere Play, this centuries-old story is told specifically from Turandot’s perspective – a tale about a young woman forced to marry before she has a chance to explore the world and herself. Our play focuses on her fight for choice and freedom. On her struggles, dreams and aspirations. We are asking you to contribute to The Tale of Turandot.

Take a look at our perks and give today.

Imagine Project is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Imagine Project must be payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law. 

Be a Part of the Magic!

 

A Detailed Breakdown

 

Imagine Project is a theatre company dedicated to producing theatrical experiences for young audiences. With our inaugural production of The Tale of Turandot, we seek to establish LA County's only union theatre company dedicated solely to children's programming.

#TYA #ChildrensTheatre

FACT: Los Angeles County - home to at least ten million people - does not have a professional union theatre dedicated solely to children's programming.

It’s time to change that! This is why we are asking you to support Imagine Project's first production!

From the beginning, we commit to the following.

  • Telling relevant stories and dynamically engaging with today’s youth, inspiring our young citizens to face life with creativity, insight and courage.
  • Hiring local union talent, and thus creating union workweeks for our artists.
  • Casting and hiring artists that are representative of the diverse population of our city. This includes artists with disabilities.
  • Choosing programming that reflects the voices of the underserved members of our community.

#StoriesThatMatter   #ArtistsShouldBePaid

Imagine Project began as an answer to a request from the members of the Eastern-European diaspora in Los Angeles. Our Founder, Armina LaManna, (who was born in USSR where she also spent much of her childhood) has been asked for several years to recreate their European & Eastern-European childhood traditions, specifically children’s theatre. The latter, including puppet and marionette theatre, was a right of passage for kids growing up in the former USSR, as well as many European countries. This large diaspora is a part of our targeted audience, as we develop this theatre-going tradition for all children in our community.

Take a look at our PERKS and GIVE TODAY!

 

Our Inaugural Production

The Tale of Turandot is inspired by Carlo Gozzi’s play titled Turandot, which itself was based on a short Persian story written by the French orientalist, François Pétis de la Croix. Our new play for young audiences is about 50 minutes long, and is told by actors and puppets together.

(Preliminary Set Design by Tom Buderwitz, USA829)

The story of The Tale of Turandot is a play within a play, starring a traveling commedia dell’arte troupe – the Diamond Patch Players –> Columbina, Arlecchino, Pantalone, Brighella, Isabella & Smeraldina.  

(Preliminary Costume Design by Dianne Graebner, USA829)

The players are joined on stage by three Bunraku-inspired puppets – Turandot, Prince Calaf and the Emperor.

(Preliminary Puppet Design by Aaron Cromie)

The physical world of the play will be realized in part by video-projections creating a multi-media experience.

Check out our Producers and Artists:

  • Co-Producer - Armina LaManna
  • Co-Producer - Alex Zonin
  • Set Designer - Tom Buderwitz (Member USA829)
  • Costumer Designer - Dianne Graebner (Member USA829)
  • Mask & Puppet Designer - Aaron Cromie
  • Writer & Director - Armina LaManna (Member SDC, AEA & DG)

 

The Play

 

In Gozzi’s play and in Puccini’s opera, the princess is portrayed as a cold and heartless young woman whose beauty and brains have no equal. Turandot forces all suitors to solve three riddles, and when they don’t, they pay with their heads. The focus is her coldness and rejection of men.

In our World Premiere Play, the tale is told from Turandot’s perspective – the story of a young woman forced to marry before she has a chance to explore the world and herself. Our play focuses on her fight for choice and freedom. On her struggles and her dreams.

Why this story? By encouraging young children, especially girls, to look at the many opportunities that are available to them in this world, we endeavor to contribute to the gender equity movement and thus the betterment of these kids’ lives.

#GenderEquity #EqualOpportunity

 

What Your Donation Will Pay For

 

This Indiegogo campaign is specifically dedicated to raising money for:

  • the venue costs
  • and the fee of our Mask & Puppet Designer – Aaron Cromie

Our presumptive venue is The ​Colony Theatre in Burbank, CA with whom we worked out a great rate for two and half weeks of space rentals.

We are currently engaged in three fundraising campaigns.

  • This crowdfunding campaign on Indiegogo.
  • We are also currently fundraising by reaching out personally to corporations and individuals to cover artist fees specifically.
  • And we will be holding our company's Inaugural Fundraiser & Gala on August 21st, with the proceeds dedicated to covering production costs. Should you wish to attend the Gala or want more information about it, please email us at imagineprojectca@icloud.com.

 

Why Give to Us

 

Seeing professional live theatre has enormous influence on the way our children interact with each other and the rest of the world. Attending a live theatrical cross-genre experience like The Tale of Turandot is a priceless experience for children. One that we plan to foster as we instill theatre-going traditions in our young audiences. Building not only tomorrow's patrons, but tomorrow's generation of leaders and innovators.

Yes, math and science should and must be skills that we pass down to our children, so that they can engineer and build. But we must also give our children the opportunity to imagine the new things that need to be engineered and built. Theatre does just this. This original form of 3D entertainment inspires young girls and boys to engage in physical play and in role-playing, away from portable screens.

A 2014 study published by the University of Arkansas Department of Education Reform analyzed the impact of high-quality live theatre on students. Findings showed that seeing live plays enhanced students’:

  • literary knowledge 
  • tolerance
  • and empathy

Study after study examines the drastic fall in empathy in today’s young people, compared to their counterparts from the late 1970s. By helping establish a professional theatre dedicated to young audiences, you make an investment not just in the arts, but also in these kids’ and our community’s future.

 

Other Ways of Giving

 

  • Sending out an email blast to your friends and colleagues telling them about our endeavor and asking them to contribute. Personal emails are the best way to get people interested and involved with fundraising.
  • Utilize your social media presence to assist us in spreading the word about Imagine Project and The Tale of Turandot. In fact, Indiegogo makes it easy – simply use the share buttons. When sharing our campaign or our website with your friends and followers on social media, take a moment to specifically tag people who you know would be interested in children’s theatre (e.g., parents, grandparents, teachers).
  • Follow us on Twitter.
  • Like us on Facebook.
  • Visit us at www.imagineprojectca.com.
  • Come see The Tale of Turandot when it goes up!

 

Click That "Back It" Button & Be a Part of the Magic!

This original form of 3D entertainment inspires young girls and boys to engage in physical play and in role-playing, away from portable screens.A 2014 study published by the University of Arkansas Department of Education Reform analyzed the impact of high-quality live theatre on students. Findings showed that seeing live plays enhanced students’:
literary knowledge 
tolerance
and empathy
Study after study examines the drastic fall in empathy in today’s young people, compared to their counterparts from the late 1970s. By helping establish a professional theatre dedicated to young audiences, you make an investment not just in the arts, but also in these kids’ and our community’s future. Other Ways of Giving 
Sending out an email blast to your friends and colleagues telling them about our endeavor and asking them to contribute. Personal emails are the best way to get people interested and involved with fundraising.
Utilize your social media presence to assist us in spreading the word about Imagine Project and The Tale of Turandot. In fact, Indiegogo makes it easy – simply use the share buttons. When sharing our campaign or our website with your friends and followers on social media, take a moment to specifically tag people who you know would be interested in children’s theatre (e.g., parents, grandparents, teachers).
Follow us on Twitter.
Like us on Facebook.
Visit us at www.imagineprojectca.com.
Come see The Tale of Turandot when it goes up!
 Click That "Back It" Button & Be a Part of the Magic!

story:
I wish I’d had some sort of warning or indication of how much The Wall would end up meaning to me when I first heard it in high school. The idea to adapt it into an original stage production had been on my mind for almost a decade. Now in my senior year of college, the decision to go forth with this entirely student-run, extra-curricular, non-profit production of the album that shaped my adolescence and formed the foundations of much of my personal beliefs has been the most cathartic experience of my life.

The Wall isn’t a very literal story. It’s an abstract journey that follows our protagonist Pink, born parallel to the murder of his father by the Nazis during World War II. His childhood in shambles, Pink begins to build a metaphorical wall between himself and what he perceives to be a cruel and heartless world. While there are certainly unfair forces that work against him, his lack of responsibility and his willful neglection eventually trap him behind his wall. The variables he uses to cope – nostalgia, self-pity, and drugs – lead him down a path of extremism resulting in his transformation into the very fascist forces that killed his father in the first place.

The fact is that The Wall is now more relevant than it has ever been since its release in 1979. We want to shout its story and its message from the rooftops, albeit as much as we can with our ramen-noodle student abilities. Nonetheless, all 50+ student cast and crew members working to make this crazy thing happen are doing it for the passion of performance art and their belief in this story of current historical relevance and warning. We’re building a 10’ tall wall. We have a kickass live band. And not to mention some of the greatest singers I’ve ever had the pleasure to know, let alone work with. The amount of work and talent from all corners that’s gone into this thing is beyond anything I could have ever hoped to imagine.

As we approach the performance dates, we just need that little extra fiscal push to be able to afford the best show we can create. Again, this is not for a school project. This is not for grades or for money. This is a group of students who are doing this because of their belief in the project and their passion for its message. Your support will be going towards this type of pure artistic expression.

-Alan Macchiarolo, Director

story:
Our Project

WHO are we? Austin, Courtney and Emma––three actors who have come together to make our dreams of bringing this show to you a reality. 

WHAT is our project? Pizza Man is a play written by Darlene Craviotto, a daringly dark comedy about the female dilemma and what happens when we let our anger get the best of us.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to reach $2,500 to cover our venue cost amongst other fees. As you know, if there's no venue, there's no show. With your contributions, we will be able to put on this hilarious play for you at the beautiful Whitmore Lindley Theater in the heart of North Hollywood's Arts District. 

"What do I get if I contribute?" you may ask. The answer is simple! $5 off your ticket to the show and an honorable mention in our program. In addition, the first 5 people to donate at least $20 get a free pizza courtesy of the cast. 

If we do not reach our goal, our production will have to be postponed and your funds will be saved for a relaunch for early next year.

 

The Impact

WHY should you contribute to our cause?

This show is hilarious. So hilarious in fact, you'll probably cry you'll be laughing so hard. And who doesn't want to see a funny show? But let's dig a little deeper than that: The fact of the matter is, theatre MAKES OUR LIVES BETTER! Why? We'll tell you why:

  • Theatre brings people together- In an age where most of our communication happens in front of a screen, the gathering function of theatre is important, especially now. It's bonding time!
  • Theatre is a sophisticated expression of the basic human need to create meaning- Who doesn't want meaning in their life? 
  • Theatre builds our skills to listen to different points of view and to empathize- It makes you a better human!
  • Theatre contributes to education and literacy- It requires attention, mental shifts, and language skills. It makes you smarter!
  • Theatre influences the way we think and feel about our own lives- It makes us more self aware!   
  • In closing, help us so we can help YOU! We want to make your lives better, and have fun while doing it too. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you're unable to donate, you can still spread the word about this amazing show! Simply by talking about it, you are supporting. Please share our Indiegogo link on every social media outlet you can think of, and come to all of our upcoming fundraising events. There will be parties, prizes, and of course, PIZZA!

story:
ReVisions Play | NYC Summerfest Premiere

By Gur Arie Piepskovitz

The Director has a vision. Good. So does everybody else. With a motley crew of young actors and aging thespians, can he create meaningful theatre in a room bursting with egos, unrequited loves and raging jealousy? 

Following a successful run at Camden People's Theatre in London, Gur Arie Piepskovitz (Writer/Director/Performer) has been selected to bring his show to the prestigious NYC SUMMERFEST, a festival celebrating original full-length, one-act and solo theatre productions, where self-producing is the magic wand that feeds the core of art and creativity. 

About ReVisions:

Re-Visions is a satirical, meta-theatrical play which investigates the power of role-playing in achieving the unrequited and how one alters reality only by perceiving it differently. The piece brings into the ring five different personas, each with its own monstrous ego, who will attempt to mimic reality, enhance it, or sometimes override it completely. And what better setting for this fistfight of conflicting desires than the ultimate enemy of reality- a theatre stage. Through fast- paced dialogues, exaggerated characters and banter, the play observes social issues in a provoking manner, incorporating documentary material with illusion.

Feedback:

A tangled web of perversity, history and the authentic!  - Simon Vincenzi, Arts Admin artistic resident, theatre director.

Extraordinary: funny, original, ridiculous, exhilarating and clever - Hanna Berrigan, theatre director

Curiously unexpected and intriguing - Jessica Ziskind, Programme Assistant, New Contemporaries

Gur Piepskovitz, director of Re-Visions and his team of performers brought to life a challenging and brave new work. This layered and challenging piece raised many questions that engaged the audience to think and seek answers for themselves. I was excited and consistently interested throughout and left wanting more - Craig Leo is an associate puppetry director at War Horse

Our Goal:

Traveling from London to NYC for the ReVisions NY Premiere is thrilling and fantastical! But it's trans-Atlantic and involves some extra cost. We are raising $5000 for these production costs:

  • Professional Stage Manager
  • Rehearsal Space (2 Weeks)
  • Videographer/editing
  • Marketing (printing/shipping posters & programs)
  • Set Design
  • Travel
  • Accommodation

Any donation big or small to make our transatlantic theatre dreams come true is so appreciated. As a gift for your donation, you will be sent a NYC souvenir and hand written letter from the Big Apply.

Thank you for your support,

Gur (Writer/Director) and Ella (Producer)

story:
It's Been One Year of Keeping Live Theatre ALIVE!

On March 16th, 2020, the theatres and renaissance festivals went into lockdown. 

On April 1st we did a show.

The Social Distancing Players was born with the sole mission of keeping live theatre alive - and we have. In our section of the internet, we've managed to stay connected with our audiences and keep theatrical professionals and ren faire actors semi-quasi-gainfully employed.

And we've done it all because of your help.

Over the last year we've done adaptations of your friendly, neighbourhood Shakespeare's ren faire stage shows: 12th Night and the 3 Bears!, Romeo & Juliet: The Flying Implement of Doom Edition!, Julius Caesar: Beware the Ides of March of the Penguins!, The Tempest: A 3-Hour Tour (A 3-Hour Tour)!, Macbeth: Death by Fluffy Kittens!, The Hamlet X-mas in July Special!, Richard: 2 Fast, 2 Furious!, A Midsummer Night's Dream: A Gaye Olde Tyme!, Titus Andronicus: Ya Know - For Kids!, and produced The Importance of Being Earnest and Six Lovers in Florence (and we also did The Hamlet X-mas Special! again, but in the holiday season). 

12 shows. About 50 performers. And all because YOU were there for us, keeping us going in this time of murder hornets and Joe Exotic.

And now we want to celebrate our 1 year anniversary with you.

We're Putting the Band Back Together!

On Wednesday, April 14th, 2021, 1 year and 13 days after the original performance, the Social Distancing Players are performing 12th Night & the 3 Bears: Take 2! - it's (mostly) the same show with the original cast as we had in April of 2020, when we were all thinking that this would be over in 2 weeks, 3 months tops. And we've learned a lot in this last year. We've learned how to light ourselves properly for Zoom. We've learned how to maximize crappy internet connections. And we've learned how to have hope again.

As our performing spaces start to open back up, we're still performing with you here, in THIS venue where you get the best seat in the house, and we're going to keep this going. Maybe not quite as often as before, but the shows will go on(line), because we're here for you just as you've been here for us.

What Do We Need?

We're looking for $1,200. That's $100 each for the professional performers from the theatre and renaissance festival communities who are performing the show for you, and with you. 

That $100 each can buy groceries, or pay for a dental visit, or a phone bill, get your oil changed or your car inspected. It can go towards rent. It helps to keep these performers semi-quasi-gainfully employed.

The Parts Available

One of my favorite parts of theatre is the interactivity it can have with the audience members - in fact, my stage shows are crafted to be able to play WITH the audience, with YOU as the performers. And so FOUR audience members will be able to play "on-stage" with the professional actors in this piece:

  • Baby Bear
  • Mama Bear
  • Sir Toby Belch
  • Sir Andrew Aguecheek

It's a $50 donation to have a part in the show, and only four slots are available - but don't worry! there are other perks, too!

  • $30 gets you a signed copy of the performance script, mailed to your house by May 1.
  • $20 gets you a PDF of the performance script
  • $10 and you can join the cast "backstage" after the show in a private Zoom meeting

Every Little Bit Helps

Even if you can only spare a dollar, it helps. And if you can't spare the change, please share out this campaign.

We've been doing this for a year - and we're still all in this together.

Thank you.

story:
Hi!

 

Aria here, the creator behind POLITICAL MOVEMENT and the choreographer of heart2heart. 

 

This year I am celebrating my company's 5 year anniversary, and it feels really special to mark this milestone. I am currently developing a new work called heart2heart that brings together twelve movement based artists to have conversations, two at a time, about the state of the world. 

 

As you can imagine, it takes a lot of resources to build and present something with twelve artists. So ... I need your help!

 

Tickets for this show are being offered in a Pay What You Can Afford model. I am asking if you will buy your ticket in advance and ... to make the request more enticing, I am adding some fun perks!

 

To book your ticket we will email you and ask what show you would like to attend!

 

Help us sell out  before the show opens so we can rely on the confirmed ticket revenue! We are so lucky to have the production support from Why Not Theatre's RISER project, this means that all of these ticket sales are going towards paying the performers.

 
heart2heart features the intimate and true stories of 12 movement-based artists. Through 6 unscripted duets, heart2heart offers a compassionate dance theatre work that questions how we seek to build relationships across difference, across sameness and across generation. Featuring an ensemble of queer, POC, fat, multilingual, non-binary, differently abled, mothers, teachers, immigrants and all Torontonians, heart2heart marks RISER Project’s first ever programmed dance work!
 

Choreographed by Aria Evans

Created with and performed by:
Tanveer Alam and Angela Sun
Corynne Bisson and Jordan Laffrenier
Michael Caldwell and Liisa Smith
Olivia Croft and Irma Villafuerte
Shay Erlich and Kari Pederson
Karen Kaeja and Sebastian Oreamuno

Dramaturgy by Ximena Huizi
Lighting Design by André du Toit

For RISER Project 2020:
Production Management by Crystal Lee Chettiar
Publicity by Damien Nelson
Produced by Tom Arthur Davis

 
Pay What You Can Afford
$12 = ticket + personalized love note
$20 = ticket + personalized love note + heart2heart or POLITICAL MOVEMENT pin
$35 = ticket + personalized love note + heart2heart or POLITICAL MOVEMENT pin + chocolate or candy bundle
$60 = ticket + personalized love note + heart2heart or POLITICAL MOVEMENT pin + chocolate or candy bundle + special non-alcoholic beverage
 
All of the perks will be available when you come see the show and pick up your ticket at the Theatre Centre.
 
To book your ticket we will email you and ask what show you would like to attend!
 

Performance runs 75 minutes (no intermission)

April 30, 2020 at 7pm (opening)
May 1, 2020 at 7pm
May 2, 2020 at 7pm
May 7, 2020 at 7pm (relaxed performance)
May 8, 2020 at 7pm
May 9, 2020 at 7pm

 

If you aren't able to make it to the show but would still like to support the project I will do everything I can to send you the perks that are ship-able. Sharing this campaign is always welcome and greatly appreciated!
 
If you would like to purchase a ticket in a Pay It Forward context, we would happily offer your seat to someone in need!
 
Join us as we celebrate our five year anniversary! LET's SELL OUT!
 
To book your ticket we will email you and ask what show you would like to attend!

story:
DO YOU LIKE SHAKESPEARE? WE DO!

The Shakespeare Company at UCLA is the only student-run classical theater company on campus. If you have a passion for theater and Shakespeare - as an actor, director, designer, or stage hand - or if you're looking to get involved for the first time, we want you to join.

SCU productions are always free, aimed at providing accessible and exciting productions to the UCLA and greater Los Angeles community. Each year, we put on three to four full-length productions and an annual cabaret-style Evening of Shakespeare. In addition, we are continually increasing our number of student-written new works each year, with productions varying from staged readings to full shows.

WHAT WE DO

Shows! We put on at least one Shakespeare show per quarter. All shows are performed, designed, and directed by students. Students of all majors and backgrounds are welcome to audition and apply to direct or design! Check our Facebook page for announcements about auditions, applications, and other opportunities to get involved.

Workshops! Each quarter, we hold one to two workshops relating to Shakespeare's work and the season's productions; past topics have included stage combat, movement, and verse and speech.

Social Events! We regularly host Shakespeare-themed parties, and other social events for club members. Past events include a party on Shakespeare's Birthday, a Diddy Riese night, a Masquerade Ball, season kickoff parties, and movie nights. Each spring break, the company also takes a field trip to the Oregon Shakespeare Festival in Ashland, Oregon.

WHERE DOES YOUR MONEY GO?

The money raised through this campaign will go to support this season's productions. We use this money to support directors and designers in getting costumes, set pieces, props, lights and sound equipment, and more. Your donation helps us advertise our events to get as many students as possible involved in our productions. Thank you for supporting us!

Each year, we put on three to four full-length productions and an annual cabaret-style Evening of Shakespeare. In addition, we are continually increasing our number of student-written new works each year, with productions varying from staged readings to full shows.WHAT WE DOShows! We put on at least one Shakespeare show per quarter. All shows are performed, designed, and directed by students. Students of all majors and backgrounds are welcome to audition and apply to direct or design! Check our Facebook page for announcements about auditions, applications, and other opportunities to get involved.Workshops! Each quarter, we hold one to two workshops relating to Shakespeare's work and the season's productions; past topics have included stage combat, movement, and verse and speech.Social Events! We regularly host Shakespeare-themed parties, and other social events for club members. Past events include a party on Shakespeare's Birthday, a Diddy Riese night, a Masquerade Ball, season kickoff parties, and movie nights. Each spring break, the company also takes a field trip to the Oregon Shakespeare Festival in Ashland, Oregon.WHERE DOES YOUR MONEY GO?The money raised through this campaign will go to support this season's productions. We use this money to support directors and designers in getting costumes, set pieces, props, lights and sound equipment, and more. Your donation helps us advertise our events to get as many students as possible involved in our productions. Thank you for supporting us!

story:
(VERSION FRANÇAISE SUIT)

The project

Surreal SoReal Theatre, Montréal’s bilingual theatre company, is creating a theatre experience that lets us think deeper about the ongoing occurrences of school shootings.

Madame Catherine prépare sa classe de troisième pour l’irrémédiable (Miss Katelyn’s grade threes prepare for the inevitable) is a story about a young grade three teacher who, obsessed and afraid of the growing violence in the United States, sets out to teach her grade three class how to prepare in the event of a school shooting.

In these frightening times, it is very easily to feel isolated. We want to create a theatre experience that gathers people together to reflect on an urgent and topical subject.

What We Need & What You Get

Our company is looking to raise 2500 dollars to cover the costs of our set design. We are transforming the entire intimate space of Théâtre Prospero in downtown Montréal into a mini classroom, and creating this design isn’t cheap.

Depending on your level of support, you can receive a mention on our website, a poster from the show, or even a couple of free tickets to come see us.

What are we doing here?

It’s pretty simple: Canadian playwright Elena Belyea has created a theatre experience that, for better or for worse, is extremely topical, and a very much needed reflection for audiences everywhere.

If you support Surreal SoReal Theatre and our production, you are making conversations happen. You are creating a sense of hope and conversation for the times we live in.

Other Ways You Can Help

We don’t need very much money to help along our production, and you can help in other ways too: spread the word about the show for any friends you might have in Montreal, check our facebook group and the show trailers at surrealsorealtheatre.ca, and if you know theatre companies in your community who might be interested in this play, get in touch with us!

(FRANÇAIS)

Le théâtre Surreal SoReal, une compagnie bilingue à Montréal, veut créer une expérience théâtrale qui nous fera penser plus profondément à l’effet des fusillades dans des écoles.

Madame Catherine, obsedée par la violence dans les écoles aux Étas Unis, ose à enseigner à ses étudiants, vous le public, comment se préparer pour l’éventualité d’une fusillade dans son école.

C’est facile aujourd’hui d’avoir peur, ou de se sentir isolé. Notre équipe croit vraiment dans la puissance du théâtre, et sa capacité d’unir une communauté ensemble en réflexion autour d’un sujet d’actualité.

Notre compagnie cherche à lever 2500$ pour payer le coût de notre décor: on va transformer la salle intime au théâtre prospero- une petite espace d’environ 50 sièges- en salle de classe! La construction de cette idée sera pas facile, et ça coûte quelque chose!

Dépendant de votre niveau de support, vous pourrez recevoir des beaux cadeaux de notre équipe, comme un mention sur notre siteweb, une affiche de la pièce signé par toute l’équipe, ou même des billets gratuits pour notre spectacle!

C’est quand même simple: écrivaine Elena Belyea a crée une pièce qui, pour le meilleur ou pour le pire, est extrêmement pertinant aujourd’hui. C’est une pièce qui nous donne l’opportunité d’une réflexion profonde et nécessaire pour un public contemporain.

En supportant notre campagne de socio-financement, vous encouragez des conversations par rapport à ce sujet. Vous créez un sens d’espoir pour le monde dans lequel on vie.

 

Nous avons pas besoin de trop trop d’argent pour ce projet, alors même des petites contributions peuvent vraiment nous aider! Il y a aussi d’autres façons que vous pouvez encourager notre projet: parlez-en! Parlez à vos amis de notre spectacle, encouragez-les de regarder à notre siteweb (surrealsorealtheatre.ca) ou notre groupe facebook.

story:
Our Story

 Tut'Zanni is a physical theatre company, which  travels the world performing and teaching workshops. We combine commedia dell'arte, clown, puppetry, music, dance, and other folk arts to create a stunning exploration of imagination and heart.

Our Mission Statement

 Tut'Zanni uses folk arts because they are accessible to everyone, and accessibility is first and foremost in our minds. Tut'Zanni exists to bring people together through performances that they can relate to and feel a part of. By using "people's theatre", we are able to create a feeling of unity or audiences will take with them past the moment the curtains are drawn. We strive to inspire thought and creativity, which we believe makes better communities, better people, and better life.


 

Our Artistic Vision

Tut’Zanni utilizes commedia dell’arte and other forms of physical theater because we believe it is the most accessible to everyone. By using folk art and a “people’s theatre” medium, we create something that all people can relate to, and are able to bring forward ideas and concepts that they can not only easily understand, but feel a part of. It is our vision to create art that can pierce through language barriers, social barriers, and bring people together in a way that will encourage tolerance and understanding in a stronger sense of community.


Our Show

 

 

As our debut show, we believe "Art For Sale" will be the perfect illustration of who we are as a company. It is comprised of 2 basic elements: First, it is a Cabaret-style show, in that there are many small pieces, or “tastes” of our characters attempting to show their own work as artists, whether it be a song, a dance, a magic show or a cartwheel. Secondly, holding it together, is one story revisited throughout, of the characters attempting to put up their own show. Unfortunately, it is finally ready to be shown just as they run out of stage time. 

 

 

This show uses various mask forms, including commedia dell’arte and neutral mask, clown, physical theatre, music, dance, and acrobatics in what will hopefully be a spectacular exploration of heart and expression that illustrates the struggle and satisfaction of being an artist.

 


What We Need

Starting a theatre company is by no means easy, nor is it cheap! Although our dear members have already given their time, effort, and funds out of the goodness of their hearts, we can only do so much on our own. Here is what we are raising funds for this year:

 

 

  • Our first rehearsal session, to build our show- this will be in the spring for about 2 weeks. We will be developing our show, and holding a preview show/fundraising party at the end of the 2 weeks! Entrance will be free, so if you are going to be in the LA area, come see us! For this whole event, we need to raise about $3000.
  • Our actual debut show! We will be performing at the CrisisArt Festival in Tuscany, Italy. We will be arriving a couple weeks early for intensive rehearsals, and possibly even working with a guest assistant director who can help us bring our show to the next level! For this show we need to raise at least $8000.
  • a company mask set of professional commedia masks - this costs about $600
  • various props, costumes, and materials for sets, masks, etc. - we only need about $300 for this. Physical Theatre shows (at least ours) don't have too many fancy sets, and costumes tend to be easily purchased at a thrift store. In fact, we prefer it that way.
  • In the fall, we are hoping to get to the New York International Fringe Festival. Again, we will be arriving to the city ahead of time to further develop our show. For this show we need to raise at least $7000.


In the unfortunate event we do not reach this goal, your generous donations will not go to waste! As you can see,  there are several smaller things we need to get our company going, and every little bit helps. Every dollar graciously given to us will absolutely be helping push us forward!


Other Ways You Can Help

We are starving artists, and if anyone understands not having expendable income, it's us! But it's not just money we need. Please help us out by spreading the word about us. Share us on Facebook, Tweet about us, tell friends and family! People just recognizing our name can go a long way. 


We are so grateful to all of you that love and support us in ALL ways. We are a little company diving into a huge world, but we are determined to succeed. We hope you will come along for the ride, and as we share our hearts with all of you, we hope that you, too, will discover your inner Zanni.

In the fall, we are hoping to get to the New York International Fringe Festival. Again, we will be arriving to the city ahead of time to further develop our show. For this show we need to raise at least $7000.


In the unfortunate event we do not reach this goal, your generous donations will not go to waste! As you can see,  there are several smaller things we need to get our company going, and every little bit helps. Every dollar graciously given to us will absolutely be helping push us forward!



Other Ways You Can Help

We are so grateful to all of you that love and support us in ALL ways. We are a little company diving into a huge world, but we are determined to succeed. We hope you will come along for the ride, and as we share our hearts with all of you, we hope that you, too, will discover your inner Zanni.

story:
OH MY IRMA GOES INTERNATIONAL

a play written & performed by Haley McGee

directed by Alisa Palmer

executive producer Derrick Chua            

as originally produced by Theatre Passe Muraille

original lighting, sound & costume designs by Dave DeGrow, John Gzowski & Cami Koo

 

i'm so glad you're here.

My name is Haley McGee, and I am an emerging Toronto-based writer and actor.  I created a solo show OH MY IRMA.  This campaign is to raise funds to assist me in taking this award-winning, critically acclaimed play on an international tour to Amsterdam, Wirksworth (UK), Moscow, New York City, Kiel (Germany).

 

take a step back. tell me about this play.

"OH MY IRMA is the award-winning solo play by Canadian rising star Haley McGee, dubbed “the next darling of Canadian theatre” (See Magazine).  Directed by Siminovitch Prize Finalist, Chalmers and Dora Award winning director Alisa Palmer, OH MY IRMA sees McGee bring the memorable Mission Bird, a socially inept young woman with an insatiable appetite for connection, to the stage in her hilarious and mesmerizing “tour de force” play.

A comedy with razor teeth, Mission Bird finds herself in front of an audience, defending an unnamable crime which YES, she committed, but it wasn’t her fault.  The story takes macabre turns and Mission Bird’s ardent defense crumbles as she comes closer to revealing to the audience what she’s done - who she’s killed. 

Originating as a five-minute piece at an emerging artist cabaret at Toronto’s legendary Theatre Passe Muraille, OH MY IRMA was presented it to rave reviews and sold-out houses at the Edmonton International Fringe Festival, before its professional debut back at Theatre Passe Muraille. In Toronto it was met again with sold out and performances critical acclaim.

In the fall of 2011 the play was selected to be part of the United Solo Theatre Festival—an international solo show festival in NYC. I went to New York City, and performed OH MY IRMA off-Broadway at Theatre ROW.  It won Best Production of the 77 shows there and has now been invited to festivals around the globe.

I have been invited to perform OH MY IRMA at five festivals in Amsterdam, Wirksworth (UK), New York City, Moscow and Kiel (Germany).  I am emboldened, encouraged and thrilled by the hunger for this play around the globe.

 

the ask

These festivals are full of innovative, sexy, cutting edge new performance.  I am thrilled and honoured to be invited to them with my show.  But as I am an emerging theatre artist, these festivals, though very cool, are not rich, and they don’t cover the costs of my travel nor my living expenses while I’m there. 

I have put together a shoestring budget for a show and tour plan that are as modest and simple as possible.  I will travel alone, billet where possible and pinch pennies at every turn. 

I will be on tour from September 3-November 17, 2012, with performances at festivals in five cities.  My entire budget is $15,000 and those funds will cover travel, accommodation, food on the road, marketing, publicity, promotions, festival fees and technical costs abroad. 

I have applied to our arts councils at the national, provincial and local levels, and am pursuing corporate donations and sponsorships.  With this online campaign my goal is to raise a third of my budget.

I need your help. Financially.  ANYTHING YOU CAN GIVE IS AMAZING.  Check out my perks over there to the right.  It all helps and it's all important and I thank you effusively for even considering it.  (If you can't donate but want to help me out in other ways scroll down the bottom of this page for some suggestions.)

If you donate to the OH MY IRMA tour you are not only supporting me and my work as a Canadian theatre artist abroad but Canada’s reputation in the international theatre scene.  You are contributing to the development of a young voice in Canadian theatre by allowing me to take part of an international conversation with a milieu of the finest theatre artists in the world.  Presenting my work in an international context will make me a stronger artist and give me more to contribute to the arts community in Canada.  And beyond that, you are ensuring that this story keeps getting told.

 

press & praise

"Haley McGee is a fearless, raw young talent.  For those who want to see a promising talent at the beginning of her career, then OH MY IRMA is worth your time."  -Lynn Slotkin, CBC Radio

“Physically, McGee conveys her character’s inner state through constant fidgets, hand wringing, hyperventilation and quick dashes to the back corner to whisper pep-talk mantras.  (Imagine a spazzed-out combination of Napoleon Dynamite, Michael Cera and a crackhead.) The result is always funny on the surface but also evocative of the mental struggles people face everyday.  An adorable, oddball anti-hero, Mission Bird is such a wonderfully well-formed character, it would be a shame if her twisted adventures ended here."  -Jordan Bimm, NOW Magazine, Critic's Pick, NNNN

"The great discovery here is McGee's deft physicality, clever composition, and above all, her ruthlessly inquisitive and impulse-driven Mission Bird. Exquisitely poetic in one moment, babbling in the next, at turns wisecracking and aggressive, or bereaved and vulnerable, this is a young woman whose story McGee would be well advised to continue exploring - and that audiences who can handle some black humour and squirm-inducing verbal imagery should get acquainted with.”  -Steve Fischer, Torontoist

"Impish and engaging ... McGee is a savvy actor.  From the moment the lights come up, she has us eating out of the palm of Mission Birds grubby little hand."  -Martin Morrow, Globe and Mail

"Haley McGee is a fresh young talent with terrific presence and range. Go see her show!"  -Glenn Sumi, NOW Magazine

"McGee's funny, affecting and disturbing play is a unique and artfully constructed piece of theatre. She is an inspired writer with a firm grasp of language and imagery.  McGee is a highly skilled actor. And her storytelling is so powerful you will feel it in your bones."  -Lauren Gillett, Theatromania, 4 Stars

“Watch out, because Mission Bird is sharp, and your fingernails will sting afterwards. She might become the next darling of Canadian theatre if she can keep her unfortunate destructive tendencies in check.”  -Becky Halliday, SEE Magazine, 5 Stars

“Toronto’s Haley McGee creates an unforgettable and often hilarious character in this essentially pitch-dark play. Oh My Irma, written by McGee, is one of those wonderful Fringe shows that sends you out of the theatre dazzled.”  -Richard Helm, The Edmonton Journal, 4.5 Stars

 

other ways you can help

not to worry if you can’t donate.  If you want to help but have no funds here are a few things I would really appreciate:

  • spread the word! use the share tools to share this campaign on your facebook, twitter, etc.
  • ask your friends with funds to take a look at this campaign
  • donate your airmiles to the cause (email me at ohmyirma@gmail.com and I'll let you know how)
  • send me good vibes
  • suggest cheap places to eat while I’m away
  • suggest cheap accommodations (or relatives/friends that I can stay with) while I'm away
  • promote the tour! tell your friends/relatives/colleagues in any of those cities to come to OH MY IRMA

 

 *If you or your company is interested in sponsoring the tour or me, please contact me directly at ohmyirma@gmail.com for more details.

donate your airmiles to the cause (email me at ohmyirma@gmail.com and I'll let you know how)
send me good vibes
suggest cheap places to eat while I’m away
suggest cheap accommodations (or relatives/friends that I can stay with) while I'm away

promote the tour! tell your friends/relatives/colleagues in any of those cities to come to OH MY IRMA
 
 *If you or your company is interested in sponsoring the tour or me, please contact me directly at ohmyirma@gmail.com for more details.

story:
The Generic Ensemble Company Presents in: THE EXPERIMENT

Fri-Sun, May 4-6; Thu-Sun, May 10-13. 8pm all days at Blue Theatre
Sun, May 6 & Thu, May 10 are "pay-what-you-can"

by Ana-Maurine Lara & kt shorb
Directed by kt shorb
Choreography by Tonya Pennie
Featuring: Saray de Jesus Rosales as Lucy, Krysta Gonzales as Dolly, and Smalls McCoy as Dora; with dancing by Kimberly Caterino, Kaitlyn Jolly, and Kirsche Dickson.
Dramaturgy by Kimberly Alidio
Stage Management by Margaux Binder 
Lighting Design by Paige Binder
Set Design by Grandma "Joshua" Baker and Ethan Stover
Costume Design by Monica Pasut Gibson, Camille Deprang and Love and Monsters Puppet Co.
Poster Design by Armand Alidio

Presented in conjunction with Love & Monsters Puppet Co.

THE EXPERIMENT is an evening-length play asking the question, “What does it mean to be human?” THE EXPERIMENT draws its structure from worlds fairs and vaudeville, creating a speculative future reminiscent of the turn of the 20th century. It incorporates theatrical dialogue between a cyborg and an immortal mutant; singing by a perverse scientist/lab attendant; and a silent dancing chorus. THE EXPERIMENT showcases performances by (queer) women of color investigating the relationship between modern human subjects experiments, turn-of-the century freak shows, and anecdotal narratives of masculine/butch women.

THE EXPERIMENT showcases the work and stories of primarily queer-identified women of color. Austin needs more shows like ours. Our approach is physical and experimental--delving into aesthetics and rehearsal processes that are innovative and new both locally and nationally. 

How We Will Use Your Funds

Donations from this campaign will go directly toward paying creative collaborators, which include over 15 creative people. Thanks to the City of Austin Cultural Contracts and a generous grant from the Open Meadows Foundation, and the Creative Fund Q-Rental Subsidy Grant, we have enough to cover some venue costs, materials, travel, and some of the honoraria. It is the Generic Ensemble Company's goal to make this work sustainable for all collaborators. To do so, we hope to compensate all collaborators as well as possible.

Why We Are So Cool

The Generic Ensemble Company (GenEnCo) is one of the few troupes in Austin, and nationally, that showcases queer-identified women of color in physcially engaged, experimental, ensemble-based performance. THE EXPERIMENT is the third collaboration between Lara and shorb, the previous two collaborations both garnering awards. This is the most recent project aimed at asking profound questions toward social change through rigorous, dangerous, and community-conscious theatre.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot help out with donating to our cause, we are looking for volunteers to run the house, be backstage, and distribute media material. Do you have a blog, radio show, or column? Talk to us and share our project with your audience!

Ticket Info

Tickets can be purchased in advance for $12 at http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/239694

story:
HOORAY! We met our original IndieGoGoal-- BUT, that's far from realizing the full budget of the show. 

Any further donations, far from being irrelevant or excessive, will actually be essential to helping produce this show on a level we previously thought unrealistic, with resources that would have been out of our reach.

We're upping the incentive to give as we are still in urgent need of your help to create this unforgettable show!

FOR ONE: We have a donor interested in MATCHING EVERY DOLLAR RAISED OVER OUR ORIGINAL $1500 GOAL. Your post-goal donations have a doubly huge impact!

FOR TWO: This show has the potential to be even better than our original modest budget would have allowed. If we can reach $2500 via this campaign, we will be able to successfully implement our sophisticated lighting and sound designs!  

LASTLY: We got posters! $75 gets you a poster (signed or not, your choice) and a VIP seat at the show.

THANK YOU!

The Show

Telemachus, Darling is a tender exploration of the life of an eight-year-old boy following his father's death at sea during World War I. Twining together the dreams and realities of young Darling's life with episodes from the story of Odysseus's son, Telemachus, this play is a strange, poetic look at loss, its tolls and redemptions, in the lives of two young men.

An original story from playwright Patrick Barrett, Telemachus, Darling is the third collaboration between Barrett and director Carly Hoogendyk, following last summer’s Dr. Apple's Last Lecture (named a “Hot Show” of the 2011 Edinburgh Fringe by The Scotsman). Our design team is currently dreaming up and implementing plans for a multimedia yet tender style of storytelling. Design elements and staging will partner archive and fantasy to bring this extremely rich script to life. By interweaving narration with an evocative soundscape, live music, inventive staging, and projections of original  illustrations, we aspire to deploy an array of artistic tools to create a sensorily engaging and immediate theatrical experience.

Your Role

The team of designers and performers tasked with bringing Telemachus, Darling to life are some of the most dedicated, collaboratively-minded talents currently working in the New York theatre scene. They do this because they love it, and consequently they're fantastically devoted and skilled. All of the money raised towards our goal will go towards compensating them for their hard work and helping fully realize their vision.

Meet the Team

PRODUCTION

Patrick Barrett (PLAYWRIGHT) 

Carly Hoogendyk (DIRECTOR) 

Colin Drummond (PRODUCER)

Hilary Keyes (ASSISTANT DIRECTOR/STAGE MANAGER) 

Mike Faba (LIGHTING DESIGNER) 

Joseph Wolfslau (SOUND DESIGNER)

Cassie Dorland (SET AND PROPS DESIGNER)

Carrie Wladis (COSTUME DESIGNER)

Gene Kogan (PROJECTIONS)

Justin Wagner (ILLUSTRATIONS)

CAST

Sammy Bravo (DARLING)

Rosie DuPont (MOTHER)

Leigh Williams (PENELOPE)

Mac Wallach (TELEMACHUS)

Tim McCarren (MR. DROOD)

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot contribute today, spread the word about Telemachus, Darling. Use Indiegogo's share tools and like Hole in the Sky on facebook. And of course come see the show! It opens July 27th!
