story:
Flux Industries is a laboratory where innovative, inspiring and moving performances are created. Performances should be fun for the people who make it and people who witness it.

We pride ourselves in creating opportunities for emerging artists to create and perform original work that contributes to their portfolio and the advancement of their career while providing new theatrical and musical experiences to a dynamic and curious audience.

We create excitement for our followers and that excites us! We think it's a good thing!

This fundraising campaign will truly and directly inject life into what we have been putting on paper since July 2012. The music has been composed, the dialogues are being put together, the designers are collecting research, the director is creating a structure and the producer is booking rehearsal space and venue.

Achieving our goal of $5000 will allow us to create an amazing opportunity for emerging artists to create and perform original work that contributes to their personal portfolio and the advancement of their career while providing a new theatrical and musical experience to a dynamic and curious audience. We are creating a space for a new generation of artists to shine.

What has been said about our cabaret:

"I can't wait for the new show! I was blessed with the opportunity to witness the awe inspiring spectacle that was Phaedra's Cabaret! It was an emotional mix of drama, comedy, and carefully nuanced beautiful talent. Phaedra's Cabaret was an appetizing guilty pleasure that left me hungry for more! Way to go Flux Industries!"

A. Rodriguez

"Such an amazingly talented group of artists and a wonderfully creative collage of acts.  The show was charming and funny with wonderful moments of tenderness including the original song "Fragile".  This is a show and a group not to be missed. Absolutely delightful!"

J. Murdock
 
"I think any artist would agree there is nothing more thrilling than collaboration.  The cabaret has been the most challenging and exciting experience I've had working with other performers.  The productions have been a chance to create anything, break the rules, break the forth wall, reach out and surprise the audience and ourselves.  It has been pure creation!"
 
Shanna Jones, singer/songwriter

"Working on the Cabaret with this powerful group of artists has truly been a blessing. The caliber of artists and their commitment to their craft is at the heart of why this project has been so successful. The Cabaret wasn’t just a wonderful presentation for an audience to witness, but a beginning of numerous creative collaborations among the artists.  I look forward to taking part in it for a long time to come."

Simón Hanukai, Director

"I have worked for big Theatres and small ones and I have never encounter this kind of commitment and creativity like this before. These artists get into a room and magic happens. Words, sounds, colors and movements are coming together creating an unexpected story that gets you right there, between your lungs and your belly button and gives you chills all over."

MA Désy, Producer

Our goal

Our goal of $5000 will be use to pay for rehearsal space ($1000), the venue for the performance ($1500), costumes, hair & make-up ($1000), musical instrument repair and maintenance ($1000) and props ($500).

We invite you to join our fundraising campaign. Every dollar counts and makes a difference! We hope to see you on November 25th and 26th at MMAC in NYC for the performances of our new cabaret.


Other ways you can help!
If a money donation is not possible at the moment or if you are passionate about our project please SPREAD THE WORD about Flux Industries! Like us on facebook (http://www.facebook.com/FluxIndustries), follow us on twitter (@fluxind), share our website (www.fluxind.com) and use the Indiegogo share tool! If everyone we know and everyone you know get together, we can really make this project fly!

story:
Buran Theatre's new play with music, NIGHTMARES: a demonstration of the Sublime, will premiere January 2-12, 2013 at The Brick in Brooklyn. After premiering in Brooklyn, the production will tour later in 2013 to the Topeka/Lawrence area and Albuquerque, with the aim to play additional cities.

However, we cannot achieve these goals without funding.

Buran Theatre was founded in 2008--in tandem with the financial crisis--and the funding climate for young independent artists has been particularly dismal ever since. In spite of this, Buran Theatre has been able to create risk-taking productions while keeping our tickets prices low, touring as often as we can--defying many odds. And we’ve been able to achieve all of this because of the support of our friends and audiences.

We want to continue this trend with NIGHTMARES! Please consider helping Buran Theatre produce this wildly inventive new production.

 --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Where funding goes: Unlike a majority of professional companies, we pay our artists. Over half of our funding goal is intended to go straight to artists as a stipend for their work. The remaining funds raised will support our scenic design and construction, rehearsal and promotional costs, as well as costume design.

Artist stipends: $3,500

Scenic & Media design/construction & materials: $1,500

Costume design/construction & materials: $250

Rehearsal/Promotional costs: $250

Tour/travel costs for 4 company members: $1,000

 

CREATIVE TEAM

Written & directed by Adam R. Burnett

Co-directed/Co-produced by Theresa Buchheister

Original music composed & performed by CS Luxem

Scenic design by Nick Kostner

Media design by Geraldo Mercado

Light design by Ann Sitzman

Choreographed by Theresa Buchheister

Dramaturgy by Lara Thomas Ducey

Poster design: Jon O'Grady (BCPrintMedia.com)

Performers: Caitlin Bebb, Arla Berman, Adam Burnett, Brady Blevins, Sarah Graalman, Marlowe Holden, Catrin Lloyd-Bollard, Jud Knudsen, Geraldo Mercado, & Curry Whitmire

ABOUT THE SHOW: NIGHTMARES situates itself between terror and comedy (the sublime), beneath the gaze of Henry Fuseli's iconic painting, and in the midst of an enveloping soundscape to plumb the extremities of our contemporary condition and posit the question: are we still capable of being overwhelmed?

Initiating at the birth of the modern sublime--the summer of 1816, when literary heavyweights Lord Byron, Mary Shelley, Percy Bysshe Shelley, and Jon Polidori convened on Lake Geneva to create their literary shapeshifters, namely Frankenstein's Monster and the Vampyre--the performance takes on the overwhelming anxiety of confronting nature and ourselves in the 21st century, an era that seemingly reaches for zeros.

There will be singing and dancing, too.

 ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

WHAT PEOPLE HAVE SAID ABOUT BURAN THEATRE:

"Imagine the chaotic postmodern aesthetic of Radiohole blended with the rigorous precision of the SITI Company, glued together with the gleeful anarchic spirit of the Marx Brothers. That, maybe gives you an idea of the cheerful, buoyant, engaging and entertaining performance style of Buran Theatre...definitely needs to be on your 'must-see' list." -  Martin Denton (NYTheatre.com)

"Exceptional, bounding, solipsistic performance." - Mitch Montgomery (Backstage Magazine) on The House of Fitzcarraldo

"...cerebral, audacious...embraces a mile-wide streak of absurdism. This show is so full of unexpected pivots  and clever concepts that it keeps the audience laughing." -Robert Trussell (KC Star) on The House of Fitzcarraldo

 "...hard not to love...superb performances. Remind[s] there are still-to-be-discovered ways for theater to tell a story." - Anthony Del Valle (Las Vegas Review Journal) on The House of Fitzcarraldo

"There will be skin, there will be songs, there will be makeup inappropriately applied and moments where the performers get muuuuuuuch too close...There will be accomplished and highly technical nose-blowing...participatory rope handling...And so but then, before you know it, it's all gone, leaving only a stage awash in fluids." -Jeff Jones, Playwright and curator of Little Theatre, on The House of Fitzcarraldo

"It is drama like this that promises to maintain the precious art of theater in this day and age." - New York Arts/Berkshire Review on The House of Fitzcarraldo

"Pleasantly surprised and frequently stunned. This is such an audacious act of creativity...it deserves to be seen." Robert Trussell (KC Star) on Money Buckets

"Semi-nuduty. Simulated masturbation. Hilarious gags. No pretenses of having great artistic merit." -An audience member in Kansas City, MO on The House of Fitzcarraldo

story:
ABOUT SPACEMAN

"We're all humans and the idea of sending one of our kind on a trip like that would be a wonderful adventure for the entire world. the whole world would get behind it."

 - James McLane, Former NASA engineer discussing a one-way, solo trip to Mars

In 2010, a bill was signed in the United States authorizing manned missions to the planet Mars by 2030s. But, the reality of such a trip comes with a catch - such a flight would take over eight months, would be performed solo and would offer no return trip.

In this brave and funny new play, the difficulties of interplanetary space travel are brought to life in exacting detail. Radiation exposure, long term weightlessness, low light, extensive communication delays and poor hygiene are just a few of the challenges astronaut Molly Jennis must face as the first to Mars. But she soon finds nothing compares to the psychological effects of having so much time alone. Time spent mulling over the decisions she has made and what might be waiting for her when she finally reaches her destination.

Spaceman simulates space travel for the stage using low light, a claustraphobic set and simulated micro-gravity. The play will also use an immersive sound design featuring works by experimental composers such as Kevin Drumm, Alva Noto, Daphne Oram, and Aiden Baker among others.

WHY WE ARE EXCITED ABOUT THIS PLAY

We at Loading Dock love to take theatre beyond the upper-middle class living room.  Doing a play about surviving in outer space is exciting to us because it grapples with both science and mythology. This combination allows us to explore what is timeless in mankind: science always pushing us forward into new frontiers, while mythology keeps us bound to our primal urges, desires and loves that have existed since time began.  Making space and science theatrical and visceral is infinitely facinating to us -- we're never bored of working on this project!  Spaceman grapples with these ideas in meaningful and funny ways.

And the idea of transporting an audience to a completely  new world -- largly through our immersive sound design -- is just really freakin' fun. And check it out – this is a real, one way trip to Mars funded by reality TV!  Almost straight out of the script!

Contributing to this play will help us realize our design to the fullest extent.  We want to simulate micro-gravity and the vacuousness of space in the most realistic way possible.  That includes a fully realized space module complete with internal lighting and a life-like space suit (see the video!).  A full set will really help transport audiences out of the theatre and into the big empty void, where we want ‘em! 

WHAT WE NEED AND WHAT YOU GET BY SUPPORTING US

SPACEMAN is an original play by Leegrid Stevens and we are lucky to be able to present it as part of the Incubator Arts Project. But self-producing theater in NYC isn't easy.

Your support will go directly towards the mounting of our play, SPACEMAN. We are producing this on our own and need help paying for sets, lights and costumes.

The design is particularly important to the success of this play. It takes place in a NASA-style shuttle on a one-way trip to Mars. We are creating a capsule that is essntially our "set" where the action will take place. 

Your support would help us not only realize this set, but actually fill out the frame with all the gadgets, buttons and switches (and even a computer screen) to create the chlosterphobic module our astronaut has been trapped in for 7 months.

We are also exploring using some creative & sophisticated lighting effects to simulate space travel. Specifically, your support would help us to obtain special dimmers, Lite Pads, and other unique light sources within the space module.

Perhaps the coolest element you'll be supporting is our purchase of two life-size replicas of actual NASA space suits. These things are super cool (and expensive!)

Speaking of the super cool space suit, check out our great perks for supporting us!

Be sure to spread the word about how you're helping support original theater in NYC! Don't forget to use the share functions on this page and tell your friends!

ABOUT US

Loading Dock and Incubator Arts Project present:

SPACEMAN
written and directed by Leegrid Stevens

featuring Erin Treadway and Shawn Davis
costume design by Rabiah Troncelitti
scene design by Carolyn Mraz
light design by Driscol Otto
sound design by Leegrid Stevens
produced by Ryan Pointer, B.J. Evans, and Regan Glover

Performances: October 12, 13, 14, 16, 18, 19, 20, 21
All shows at 8pm
Incubator Arts Project
St. Marks Church In-the-Bowery
131 East 10th Street
(at 2nd Ave)
New York, NY 10003

Loading Dock was formed by playwright/director Leegrid Stevens and actor Erin Treadway. The primary focus of Loading Dock is to create original plays that explore the extremes in human behavior. The company often juxtaposes ancient mythology with modern social thought and convention to explore the conflicted relationship of the modern man to his/her more primal instincts. While grounded in the traditions of realism, Loading Dock does not subscribe to a universal or stable reality but instead seeks to present the warped realities of its subjects as they perceive the world. These augmented realities are created using both traditional and innovative theatrical conventions. Avant-guarde and experimental techniques such as exploratory language, contradictory or non-linear narrative, video, and experimental sound are combined with the theatrical traditions of complex, emotionally expressive characters, recognition and reversal, and focus of action that were established by theatre's forbearers such as Sophocles, Anton Chekov, and Tennessee Williams.

Leegrid Stevens
Plays: The Twelfth Labor, Spaceman, Echo's Longing, The Dudleys!, Albatross at Sea, Deathless, Leda's Swan, Nine-Twelve Tapes, The Dislodging, Approaching Midnight, Theme & Variations, and Sun Stand Thou Still

Leegrid grew up in the hill country of Spicewood, TX. He moved to New york after attending SMU in Dallas and now lives in Brooklyn. His plays have been seen in downtown theatres in New York including HERE Arts Center, Incubator Arts Project, Lark Theatre, Altered Stages, Theatre for the New City among others both nationally and internationally. You can find some of his plays in print including Post-Oedipus (Playscripts), Leda's Swan (Stage Tribes, Theater-Verlag Desh Publishers), Sun Stand Thou Still (Plays and Playwrights 2004), and The Dudleys! (Indie Theatre). Leegrid has bee the playwright in residence at Tutto Theatre in Austin for 2011 and 2012.
BFA - SMU
MFA - Columbia

Erin Treadway
story_txt:
ABOUT SPACEMAN
"We're all humans and the idea of sending one of our kind on a trip like that would be a wonderful adventure for the entire world. the whole world would get behind it." 
 - James McLane, Former NASA engineer discussing a one-way, solo trip to Mars
In 2010, a bill was signed in the United States authorizing manned missions to the planet Mars by 2030s. But, the reality of such a trip comes with a catch - such a flight would take over eight months, would be performed solo and would offer no return trip.
In this brave and funny new play, the difficulties of interplanetary space travel are brought to life in exacting detail. Radiation exposure, long term weightlessness, low light, extensive communication delays and poor hygiene are just a few of the challenges astronaut Molly Jennis must face as the first to Mars. But she soon finds nothing compares to the psychological effects of having so much time alone. Time spent mulling over the decisions she has made and what might be waiting for her when she finally reaches her destination.
Spaceman simulates space travel for the stage using low light, a claustraphobic set and simulated micro-gravity. The play will also use an immersive sound design featuring works by experimental composers such as Kevin Drumm, Alva Noto, Daphne Oram, and Aiden Baker among others.
WHY WE ARE EXCITED ABOUT THIS PLAY
We at Loading Dock love to take theatre beyond the upper-middle class living room.  Doing a play about surviving in outer space is exciting to us because it grapples with both science and mythology. This combination allows us to explore what is timeless in mankind: science always pushing us forward into new frontiers, while mythology keeps us bound to our primal urges, desires and loves that have existed since time began.  Making space and science theatrical and visceral is infinitely facinating to us -- we're never bored of working on this project!  Spaceman grapples with these ideas in meaningful and funny ways.
And the idea of transporting an audience to a completely  new world -- largly through our immersive sound design -- is just really freakin' fun. And check it out – this is a real, one way trip to Mars funded by reality TV!  Almost straight out of the script!
Contributing to this play will help us realize our design to the fullest extent.  We want to simulate micro-gravity and the vacuousness of space in the most realistic way possible.  That includes a fully realized space module complete with internal lighting and a life-like space suit (see the video!).  A full set will really help transport audiences out of the theatre and into the big empty void, where we want ‘em! 


WHAT WE NEED AND WHAT YOU GET BY SUPPORTING US
SPACEMAN is an original play by Leegrid Stevens and we are lucky to be able to present it as part of the Incubator Arts Project. But self-producing theater in NYC isn't easy.Your support will go directly towards the mounting of our play, SPACEMAN. We are producing this on our own and need help paying for sets, lights and costumes.The design is particularly important to the success of this play. It takes place in a NASA-style shuttle on a one-way trip to Mars. We are creating a capsule that is essntially our "set" where the action will take place. 
Your support would help us not only realize this set, but actually fill out the frame with all the gadgets, buttons and switches (and even a computer screen) to create the chlosterphobic module our astronaut has been trapped in for 7 months.
We are also exploring using some creative & sophisticated lighting effects to simulate space travel. Specifically, your support would help us to obtain special dimmers, Lite Pads, and other unique light sources within the space module. Perhaps the coolest element you'll be supporting is our purchase of two life-size replicas of actual NASA space suits. These things are super cool (and expensive!)Speaking of the super cool space suit, check out our great perks for supporting us!


Be sure to spread the word about how you're helping support original theater in NYC! Don't forget to use the share functions on this page and tell your friends!

featuring Erin Treadway and Shawn Daviscostume design by Rabiah Troncelittiscene design by Carolyn Mrazlight design by Driscol Ottosound design by Leegrid Stevensproduced by Ryan Pointer, B.J. Evans, and Regan Glover

story:
Our Story

I started this show over a year ago, workshopping the script with Eric Trules. In that workshop, a deadline was provided to get our shows completed: The Hollywood Fringe Festival. I did manage to pull it all together in time and presented my one man show, Blood Fruit, about how I came out to my Catholic Iraqi parents. The audience laughed and cried and the show was so well-received I even won BEST of the Hollywood Fringe! I was given an encore show at the Theatre Asylum, and then I embarked on producing the show on my own at the Lounge Theatre where I originally opened. I just had to cancel all future performances because the production is lacking in funds! Please help!


The Impact

What's so special about my show is that people connect to it in very personal ways. When I see a play, I can tell the actors "good job", but it's hard to say how personal it was to see the show because the actor isn't the whole show. Blood Fruit is different. It is me telling my own life story. What the audience gets is my true story overcoming my own fears and my own challenges being gay. The result is that my audience can connect with material and with me. They learn more about themselves and how they can be different. The BEST example of this was a friend of mine who was so moved by the show he couldn't stand to greet me afterwards because he had to contemplate his relationship with his father (I opened before Father's Day, so it impacted him even more). He was inspired by my show to visit his father and try to make peace despite his rejection of my friend's sexuality. I keep hearing how inspiring my show it, and I have to continue to share it and inspire others!

What We Need & What You Get

This fundraiser will SAVE Blood Fruit and allow me to produce it again. Your donation will go directly towards all of the production costs, the space rental being the biggest. The first grand will go towards the next production and the second grand will be for the continuation of the show. I hope to take the funds submit the show towards more Fringe Festivals around the US. If I don't have enough by then I'll do whatever I need to to get it and let this show thrive. Help me make it happen! Of course, depending on your donation, you could receive something as well! Check it out!


Other Ways You Can Help

SPREAD THE WORD! Tell people about the show, especially if you've seen it. Most of my audience has come from word of mouth. Keep 'em coming! And if you know any people that work with the LGBT community or are themselves queer, tell them to donate! Tell everyone to donate! Let's do it!

story:
Our Story

Prav MJ discovered Six Rounds by John Oluwole Adekoje in Boston in 2007 when she was training to be a director at the ART.  Returning to London in 2008, Liminal Space Productions was founded to produce new contemporary writing with up and coming actors ( www.pravmjdirect.com) This is the first major production for Liminal Space Productions at LOST Theatre in Stockwell, London from June 7th - July 2nd 2011.

 

Six Rounds is a hard hitting drama about life for black kids on the streets and the problems they face with guns, the police and other members of the community. “Snitching” and the consequences of gun crime are a strong theme in this play. A Hip-Hop DJ cuts and scratches in the background to the beat of life on the streets. As ADEkoje writes “The young with the aggression of hip-hop & Rock and Roll carry the petals of hope. This is the texture and fabric of this play.”

Six Rounds Cast include:
Tommy Coleman, Eve Fontaine, Caleb Frederick, Chris Mitchell, Dubem Nuabe , Darren Raymond, Catriona Toop & Anthony Vander

Creatives include:
DJ J-Den (Composer), EdgE (Graffiti Artst) , Ben Pickersgil (Lighting), Sam Charleston (Sound Designer,) Shane & Troy Glasgow (Video designers) & Reinhold Mahler (Poster Design)

Sponsors include:
LUKE clothing (http://www.luke1977.com) and Ringtone Boxing.

 

The Impact

Limimal Space Productions is supporting a number of charities during the run of the play

·       Brook that deals with under 25's sexual health needs

·       Art Saves Lives who are trying to open a theatre space in New Cross, London

·       Terrence Higgins Trust which is the largest HIV/Aids charity

·       One of the actors involved is from NZ, The Red Cross NZ Earthquake appeal

 

Also, the play is very relevant at the moment since there has been an increase in youth violence in London with issues of guns and "snitching' being hotly discussed. It is important to get the message out to the youth in the community regarding the consequences of street crime through the medium of theatre.

 

What We Need & What You Get

This is the first major production for Liminal Space Productions and the artistic director Prav MJ would like to ensure that the money raised will be used to promote Six Rounds and the charities involved. The donors will become our angels and will be included in our program and invited to attend the Press Night and After Party on June 8th at LOST theatre in Stockwell. If donor cannot attend, they will be also be acknowledged on my website www.pravmjdirect.com.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please let other people know about the show! Would love to see you there and discuss the show.

Follow us on Facebook & Twitter

http://www.facebook.com/event.php?eid=111929228...

http://twitter.com/#!/SIXROUNDS

story:
Our Story

Pipeline Theatre Company opens its 3rd season with the world premiere of Colby Day's Felix and The Diligence in the Fall of 2011 at the Connelly Theatre in New York City.

 

PIPELINE THEATRE COMPANY is a downtown Manhattan-based non-profit theater company, comprised of 25 emerging actors, directors, writers and designers. The work Pipeline produces–both new and established–hopes to to be a testament to the power of theater to entertain, inspire, and enlighten. Productions include: The Love of the Nightingale, Sleepless City (World Premiere), Psycho Beach Party,Shakespeare the Dead (World Premiere,2010 “Dream Up” Fest at Theater for the New City), Bekah Brunstetter’s Fat Kids on Fire (directed byTony-nominee Peter Frechette, and The Caucasian Chalk Circle (nominated for two 2011 IT Awards). Our Brave New Works series, produced in tandem with our mainstages, brings together other young theater companies in hopes of building a community of our contemporaries, and strengthening one-another’s fanbase.

 

The Impact

Pipeline Theatre Company is proud to continually offer new work from emerging artists with programs like our Brave New Works series, and our Whipser and Shout Reading Series in which Felix and The Diligence originated.

 

Our Company prides itself on our collectivity and the empowerment of our peers by offering the opportunity for full-scale, fully funded, fully organized and realized Off-Off Broadway productions.

In this spirit we are proud to present company member Colby Day's Felix and The Diligence, a hilarious comedy set at sea with nazi spies, sea monsters, mistaken identities, romance, weird vibes and a mostly happy ending.

What We Need

We ask for your help to ensure this production becomes the best it can be for all involved and for our ravenous audience.

 

Your donations will directly go to the purchasing of materials, props, costumes, etc.

 

$20 donations would mean a modest payment to the many many volunteers donating their time to this production.

$50 would provide a full costume for one of our cast members

$100 would pay for 10 hours of rehearsal space that is not our living room

 

 

Any amount, big or small is greatly appreciated and incredibly helpful!

 

Thank you for helping this make this wonderful show a reality!

                 

-The Felix Team

story:
High School Saved our Lives


We (Collin Clay Chace and Seth Lepore) first started doing theatre together while attending an alternative high school in Providence, RI called School One. We were cast in a play called “Inside Al”. This script was about a man whose inner struggle with having cerebral palsy comes to a head as his inside self (played by Collin) gets completely fed up with how he presents his outside self (played by Seth) to the world. 


The Reunion Minus Male Pattern Baldness 


Twenty years later we started chatting about touring two new one-man shows together. We found that we’d been living parallel lives on different continents (Western Mass and London respectively), sharing similar solo performance trajectories and grappling with our own spiritual quests and emotional upheavals.  


Huge admirers of each other's work, we came together again to expand the boundaries of where theater can take an audience. Here's what our shows are all about:


The Rock N' Wrestle Roadshow


In Chace’s “one-man/multiple personality” Rock N Wrestle Roadshow, what we’re wrestling with is mental health. Yet the “funny folks” involved - from a multi-racial porn stud to an heiress-turned-peace activist to an 8-year-old poet – all eschew chat about diagnosis. 


Instead, they skip out of the hospital “crazy ward” to relay their unexpected conclusions about the curveballs life has thrown them. The show celebrates those folks who’ve been written off as deranged and affirms them as essential voices for social change. 


SuperHappyMelancholyexpialidocious


Following on the coat tails of his award-winning monologue Losing My Religion: Confessions of a New Age Refugee, Lepore continues with the second part of his trilogy on the underbelly of the self-help movement.  


Lepore explores the rise in popularity of the happiness industry across the American landscape through the trajectory of hysterical character-driven scenes, as well as autobiographical digests of his personal struggles.  Lepore uses his fecund observations of our fascinating hang-ups with happiness to expose the true cost of this ongoing pursuit.


The Bottom Line


This is much more than two solo shows playing in one evening; it’s a collaboration that creates room for two autonomous experiences, mirroring back to the audience the craving we all have for community, even in the midst of xenophobic obstacles. 


The Double Trouble Tour Storms the Mid-West and Northeast


We got to work last February planning a 7 week tour with including stops in Boulder, Minneapolis, Chicago, NYC, Providence, Boston, Northampton and Brattleboro. Our good friend Karen Spies was enlisted to be our Business Manager as her experience as the CFO of the Boulder Fringe Festival and as a bookkeeper would be invaluable.


As of right now the tour is booked in several theaters in the Mid-West and NorthEast. All of these shows are self-produced which means we are doing all the work: booking the venue, hiring technicians, marketing the shows on a grassroots level and handling all the administrative duties. We are also generating some college gigs and other paid appearances through various arts presenters. Needless to say it’s a lot of work but we’re super excited about how it’s all coming together.


Where You Come In


Our project is fiscally sponsored through Fractured Atlas. That means contributions to our tour are tax-deductible to the full extent of the law (for U.S. bank account holders). We love being able to extend this benefit to our donors.


We will be asking everyone and their mother to help us achieve our goal of $10,000 for the 7 week tour. Renting the theaters, paying technical support, outsourcing some of the PR and marketing, liability insurance and transportation are a few of the many things that quickly add up. 


How You Can Help Us Live the Dream (Levels of Giving) 


  • $250- Graphic design services for our amazing posters, postcards and programs from paperandcloud.com
  • $500- Two nights of rental fees for a theater including technical assistance and box office help
  • $750- Full color Program/ Poster/ Postcard printing for the entire tour
  • $1000- Flyering and distribution services of posters and postcards for the entire tour
  • $2500- The cost of outsourcing our PR/Marketing campaign



What’s Next?


Check out the perks to the right and donate away. Any amount donated will be tax-deductible to the full extent of the law.


Thank you in advance for your generous support. 


Sincerely, 

 

Seth Lepore and Collin Clay Chace

Writers/Performers/Producers

The Double Trouble Tour

The Double Trouble Tour Storms the Mid-West and Northeast

We got to work last February planning a 7 week tour with including stops in Boulder, Minneapolis, Chicago, NYC, Providence, Boston, Northampton and Brattleboro. Our good friend Karen Spies was enlisted to be our Business Manager as her experience as the CFO of the Boulder Fringe Festival and as a bookkeeper would be invaluable.

As of right now the tour is booked in several theaters in the Mid-West and NorthEast. All of these shows are self-produced which means we are doing all the work: booking the venue, hiring technicians, marketing the shows on a grassroots level and handling all the administrative duties. We are also generating some college gigs and other paid appearances through various arts presenters. Needless to say it’s a lot of work but we’re super excited about how it’s all coming together.

Where You Come In

Our project is fiscally sponsored through Fractured Atlas. That means contributions to our tour are tax-deductible to the full extent of the law (for U.S. bank account holders). We love being able to extend this benefit to our donors.

We will be asking everyone and their mother to help us achieve our goal of $10,000 for the 7 week tour. Renting the theaters, paying technical support, outsourcing some of the PR and marketing, liability insurance and transportation are a few of the many things that quickly add up. 

How You Can Help Us Live the Dream (Levels of Giving) 


$250- Graphic design services for our amazing posters, postcards and programs from paperandcloud.com

$500- Two nights of rental fees for a theater including technical assistance and box office help
$750- Full color Program/ Poster/ Postcard printing for the entire tour
$1000- Flyering and distribution services of posters and postcards for the entire tour
$2500- The cost of outsourcing our PR/Marketing campaign


What’s Next?

Check out the perks to the right and donate away. Any amount donated will be tax-deductible to the full extent of the law.

Thank you in advance for your generous support. 

Sincerely, 
 
Seth Lepore and Collin Clay Chace
Writers/Performers/Producers
The Double Trouble Tour

story:
Who are we?

On Broadway Thespians, Inc is a non-profit cultural organization incorporated in 1994 with the original mission to produce quality theater for out local community in an intimate playhouse setting.

What are we doing?

Everyone remembers "Clue" - the board game by Parker Brothers, right? Well, they have taken the "Who done it?, In what room? and with what weapon?" and transported it onto the stage, and we'd like a chance to stage it right here in the Bay Area.

Why?

Clue - The Musical has never been done in our area and it would provide fun and entertainment for audiences of all ages. Clue - The Musical is interactive and the audience gets to play along with the cast in choosing who done it, with what weapon, and in which room. There are 216 potential endings as determined by the cards selected by the audience. This would be a welcome addition to our area as safe, entertaining, and a family oriented night out.

What we need?

Royalties - $1.350.00

Rental of Perusals - $225.00

Scripts - 8.95 X 15 = $23.95

Shipping Fees - $100.00

Deposit - $100.00

Perusal Scores - $7.95 X 11 = $87.45

Conductors Piano Score - $14.95

Stage Managers Script - $16.95 X 2 = $48.85

Misc Costs - $249.80

Total pre-production cost $2200.00

Commercial - $400.00

Print ad in paper - $500.00

Posters - $175.00

Programs - $200.00

Props - $150.00

Costumes / Makeup - $300.00

Insurance - $75.00

Performance Space Rental - $1000.00

Total Production Cost - $2800.00

Total of all expenses - $5000.00

The Impact

On Broadway Thespians has been producing plays for children, teens, adults, and seniors for over 20 years, which facilitates a sense of community, team work, self esteem, memorization and communication skills for all involved in the production of our plays.

Other Ways You Can Help

Help spread the word about our programming and our fundraising! Make some noise! Like us on facebook too! Volunteer as an usher (and get to see the show for free) Check out our website for more information on ways you can help.

Performances

August 29th - September 14th 2014.

Friday and Saturday evening shows at 7:00 PM and Sunday Matinees at 2:00 PM.

THANK YOU MUCH!!!!

story:
My Journey:

Lisa Honig Buksbaum, CEO & Founder, Soaringwords

I am a passionary (a visionary driven by great passion and action). Based on three personal experiences with illness and death in my family, I was inspired to launch Soaringwords twelve years ago. Since then, Soaringwords has embraced more than 250,000 ill children and families. I have devoted the last twelve years to inspiring children and families who are grappling with serious illness to "Never give up!" 

Our Campaign Goal:

Dance can transform a hospitalized child's day and inspire each patient to heal. Imagine the joy and laughter as pediatric patients enjoy fun and lively Zumba® classes. 

When pediatric patients come to the Zumba class, they will be greeted by caring, compassionate, and talented dance instructors who want to bring hope and joy to hospitalized children, their families, and the dedicated hospital staff.

However, we cannot do this without your help. We need your financial contribution. 100% of your donation will support us in managing this worldwide initiative, as we lead and coordinate hospital professionals and Zumba® instructors. With your support, we will share the healing power of dance, movement, laughter, and community to transform the lives of pediatric patients.


To ensure the highest quality experience, we are only working with licensed Zumba® Fitness instructors who have been specially trained to work with children. Child Life professionals and pediatric hospital caregivers will ensure that patients are able to participate in the classes.

Currently we are bringing free monthly Zumba® Fitness classes to:
1. Joe DiMaggio Children's Hospital (Florida) led by the fabulous Richard Gormley, Zumba Education Specialist
2. Shriners Hospitals for Children (Chicago) led by the warm and wonderful Caroline Matheus and Debbie Guzzo Beck. 
3. Children's Healthcare of Atlanta led by the fantastic Renee Burwell 
4. Miami Children's Hospital led by the amazing and energetic team: Henry Cedeno, Reyna Zurita and Janice Gonzalez.
5. Florida Hospital for Children in Orlando led by Reyna Zurita, Janice Gonzalez and Jenisse Alvarez.
6. Komansky Center for Children's Health at NY-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell Medical Center.


Why Our Program? Why Donate? 

When a child is ill, the whole family is in crisis. While current medical advances are impressive, a hospitalized child's social, emotional and physical worlds can be shattered.  Pediatric patients are isolated from family, friends, classmates, and a sense of community.  Hospitalization is a stressful and painful experience for a child with limited opportunities for choice and control. The change in daily routine, including limited play and physical activity, adds to the stress and isolation.

Benefits of Zumba for hospitalized children:

  • Promotes physical and psychological healing through movement and community
  • Decreases stress
  • Works on physical goals such as walking and balance
  • Helps patients develop positive friendships and connections
  • Builds community by bringing all parents, children and hospital staff together to have fun
  • Reinforces the idea that its okay to just be yourself and dance like no one is watching
  • Models the importance of movement and fitness
  • Combats the risk of childhood obesity
  • Inspires feelings of purpose and meaning


It's Working!

We have received an overwhelming positive response from hospitalized children, families, hospital staff, which has inspired us to expand this successful healing project to 100 hospitals world wide.  

"It has been a great experience to share Zumba®Fitness with patients and families and staff at Shriners Hospital for Children these past ten months. It is so fulfilling to see patients and staff members dancing and having fun. There are so many dedicated people caring for these children, it is wonderful to give them a chance to relieve stress.  It is hard to describe how happy and grateful we as ZINs feel when we see the patients returning, especially the children in the wheelchairs. When they move their arms and spin in their wheelchairs it is so inspiring."   -Caroline Matheus, ZIN member since 2010. Zumba team lead of Shiners Hospital for Children.

"We at Joe DiMaggio Children’s Hospital would like to thank Soaringwords and Zumba® Fitness for generously providing our patients and families a free class once a month. Our kids love this chance to dance, be silly, have fun and just really be kids again. They can forget about being in the hospital and all the scary things that come with that experience for the one hour that they are in the Zumba class. The way that all the instructors engage the children and make it fun for them touches our hearts. Again, we would like to thank you so much for this amazing privilege!" -Katelynn Maltby, Child Life Specialist, Joe DiMaggio Children's Hospital 

"I look forward to teaching my monthly classes at Joe DiMaggio Children’s Hospital every month. Each class is unpredictable. Seemingly healthy children and those hooked up to IVs join the fun, some in wheelchairs ready to dance. It always takes a few minutes for me to realize that these are regular kids who just want to DANCE and have FUN like their typically functioning peers. The hour flies by and the joy and excitement for the program is written in their smiles. The joy spreads and follows them back to their rooms and changes the perspective life of those present forever!" -Richard Gormley, ZES 

"We are trying to get our children to move because this accelerates the process of healing. Our hospital is strongly committed to promoting wellness so we frequently recruit outpatients and families to join in the Soaringwords + Zumba® Fitness classes each month. Parents that are here for a long time really appreciate the opportunity to get out of their child's hospital room and have fun and be with other people and dance. It's a tremendous motivator for our staff who do so much to care for others, this is the one hour each month that we can take care of ourselves." - Darlene Kelly, Director Recreation Therapy/Child Life Department, Shriners Hospitals for Children, Chicago


Other Ways You Can Help:

Money isn't the only thing that can bring joy and laughter to hospitalized children. There are other ways to help our campaign: 

1. Please share this campaign. Our cause is by no means limited to our zip code. Soaringwords works with ill children and their families all around the world. 
2. "Like" Soaringwords on Facebook www.facebook.com/soaringwords
3. If you are a licensed Zumbatomic® / Zumba® Kids instructor and would like to volunteer please click here.


Let the Zumba classes and the healing begin! Together we can soar.

story:
About Us:

 

Have you ever watched a dance or theatre performance and think to yourself, "I wish I could do that!" Well, wish no more! Alexa Luthor, of Green Mountain Cabaret, and Aeshna Mairead, of Silk Lotus Dance, are teaming up to create Soul Fire Studio, a place for all to openly indulge in burlesque, belly dance, hooping, yoga, improv, stand up, sketch, and much, much more! But before we can offer such fantastic classes, we need your help... yes YOU! Help us build a home for the arts so we can share our passion for performance with you!

 

About This Campaign:

 

With your generous contribution, you will help secure and build an all-inclusive performing arts studio, where anyone with passion can learn and practice the style of expression they desire in a comfortable and judgment-free zone or rent a rehearsal space. All contributions will go towards renting our studio in the South End of Burlington and paying the utilities for our first few months.  Contributions will also be used in obtaining the necessities to help make the space more welcoming and user-friendly. Only you have the power to help us create a home for the artistic community to bare its soul!

 

What We Need & What You Get:

 

We are looking for $10,000 total, to cover two month's rent, utilities, purchasing of items necessary to everyday operations like internet and phone, and to fund the installation of the lower level classroom flooring. If we don't reach our goal, whatever funds we do accumulate will still go towards the payment of as much of the monthly rental/utility fees/flooring costs as possible.

 

Besides the perks from your donation, you will have access to learn in a welcoming space where we plan to run unique dance and theatre classes taught by educated professionals. Here are just a few of the great teachers you can expect to take classes with at Soul Fire Studio:

 

~Alexa Luthor: Classically-trained in ballet for 19 years at Vermont Ballet Theatre School, Alexa moved out to Chicago to pursue graduate school and instead ended up falling in love with burlesque. She trained and graduated from Studio L'Amour, a prestigious burlesque studio in Chicago, IL. She then joined the cast of Boobs of Khan: A Star Trek Burlesque with Gorilla Tango Burlesque and later, Kiss Kiss Cabaret, premiere burlesque companies located in Chicago. She moved back to Vermont (because frankly, she missed it) to start her own company, Green Mountain Cabaret, a neo-burlesque variety show that performs monthly at Club Metronome. She is looking forward to teaching men and women burlesque, adult ballet, and more!

 

~Aeshna Mairéad: Aeshna has been belly dancing since 2010 in the Burlington, VT area. Fascinated with the art form since seeing belly dancers at the renaissance faire as a teenager but never having the opportunity to pursue it, she was finally able to find a belly dance fitness class in the summer of 2010. This class led her to other teachers in the area and she began studying American Cabaret, Improvisational Tribal Style, and Tribal Fusion. Aeshna also has experience in Turkish Romany dance.

Aeshna received her General Skills for ATS® and Teacher Training I and II Certifications in Atlanta, GA in 2012. She is a FatChanceBellyDance® Sister Studio. Aeshna has a great passion for American Tribal Style® and one of her greatest joys is found in building the community of dancers.

 

~Dustin Bruley: Dustin Bruley is a native Vermonter who studied improv for 4 years at Saint Michael's College. In addition to Saint Michael's, he has performed improv at the Waterfront Theater at Main Street Landing, the FlynnSpace, the Upright Citizens Brigade Theater in New York City, and at private events. He is also a founding member of local improv troupe People With Faces. He has taught improv for Diversity Arts, the Burlington School District, and Milton High School.

He has performed as a puppeteer for The PuppeTree, a puppet company based out of Thetford, VT, intermittently since 2011. In this capacity, he has constructed and performed with a variety of styles of puppets. This position has brought him into schools, libraries, and theaters in 6 states around the northeast. He has taught puppetry in classes lasting several hours, several days, several weeks, or several months, in various circumstances.

 

~Vienna Velvette: Vienna, as her name might suggest, has been enthralled by and involved with music since her mother's womb where she listened to her father play on stage while her mother ran lights while on tour. She was destined to be an artist even before she could understand the definition of one.

For many years, she took to the stage as a vocalist and actress, performing with several musical theater companies and attending North Carolina School of the Arts, where she majored in Opera and double majored in Wigs & Makeup. Vienna has had the privilege to work with and under the direction of Marion Pratnicki and Glenn Siebert for Voice and the amazingly talented and renowned Martha Ruskai for Wigs & Make Up. She has been involved with over 175 theater productions off and on stage including the Millennium Celebration at The Kennedy Center under the direction of James Allbritten, and Bizet's Carmen where she assisted Martha Ruskai under the direction of former Metropolitan Opera stage director, Bodo Igesz.  After over 20 years of performing, Vienna has finally found her home in cabaret and burlesque.  "The perfect trifecta of performance art, it encompasses everything I've learned over the years... sass, class, and seduction." 

 

~Christine Coe: After losing almost 50 pounds from attending hooping classes I decided to pursue becoming an instructor so that I could share my success and new found love of hooping with others. I am a Certified Hoopnotica Instructor and teach classes in both hoop dance and hoop fitness. Hooping will help improve balance and strengthen your core. It is a very low impact class that is easy on joints. You will typically burn 400-600 calories per hour while letting loose and having fun.

 

~Nicole Stevenson: She has been involved in fitness and dance since 2000. She grew up in Bethany, Connecticut and was always active. She played field hockey and lacrosse in High School and fell in-love with ballet after graduating Champlain College in 2007. Her love of ballet inspired her to study Pilates. She has been diligently working on her skills in both since 2008. She always knew that she would someday teach a class that fuses both dance and Pilates. She has been teaching ballet to children ages 3 to 12-years-old since the fall of 2009.  In the summer of 2011, she was hypnotized by some amazing hoop dancers. She started her hoop journey right then and there. She is now a Hoopnotica Certified Instructor and plans to spread her love of hooping with Vermont! “Keep on Hoopin'”

 

~Sonja Heins: Sonja will be teaching Poi/Fire Dance.* Sonja has been fire dancing since 2001 and has performed fire and non-fire poi at many venues including The Haunted Forest, Moonlight Body, Mind, Spirit Festival, Nightmare Vermont, Liberate Festival, Green Mountain Renaissance Fair, Jericho Medieval Fair, First Night and for private parties. Sonja has also taught three years of Beginner Poi. Organized and lead a fire dance troupe called The Poi-Rates which performed choreographed dances for Medieval festivals and for the Jericho Medieval Fair.

*Note: no open flame will be permitted inside Soul Fire Studio

 

The Breakdown

 

Your generous contribution will help to cover rent and utilities for two months (around $4000), specialty dance flooring for the downstairs dance studio, (quoted around $5000), mirrors for the walls (quoted around $500), installation of phone line and internet, dressing room essentials such as curtains, coat racks and benches, as well as securing some simple light and sound equipment for public performances on location.

 

The Impact of Your Donation

 

Your generous contribution will guarantee that a studio where alternative dance and theatre arts will be available to any member of the public for their artistic exploration. We are determined to open a space where anyone to discover their dream, learn in a comfortable classroom free of bias and judgment, and rent rehearsal/performance space for their artistic endeavors.

 

The Perks

 

The Shimmy

For $5, you will receive a Soul Fire bumper sticker and thanks on our website.

 

The Bump

For $10, you will receive a Soul Fire bumper sticker and button, and thanks on our website.

 

The Hip Roll

For $20, you will receive a Soul Fire bumper sticker, button, tee, and thanks on our website

 

The Hip Twist

For $50, you will receive a Soul Fire bumper sticker, button, tee, thanks on our website, as well as pasties by Alexa, a boa, and a hair flower by Aeshna.

 

The Wink and Smile

For $100, you will receive a Soul Fire bumper sticker, button, tee, thanks on our website, pasties by Alexa, a hair flower by Aeshna, and a boa and hip scarf to match your pasties and flower.

 

The Hip Circle

For $200, you will receive a Soul Fire bumper sticker, button, tee, thanks on our website, pasties by Alexa, a hair flower by Aeshna, a boa, hip scarf, and a two-hour group introductory workshop in belly dance or burlesque.

 

The Figure Eight

For $500, you will receive a Soul Fire bumper sticker, button, tee, thanks on our website, pasties by Alexa, a hair flower by Aeshna, a boa, hip scarf, a two-hour group introductory workshop in belly dance or burlesque, and two VIP tickets to Green Mountain Cabaret.

 

The Bump and Grind

For $1000, you will receive a Soul Fire bumper sticker, button, tee, and thanks on our website, pasties by Alexa, a hair flower by Aeshna, a boa, hip scarf, a complete class session of your choice, and four VIP tickets to Green Mountain Cabaret.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

We understand that times are tough for everyone. If you can’t contribute monetarily but would still like to help, like us on Facebook and share our page with all your friends! Please help us spread the word that Vermont is gaining an amazing new space for artistic expression!

Fascinated with the art form since seeing belly dancers at the renaissance faire as a teenager but never having the opportunity to pursue it, she was finally able to find a belly dance fitness class in the summer of 2010. Aeshna received her General Skills for ATS® and Teacher Training I and II Certifications in Atlanta, GA in 2012. She is a FatChanceBellyDance® Sister Studio. Aeshna has a great passion for American Tribal Style® and one of her greatest joys is found in building the community of dancers.
 
~Dustin Bruley: Dustin Bruley is a native Vermonter who studied improv for 4 years at Saint Michael's College. In addition to Saint Michael's, he has performed improv at the Waterfront Theater at Main Street Landing, the FlynnSpace, the Upright Citizens Brigade Theater in New York City, and at private events. He is also a founding member of local improv troupe People With Faces. He has taught improv for Diversity Arts, the Burlington School District, and Milton High School.
He has performed as a puppeteer for The PuppeTree, a puppet company based out of Thetford, VT, intermittently since 2011. In this capacity, he has constructed and performed with a variety of styles of puppets. This position has brought him into schools, libraries, and theaters in 6 states around the northeast. He has taught puppetry in classes lasting several hours, several days, several weeks, or several months, in various circumstances.
 
~Vienna Velvette: Vienna, as her name might suggest, has been enthralled by and involved with music since her mother's womb where she listened to her father play on stage while her mother ran lights while on tour. She was destined to be an artist even before she could understand the definition of one.
For many years, she took to the stage as a vocalist and actress, performing with several musical theater companies and attending North Carolina School of the Arts, where she majored in Opera and double majored in Wigs & Makeup. Vienna has had the privilege to work with and under the direction of Marion Pratnicki and Glenn Siebert for Voice and the amazingly talented and renowned Martha Ruskai for Wigs & Make Up. She has been involved with over 175 theater productions off and on stage including the Millennium Celebration at The Kennedy Center under the direction of James Allbritten, and Bizet's Carmen where she assisted Martha Ruskai under the direction of former Metropolitan Opera stage director, Bodo Igesz.  After over 20 years of performing, Vienna has finally found her home in cabaret and burlesque.  "The perfect trifecta of performance art, it encompasses everything I've learned over the years... sass, class, and seduction." 
 
~Christine Coe: After losing almost 50 pounds from attending hooping classes I decided to pursue becoming an instructor so that I could share my success and new found love of hooping with others. I am a Certified Hoopnotica Instructor and teach classes in both hoop dance and hoop fitness. Hooping will help improve balance and strengthen your core. It is a very low impact class that is easy on joints. You will typically burn 400-600 calories per hour while letting loose and having fun.
 
~Nicole Stevenson: She has been involved in fitness and dance since 2000. She grew up in Bethany, Connecticut and was always active. She played field hockey and lacrosse in High School and fell in-love with ballet after graduating Champlain College in 2007. Her love of ballet inspired her to study Pilates. She has been diligently working on her skills in both since 2008. She always knew that she would someday teach a class that fuses both dance and Pilates. She has been teaching ballet to children ages 3 to 12-years-old since the fall of 2009.  In the summer of 2011, she was hypnotized by some amazing hoop dancers. She started her hoop journey right then and there. She is now a Hoopnotica Certified Instructor and plans to spread her love of hooping with Vermont! “Keep on Hoopin'”
 
~Sonja Heins: Sonja will be teaching Poi/Fire Dance.* Sonja has been fire dancing since 2001 and has performed fire and non-fire poi at many venues including The Haunted Forest, Moonlight Body, Mind, Spirit Festival, Nightmare Vermont, Liberate Festival, Green Mountain Renaissance Fair, Jericho Medieval Fair, First Night and for private parties. Sonja has also taught three years of Beginner Poi. Organized and lead a fire dance troupe called The Poi-Rates which performed choreographed dances for Medieval festivals and for the Jericho Medieval Fair.
*Note: no open flame will be permitted inside Soul Fire Studio
 
The Breakdown
 
Your generous contribution will help to cover rent and utilities for two months (around $4000), specialty dance flooring for the downstairs dance studio, (quoted around $5000), mirrors for the walls (quoted around $500), installation of phone line and internet, dressing room essentials such as curtains, coat racks and benches, as well as securing some simple light and sound equipment for public performances on location.
 
The Impact of Your Donation
 
Your generous contribution will guarantee that a studio where alternative dance and theatre arts will be available to any member of the public for their artistic exploration. We are determined to open a space where anyone to discover their dream, learn in a comfortable classroom free of bias and judgment, and rent rehearsal/performance space for their artistic endeavors.

Other Ways You Can Help
 
We understand that times are tough for everyone. If you can’t contribute monetarily but would still like to help, like us on Facebook and share our page with all your friends! Please help us spread the word that Vermont is gaining an amazing new space for artistic expression!
